title: Ellis v. Davidson
description: In this appeal from a grant of partial summary judgment, Appellant primarily argues the trial judge erred in: (1) finding there was no attorney/client relationship created between Respondents' attorneys and Appellant, and, as a result, granting summary judgment in favor of Respondents on the causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty and attorney malpractice; (2) refusing to consider an expert witness affidavit; (3) granting summary judgment as to all causes of actions against one of the parties to the suit; and (4) granting summary judgment when there were outstanding motions and discovery.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

 

  
    
      
Mark W. Ellis, individually, and in the right of American Survey, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Eric J. Davidson, L. Russell Bennett, Jarrel L. Wigger, Mark W. Weeks, Kelly 
  Davis, American Survey, Inc., Davidson and Bennett, Absolute Survey, Inc., jointly 
  and severally, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3748
Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  1, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Cynthia B. Castengera, of Newland, NC and D. Dusty 
  Rhoades, of Charleston, for Appellant.
M. Dawes Cooke, Jr. and K. Michael Barfield, both of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Mark W. Ellis, individually and on behalf of American 
  Survey, Inc., appeals from the trial judgeâ€™s grant of partial summary judgment 
  to Respondents.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the spring of 1998, Ellis, a licensed surveyor, 
  decided to start his own residential surveying company.Â  Ellis contacted Rusty 
  Bennett, a partner at the law firm of Davidson & Bennett (the Firm) because 
  he needed an investor.Â  Ellis had performed prior survey work for the Firm.Â  
  According to Ellis, Bennett agreed to invest in the company and stated:

That he would handle all of the legal paperwork and make 
  sure that the company was set up properly and that [Ellisâ€™s] rights were protected. 
  . . . [Bennett] said he would cover all legal advice involving [Ellis] and the 
  company, for [Ellis] not to worry about anything other than producing surveys.

Ellis believed that, in having the Firm invest 
  in the business, he would be able to perform work for the Firm and have the 
  Firm set up the surveying company in such a way that he was protected from liability.Â  
  After Bennett invested, the business ownership was: Bennett â€“ 60%; Ellis â€“ 40%; 
  the 1000 shares of common stock would be divided proportionally, with no restrictions 
  placed upon them; Bennett would â€œset upâ€ the surveying company; and Ellis would 
  be employed by the surveying company.Â  Other than proposed business plans, no 
  written contracts or documents memorialize the agreement between Ellis and Bennett.Â  
  The parties created American Survey, Inc. (American).Â  Bennett set up the company 
  and arranged for American to lease space in a building he owned.Â  At some point, 
  Bennettâ€™s law partner in the Firm, Eric Davidson, became a shareholder in American.Â  
  Ellis claimed that, in January of 1999, he â€œwas told [the new percentage of 
  ownership] was one-third, one-third, one-third.â€Â  Bennett professed he â€œbelieve[d] 
  . . . the agreement . . . was that [he and Davidson] would hold 65 percent of 
  the shares and [Ellis] would have 35 percent of the shares.â€ 
  [1] 
Several months later, Bennett retired from 
  the practice of law and sold his interest in the Firm and the Firmâ€™s businesses 
  (including American) to his three partners: Davidson, Jarrell Wigger, and Mark 
  Weeks (hereinafter, â€œthe Firmâ€).Â  After Bennettâ€™s retirement, the Firm instructed 
  Ellis not to sign a new lease with Bennett.Â  The Firm met with Ellis after discovering 
  Bennett never filed Americanâ€™s corporate papers.Â  In fact, Bennett never kept 
  corporate minutes, records, or by-laws for American.Â  Ellis testified the members 
  of the Firm told him they were acting as attorneys for the corporation, and 
  that he should sign the papers as instructed. 
Ellis and the Firm soon disagreed over the way 
  Ellis operated American.Â  At a meeting in March of 1999, Ellis told the Firm 
  he wanted to buy out their interest in American.Â  After offers and counteroffers 
  were made and rejected, the parties came to a verbal agreement about the buyout.Â  
  The agreement was put into writing, and Ellis and Davidson faxed revisions back 
  and forth.Â  While admitting the buyout negotiations were â€œa matter strictly 
  of business,â€ Ellis stated the Firm did not advise him to obtain separate counsel, 
  and that he thought the Firm acted as attorneys on behalf of both American and 
  himself.Â  The agreement was not finalized, as Ellis wanted a written commitment 
  from the Firm that American would still continue to be used as the Firmâ€™s chief 
  surveying company.Â  In order to force a decision, Ellis informed the Firm that 
  he would close Americanâ€™s doors and terminate its employees if the Firm did 
  not agree to his terms.Â  The Firm then decided to close American themselves.Â  
  They arrived at American with deputy sheriffs, terminated the employees, and 
  changed the locks.
At approximately the same time Ellis and the Firm 
  were in the midst of buyout discussions, the Firm decided to form a new surveying 
  company. Members of the Firm testified the new company, Absolute Survey Inc. 
  (Absolute), would be run by Kelly Davis and would perform surveying for the 
  Firm after Ellis bought their interests in American.Â  Ellis declared that, while 
  he was aware of Absoluteâ€™s formation, he did not realize it would be a competing 
  surveying company.
On behalf of American and in his individual capacity, Ellis filed 
  an amended complaint against the Firm (including the lawyers in their individual 
  capacities), American, Absolute, and Davis.Â  Ellis alleged various causes of 
  action, including breach of fiduciary duty, legal malpractice, conversion, and 
  civil conspiracy.Â  The Firm and the lawyers in their individual capacities answered, 
  counterclaimed, and moved for summary judgment.Â  Additionally, the Firm asked 
  for summary judgment for Davis as to all claims against him.
The Circuit judge granted the Firmâ€™s summary judgment motion as to the causes 
  of action for legal malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty.Â  The judge denied 
  the motion for summary judgment as to the remaining causes of action.Â  Further, 
  the judge granted summary judgment in Davisâ€™s favor as to all causes of action 
  against him.Â  The judge denied Ellisâ€™s subsequent motion for reconsideration.
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I.
         
  Did the trial judge err in classifying the relationship that existed between 
  the parties?
      
      
         II.
        Did the trial judge err
          in â€œdiscountingâ€ the expert witness affidavit?
      
      
         III.  
         
  Did the trial judge err in dismissing Kelly Davis as a party?
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court 
  applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: 
  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Laurens 
  Emergency Med. Specialists v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 104, 
  584 S.E.2d 375 (2003); Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 
  (2002); Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 
  2003); Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence 
  and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in 
  the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Public Serv. 
  Auth., 354 S.C. 397, 581 S.E.2d 161 (2003); Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 
  353 S.C. 449, 578 S.E.2d 711 (2003); McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 
  499 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998); see also Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists, 
  355 S.C. at 108, 584 S.E.2d at 377 (stating that in reviewing summary judgment 
  motion, facts and circumstances must be viewed in light most favorable to non-moving 
  party).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.Â  Baril 
  v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 573 S.E.2d 830 (Ct. App. 2002); 
  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 
  413 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, depositions, answers to 
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, 
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving 
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Russell v. Wachovia Bank, 
  N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 578 S.E.2d 329 (2003); Regions Bank, 354 S.C. 
  at 659, 582 S.E.2d at 438; Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 
  348 S.C. 340, 559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  All ambiguities, 
  conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most 
  strongly against the moving party.Â  Schmidt v. Courtney, Op. No. 3719 
  (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 22, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 1 at 66); Bayle 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 
  2001); see also Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 
  349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002) (â€œOn appeal from an order granting 
  summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, 
  and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to 
  the non-moving party below.â€).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of 
  the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Brockbank v. 
  Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688 (2000); Bayle, 344 
  S.C. at 120, 542 S.E.2d at 738.Â  Summary judgment should not be granted even 
  when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts if there is disagreement concerning 
  the conclusion to be drawn from those facts.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary 
  Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000).Â  However, when plain, 
  palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, 
  summary judgment should be granted.Â  Hedgepath, 348 S.C. at 355, 559 
  S.E.2d at 336; Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 426, 480 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 
  1997).
Under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, the party seeking summary judgment has the initial 
  burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  Regions 
  Bank, 354 S.C. at 659, 582 S.E.2d at 438; Trivelas v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Once the 
  party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence 
  of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest 
  on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Regions Bank, 
  354 S.C. at 660, 582 S.E.2d at 438.Â  Rather, the nonmoving party must come forward 
  with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.Â  SSI Med. 
  Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 392 S.E.2d 789 (1990); Peterson v. 
  West American Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 518 S.E.2d 608 (Ct. App. 1999); Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of 
  cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 
  354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 548 
  S.E.2d 868 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Relationship 
  Between the Parties

A.Â  Fiduciary Duty

Ellis argues the trial judge erred in finding there was no evidence of a fiduciary 
  duty between the Firm and Ellis and/or American.Â  We agree.
A fiduciary relationship is founded on the trust 
  and confidence reposed by one person in the integrity and fidelity of another.Â  
  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003); 
  Redwend Ltd. Partnership v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. 
  App. 2003); Steele v. Victory Sav. Bank, 295 S.C. 290, 368 S.E.2d 91 
  (Ct. App. 1988).Â  A fiduciary relationship exists when one imposes a special 
  confidence in another, so that the latter, in equity and good conscience, is 
  bound to act in good faith and with due regard to the interests of the one imposing 
  the confidence.Â  Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 353 S.C. 449, 578 S.E.2d 
  711 (2003); Oâ€™Shea v. Lesser, 308 S.C. 10, 416 S.E.2d 629 (1992); SSI 
  Med. Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 392 S.E.2d 789 (1990); Regions 
  Bank, 354 S.C. at 670, 582 S.E.2d at 444; Steele, 295 S.C. at 293, 
  368 S.E.2d at 93.Â  A relationship must be more than casual to equal a fiduciary 
  relationship.Â  Regions Bank, 354 S.C. at 670, 582 S.E.2d at 444; Steele, 
  295 S.C. at 293, 368 S.E.2d at 93.
As a general rule, a fiduciary relationship cannot be created by 
  the unilateral action of one party.Â  Regions Bank, 354 S.C. at 670, 582 
  S.E.2d at 444; Brown v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 483 S.E.2d 477 (Ct. App. 
  1997).Â  To establish the existence of a fiduciary relationship, the facts and 
  circumstances must indicate the party reposing trust in another has some foundation 
  for believing the one so entrusted will act not in his own behalf but in the 
  interest of the party so reposing.Â  Burwell v. South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank, 
  288 S.C. 34, 340 S.E.2d 786 (1986).Â  The evidence must show the entrusted party 
  actually accepted or induced the confidence placed in him.Â  Regions Bank, 
  354 S.C. at 671, 582 S.E.2d at 444; State v. Parris, 353 S.C. 582, 578 
  S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2003); Brown, 326 S.C. at 423, 483 S.E.2d at 484.
We find there are genuine issues of material fact as 
  to whether a fiduciary duty existed between the Firm and Ellis, in his individual 
  and representative capacities.Â  There is evidence that Ellis relied upon the 
  Firmâ€™s legal expertise and reposed a â€œtrust and confidenceâ€ in the Firm in their 
  joint business dealings.Â  The Firm had always tendered legal advice to Ellis, 
  even after American was set up.Â  For example, Davidson instructed Ellis to speak 
  to Wigger about an American employee who was injured in the course of his employment.
We rule that genuine issues of material fact exist as to whether 
  the Firm breached a fiduciary duty in its treatment of Ellis, both in his individual 
  and representative capacities.Â  We disagree with the judgeâ€™s finding that any 
  such duty ended with the formation of American.Â  Bennett was integral to the 
  process of structuring and incorporating American.Â  When asked who â€œhad the 
  responsibility of handling all of the legal work with the formation of American,â€ 
  Bennett responded: â€œThat would have been me or our firm.â€Â  According to Ellis, 
  even after American was set up and Bennett left the Firm, the remaining members 
  of the Firm told Ellis they were acting as Americanâ€™s attorneys.Â  When queried 
  regarding whether he or the Firm gave advice to Ellis personally or to American, 
  Weeks answered: â€œAmerican Survey.â€Â Â Â Â  The Firm instructed Ellis about: (1) 
  breaking Americanâ€™s lease in Bennettâ€™s building and (2) following their advice 
  in signing papers to properly incorporate American.Â  In fact, when the parties 
  were engaged in buyout negotiations, Ellis testified he did not obtain separate 
  counsel because he believed the Firm acted as attorneys for both himself and 
  American.
We conclude genuine issues of material fact exist as to whether there was a 
  fiduciary duty and, if so, whether such duty was breached.Â  Accordingly, the 
  trial judge erred in granting summary judgment on this issue.

B.Â  Attorney-Client Relationship

Ellis contends the trial judge erred in finding there 
  was insufficient evidence of an attorney-client relationship between the Firm 
  and Ellis and/or American.Â  We agree.
Our courts have recognized the attorney-client relationship is, by 
  its very nature, a fiduciary one.Â  Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 353 S.C. 
  449, 578 S.E.2d 711 (2003); Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 532 S.E.2d 
  310 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Hotz v. Minyard, 304 S.C. 225, 403 
  S.E.2d 634 (1991) (noting that attorney-client relationship is by nature a fiduciary 
  one); De Pass v. Piedmont Interstate Fair Assâ€™n, 217 S.C. 38, 59 S.E.2d 
  495 (1950) (stating that a fiduciary relationship always exists between attorney 
  and client).Â  The relationship between an attorney and a client is highly fiduciary 
  in its nature and of a very delicate, exacting and confidential character, requiring 
  a high degree of fidelity and good faith.Â  Weatherford, 340 S.C. at 582, 
  532 S.E.2d at 315; 7 Am. Jur. 2d Attorneys at Law Â§ 137 (1997).
In the instant case, the Firm was intricately involved in Americanâ€™s businessâ€”from 
  the time of its formation until the Firmâ€™s lockout of the company.Â  Bennett 
  drafted the initial incorporation papers for American and, after Bennett left 
  the Firm, the remaining Firm attorneys re-drafted and filed Americanâ€™s corporate 
  papers.Â  The following colloquy occurred during Ellisâ€™s deposition:

QÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Can you think of any other personal legal advice 
  that they have given you?
AÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Yes.Â  At our second meeting at Davidson and Bennett, 
  the missing corporate books showed up that were at the James Island office the 
  whole time, and Eric stated that Jerry would be going over with me the corporate 
  books and what needed to be taken care of.
Jerry opened up the books sitting there at the table across from me and said, 
  none of this stuff ha[s] been done, all of the forms are blank.Â  That I could 
  get sued personally.Â  Mark Weeks jumped up and said, we are one station wagon 
  loaded full of kids with a soccer mom going through an intersection and having 
  one of our vehicles hit her, and that I could be sued personally and they could 
  take everything that I own.
Jerry flipped open the book and said, you need to sign here and we get our ass 
  offâ€”you need to sign here, you need to sign here.Â  I am sitting there going, 
  shit, I had no idea, Rusty was supposed to be taking care of this.
At the same time they are going, this company is a â€œCâ€ corp., Rusty put the 
  screws to us, we should have been a â€œSâ€ corp.Â  Rusty made it a â€œCâ€ corp. to 
  protect his ass.Â  That is the only reason Rusty did it.Â  He didnâ€™t give a shit 
  about you, Mark.Â  He has this thing as a â€œCâ€ corp.
Sign here, sign here, take care of this.Â  I am thinking, the signatures I am 
  putting on these blank sheets of paper, if you look, you will see they are not 
  only blank, but they are not dated, was to protect me from getting sued.Â  This 
  is what they are telling me sitting in that office--
QÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Who told you--
AÂ Â Â Â Â Â  --they are protecting my rights.
QÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Who told you that?
AÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Mark Weeks, Jerry Wigger and Eric Davidson, sitting 
  in there.
QÂ Â Â Â Â Â  What did you sign?
AÂ Â Â Â Â Â  I signed every piece of paper they threw in front 
  [of] me that they said would cause me to get sued by some soccer mom loaded 
  up full of kids.
QÂ Â Â Â Â Â  What were the papers that you signed?
AÂ Â Â Â Â Â  I signed a bunch of papers.Â  I couldnâ€™t tell you 
  the exact one.Â  I tell you how quick it went, you need to sign here, flip, flip, 
  you need to sign here, flip, flip, and sign here and sign here, and this is 
  going to protect you, Mark, this is going to stop that soccer mom loaded full 
  of kids from suing you personally.
QÂ Â Â Â Â Â  You mean by making sure that the corporation was 
  duly incorporated, is that what they were telling you?
AÂ Â Â Â Â Â  What they told me, what Jerry Wigger told me, in 
  particular, as I was told from Eric, that he was a business attorney for the 
  group, was that a corporation has to act as a corporation.Â  It cannot act as 
  just some little fly by night, oh, yeah, we filed some paperwork with the State, 
  therefore, we have this corporate veil, we are impenetrable personally by it.
Jerry said that is what he did all day long is pierce the corporate veil in 
  order to go after personal assets, personal, private assets, and that he was 
  protecting me by me signing these documents.

After American was properly formed, the Firm advised Ellis on at least one 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation matter and acted in Americanâ€™s interest in negotiating 
  a new lease for Americanâ€™s offices.Â  In addition, the Firm did not advise Ellis 
  to obtain outside counsel during the buyout negotiations.
We conclude there was ample evidence presented to overcome summary judgment 
  on this matter.Â  Concomitantly, the trial judge erred in finding there was insufficient 
  evidence of an attorney-client relationship.

C.Â  Legal Malpractice

Ellis maintains the trial judge erred in finding there was no evidence of legal 
  malpractice.Â  We agree.
In order
to prevail in a legal malpractice action, the plaintiff must prove four
elements:

  
    
      
        (1) 
        the existence of an
          attorney-client relationship;
      
      
        (2) 
        a breach of duty by the
          attorney;
      
      
        (3)
         damage to the
          client; and
      
      
        (4)
         proximate
          causation of the clientâ€™s damages by the breach.
      
    
  

Smith v. Haynsworth, Marion, McKay &
Geurard, 322 S.C. 433, 472 S.E.2d 612 (1996); Sims
v. Hall, Op. No. 3703 (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 8, 2003) (Shearouse Adv.
Sh. No. 43 at 60); Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 561 S.E.2d 654 (Ct. App.
2002); Henkel v. Winn, 346 S.C. 14, 550 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 2001); McNair
v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 499 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998).
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Ellis and American, 
  we find there was sufficient evidence presented on the issue of legal malpractice 
  to survive the Firmâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Factual issues exist as 
  to the (1) buyout negotiations; (2) subsequent lockout of the American offices; 
  and (3) Firmâ€™s formation of a rival surveying company, Absolute, in the midst 
  of these buyout negotiations.Â  We disagree with the trial judgeâ€™s finding that 
  no evidence exists as to damages.Â  The damages Ellis and American suffered in 
  this case flowed from the improper formation of American.Â  The Firm did not 
  perform several functions, including: issuing stock certificates, holding an 
  organizational meeting, writing by-laws, drafting an employment contract for 
  Ellis, and preparing documentation that Ellis loaned personal equipment to American.Â  
  If the Firm had drafted these documents, the rights and responsibilities of 
  the parties could have been clearly laid out.Â  For example, stock restrictions 
  could have been implemented, corporate governance could have been set out, a 
  right of first refusal in transferring company stock could have been included, 
  and the procedure for valuing and selling American could have been devised and 
  agreed upon by the parties.Â  As a result of the Firmâ€™s poor drafting, Ellis 
  was not apprised of the proper procedures and methods for governing American.Â  
  He was later literally and figuratively shut out of Americanâ€™s operation.Â  Further, 
  as there was no documentation of equipment loaned to American, Ellis lost several 
  pieces of personal property when the Firm effected a lockout of the company.Â  
  Finally, genuine issues of material fact exist as to whether these damages were 
  proximately caused by the Firmâ€™s improper formation of American.
II.Â  Affidavit 
  from Expert Witness
Ellis asserts the trial judge erred in â€œdiscountingâ€ an affidavit from an expert 
  witness.Â  We agree.
The admission or exclusion of expert testimony is a matter within the sound 
  discretion of the trial court.Â  Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 495 S.E.2d 
  205 (1998); Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 574 S.E.2d 215 (Ct. App. 
  2002); Means v. Gates, 348 S.C. 161, 558 S.E.2d 921 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  A trial courtâ€™s decision to admit or exclude expert testimony will not be disturbed 
  on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 
  392, 570 S.E.2d 176 (2002); Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 
  354 S.C. 445, 581 S.E.2d 489 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Grubbs, 353 S.C. 
  374, 577 S.E.2d 493 (Ct. App. 2003); Burroughs, 352 S.C. at 390, 574 
  S.E.2d at 219.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when there is an error of law 
  or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.Â  Fontaine v. 
  Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 354 S.E.2d 565 (1987); Fields, 354 S.C. at 451, 
  581 S.E.2d at 492; Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 
  340, 559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 
  344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001); see also Zabinski v. 
  Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001) (stating that 
  abuse of discretion occurs where trial court is controlled by error of law or 
  where trial courtâ€™s order is based on factual conclusions without evidentiary 
  support).Â  A courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of an expertâ€™s testimony constitutes 
  an abuse of discretion where the ruling is manifestly arbitrary, unreasonable, 
  or unfair.Â  Fields, 354 S.C. at 451, 581 S.E.2d at 492; Grubbs, 
  353 S.C. at 379, 577 S.E.2d at 496; Means, 348 S.C. at 166, 558 S.E.2d 
  at 924.
In order for this Court to reverse a judgment for an alleged error in the exclusion 
  of evidence, the complaining party must prove both the error of the ruling and 
  resulting prejudice.Â  Fields, 354 S.C. at 451, 581 S.E.2d at 492; Means, 
  348 S.C. at 166, 558 S.E.2d at 924; see also Lee v. Suess, 318 
  S.C. 283, 457 S.E.2d 344 (1995) (admission of expert testimony is within sound 
  discretion of trial judge and will not be overruled absent finding of abuse 
  of discretion and prejudice to complaining party); Stevens v. Allen, 
  336 S.C. 439, 448, 520 S.E.2d 625, 629 (Ct. App. 1999), affâ€™d, 342 S.C. 
  47, 536 S.E.2d 663 (2000) (â€œFor this Court to reverse a case based on the admission 
  of evidence, both error and prejudice must be shown.â€); Potomac Leasing Co. 
  v. Bone, 294 S.C. 494, 497, 366 S.E.2d 26, 28 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œBefore the 
  Court of Appeals will reverse a judgment for an alleged error in the exclusion 
  of evidence, the appellant must show prejudice.â€).
Rule 702, SCRE, articulates guidelines for the admissibility of expert 
  testimony.Â  Rule 702 provides: â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized 
  knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine 
  a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, 
  training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  
  Rule 702, SCRE.Â  For a court to find a witness competent to testify as an expert, 
  the witness must be better qualified than the fact finder to form an opinion 
  on the particular subject of the testimony.Â  Mizell, 351 S.C. at 406, 
  570 S.E.2d at 183; Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 
  487 S.E.2d 596 (1997); Crawford v. Henderson, 356 S.C. 389, 589 S.E.2d 
  204 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Fields, 354 S.C. at 452, 581 S.E.2d 
  at 492 (to be competent as expert, witness must have acquired, by reason of 
  study or experience, or both, such knowledge and skill in a business, profession, 
  or science that he is better qualified than the fact finder to form an opinion).
At the summary judgment hearing, Ellis presented an expert affidavit from Gregory 
  Adams, a University of South Carolina law school professor and expert on legal 
  ethics.Â  Adams concluded the Firm â€œincompetently set upâ€ American and failed 
  to properly advise Ellis about several important matters while forming the company.Â  
  Adams opined there was an attorney-client relationship between the parties, 
  and that this relationship was subsequently breached by the Firmâ€™s actions.Â  
  Adams noted the Firm engaged in transactions which conflicted with their responsibilities 
  to Ellis and American.Â  The trial judge ruled:

[Adamsâ€™s] affidavit . . . cannot create the requisite factual 
  issue because it is based on factual assumptions about advice provided to Plaintiff 
  Ellis, which assumptions are not supported by the record in this case. . . . 
  [A]s the record establishes that the only potential legal advice provided to 
  Ellis was with regard to formation of the corporation and obtaining workerâ€™s 
  compensation insurance, Dr. Adamsâ€™ affidavit does not change this Courtâ€™s conclusion 
  that no attorney-client relationship existed between Ellis and the Defendants 
  that resulted in any damages alleged in this action.

The record supports Adamsâ€™s conclusions in the affidavit, and, when considered 
  in conjunction with Ellisâ€™s testimony, presented a genuine issue of material 
  fact about the questions of breach of fiduciary duty, the existence of an attorney-client 
  relationship, and legal malpractice.Â  As the affidavit was crucial to proving 
  the Firm breached a fiduciary duty in their attorney-client relationship with 
  Ellis and American, Ellis, in his individual and representative capacities, 
  was prejudiced by the courtâ€™s ruling.Â  See Hall v. Fedor, 349 
  S.C. 169, 561 S.E.2d 654 (Ct. App. 2002) (explaining the client in a legal malpractice 
  action must generally establish the standard of care by expert testimony).
The trial judge abused his discretion in failing to give efficacy 
  to the expert witness affidavit.Â  Because this resulted in prejudice to Ellis 
  and American, it was error.
III.Â  Dismissal 
  of Davis
Ellis argues the trial judge erred in dismissing Kelly Davis from the lawsuit.Â  
  We disagree.
In the complaint, Ellis and American included Kelly 
  Davis, the surveyor for Absolute, as a party in this action on the grounds of 
  civil conspiracy and conversion.Â  The trial judge granted Davisâ€™s motion for 
  summary judgment as to all causes of action raised against him.Â  We agree with 
  the trial judgeâ€™s ruling on this issue.

 A.Â  Civil Conspiracy

A civil conspiracy consists of three elements: (1) a combination 
  of two or more persons; (2) for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff; 
  (3) which causes the plaintiff special damage.Â  Lawson v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Corrections, 340 S.C. 346, 532 S.E.2d 259 (2000); Robertson 
  v. First Union Natâ€™l Bank, 350 S.C. 339, 565 S.E.2d 309 (Ct. App. 2002); 
  Lee v. Chesterfield Gen. Hosp., Inc., 289 S.C. 6, 344 S.E.2d 379 (Ct. 
  App. 1986).Â  Ellis did not prove Davis engaged in a civil conspiracy with the 
  Firm in order to purposely injure either Ellis or American.Â  We find no genuine 
  issue of material fact exists in the allegations levied against Davis.Â  Ellis 
  proved only that Davis was involved with the Firm in the formation of Absolute, 
  not that he undertook this enterprise for the purpose of injuring either Ellis 
  or American.Â  Because Ellis could not establish the second element of civil 
  conspiracy, the trial judge did not err in granting summary judgment in Davisâ€™s 
  favor.

B.Â  Conversion

Conversion is the unauthorized assumption and exercise of the right 
  of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging to another, to the alteration 
  of the condition or the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.Â  Regions Bank v. 
  Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Davis is not liable 
  for Absoluteâ€™s alleged conversion of Americanâ€™s property.Â  Absolute is a corporation.Â  
  Davis may use the disputed equipment but only in his capacity as a surveyor 
  employed by Absolute.Â  Ellis and American have not alleged that Davis personally 
  gained from the property in question.Â  They aver only that Absolute has benefited 
  from it.Â  Even if Davis had believed the property belonged to Ellis or American, 
  he would have had no authority to dispose of it without the approval of the 
  corporation.Â  In the Appellantsâ€™ brief, Ellis and American assert: â€œDavis is 
  the responsible party at Absolute.â€Â  However, Davis is a surveyor for Absolute.Â  
  He is an employee of the corporation and a minority shareholder.Â  This does 
  not make him personally liable to Ellis and American for property that Absolute, 
  as a corporation, has allegedly converted.Â  The judge properly granted summary 
  judgment to Davis.
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing, the trial judgeâ€™s order granting the Firmâ€™s motion 
  for partial summary judgment [2]  
  is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED. [3] 
 HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

 
    [1]
    
   
    While Ellis and Bennett disagree over the series of events leading to Davidsonâ€™s 
    participation in American, it is clear Davidson was involved early in Americanâ€™s 
    formation.

 
    [2]
    
   
    On remand, the Circuit Court will evaluate all issues separately and distinctly 
    in regard to Mark W. Ellis, individually, and American Survey, Inc.

 
    [3]
    
   
    Ellis alleges the trial judge erred in granting summary judgment while there 
    were outstanding motions and discovery in this case.Â  However, as we are reversing 
    and remanding this case on several issues, we need not reach this one.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cynthia P. Goldston, Personal Representative of the Estate of Neil Bryan
Goldston, Sr., Appellant,
v.
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â Gene M. Connell, Jr., Special Referee 

Opinion No. 3749
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  1, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Neil D. Wright, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Linda Weeks Gangi, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Cynthia P. Goldston, 
  as personal representative to the estate of Neil Bryan Goldston, Sr., appeals 
  the special refereeâ€™s ruling in favor of State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance 
  Company in this declaratory judgment action concerning State Farmâ€™s obligation 
  to pay underinsured motorist coverage benefits.Â  We affirm, as modified.
FACTS
The facts in this case are undisputed.Â  
  On August 22, 1991, Rickie D. Johnson was driving a pickup truck along a highway 
  in Georgetown County, South Carolina.Â  The truck ran off the highway and struck 
  Neil Bryan Goldston, Sr., who died from injuries sustained in the collision.Â  
  Johnson was involved in repossessing three vehicles on behalf of his employer, 
  American Lenders Service Company of Charleston, Inc., at the time of the accident.Â  

The truck driven by Johnson was insured 
  under a policy issued by the South Carolina Insurance Company.Â  This policy 
  contained liability limits of $100,000 per person.Â  At the time of the accident, 
  the truck was titled under the name â€œS.C. Auto Sales & Recovery, by A.M 
  Sprague, V.P.â€Â Â Â  S.C. Auto Sales and Recovery is not, and never has been, a 
  registered corporation, partnership, or other legal entity.Â Â Â  
In 1974, Sprague formed a South Carolina 
  corporation under the name of Southern Recovery Service, Inc., for the operation 
  of a â€œcollateral recoveryâ€ or repossession business.Â  By amendment to the articles 
  of incorporation, the business was renamed to South Carolina Auto Recovery Services, 
  Inc.Â  Sprague was the sole owner and stockholder of this corporation.Â  
In September 1979, Sprague acquired a 
  franchise from American Lenders Service Company of Odessa, Texas (â€œAmerican 
  of Texasâ€) for the operation of a collateral recovery business under the name 
  American Lenders Service Company of Charleston.Â  From this time forward, the 
  business of South Carolina Auto Recovery Services, Inc. was conducted under 
  the name of American Lenders Service Company of Charleston.Â  In 1984, Sprague 
  and his wife, Linda, created a new South Carolina corporation under the name 
  of American Lenders Service Company of Charleston, Inc. (â€œAmerican of Charlestonâ€).Â  
  They are the companyâ€™s sole owners, officers, and directors, and Sprague is 
  an employee.Â  All of the operating assets of South Carolina Auto Recovery Service, 
  Inc. were transferred to American of Charleston, and South Carolina Auto Recovery 
  Service, Inc. was dissolved in June 1985. 
Although the Spragues have conducted their 
  business under the name of American of Charleston since 1979, the trucks used 
  to perform their repossession business were both titled and insured under the 
  name of S.C. Auto Sales & Recovery.Â  Even trucks purchased after the incorporation 
  of American of Charleston were titled and insured under the name of S.C. Auto 
  Sales & Recovery.Â Â Â  
American of Charleston paid the purchase 
  price of the truck Mr. Johnson was driving at the time of the accident as well 
  as all of the insurance, taxes, gas, upkeep, and registration expenses.Â Â  The 
  truck is listed as an asset on American of Charlestonâ€™s financial statements, 
  and American of Charleston claimed depreciation of the truck on its income tax 
  returns.Â Â Â Â  Furthermore, the truck was used to repossess vehicles on behalf 
  of American of Charleston, and was being so used at the time of the accident. 

Appellant, the decedentâ€™s 
  personal representative, commenced wrongful death and survival actions against 
  the driver of the truck, the Spragues d/b/a S. C. Auto Sales and Recovery, American 
  of Charleston, American of Texas, and General Motors Acceptance Corporation 
  d/b/a GMAC Financial Services.Â  All parties answered denying liability for Goldstonâ€™s 
  death.Â  
The parties reached a settlement in which 
  the Appellant received $700,000.Â  The liability insurance carrier on the truck 
  involved in the accident, South Carolina Insurance Company, paid its limits 
  of $100,000.Â Â Â  The remainder of the settlement was paid by National American 
  Insurance Company (â€œNationalâ€).Â  American of Charleston maintained an insurance 
  policy with National consisting of a commercial general liability coverage, 
  commercial auto coverage, and commercial inland marine coverage, which contained 
  limits of $1,000,000.Â  American of Texas, the franchisor of American of Charleston, 
  maintained an additional commercial policy with National, which had essentially 
  the same commercial general liability coverage, commercial auto coverage, and 
  commercial inland marine coverage as the policy issued by National to American 
  of Charleston.Â  This policy also contained limits of $1,000,000.Â Â Â  
State Farm, the Respondent, 
  issued an automobile insurance liability policy to the decedent, Goldston, which 
  contained underinsured motorist coverage in the amount of $50,000 per person.Â  
  State Farm consented to the settlement agreement described above, which ended 
  both the wrongful death and survival claims against all defendants, while agreeing 
  to preserve Appellantâ€™s claim to the underinsured motorist benefits under the 
  State Farm policy.Â  State Farm also stipulated that the damages recoverable 
  in the actions brought by Appellant exceeded $150,000.Â  
Appellant commenced this declaratory judgment 
  action by filing a complaint seeking to determine whether State Farm was under 
  an obligation to pay the underinsured motorist benefits contained in the policy 
  issued to the decedent.Â  By agreement of the parties, the matter was referred 
  to a special referee.Â  After two hearings, the special referee issued an order 
  dismissing the action. 
The refereeâ€™s order states the issue to be 
  decided was whether the commercial auto coverage or the commercial general liability 
  coverage under the National policies issued to American of Charleston and American 
  of Texas constitute â€œâ€˜applicable bodily injury liability and property damage 
  liability insurance policies or bonds that apply to the bodily injury suffered 
  by [the decedent].â€™â€Â Â  
The significance of this question lies in 
  the fact that if the policies constituted liability policies applicable to the 
  decedent, then by definition, the vehicle driven by Johnson could not be underinsured 
  because these policies would provide coverage in excess of the $150,000 in damages 
  stipulated to by the parties.Â  Therefore, Appellant would not be entitled to 
  collect the $50,000 in underinsured benefits provided for in State Farmâ€™s policy. 

The special referee proceeded to make several 
  conclusions of law, all of which Appellant argues were in error.Â  First, the 
  referee determined that the status of the at-fault vehicle, for purposes of 
  the insurance policies issued by National to American of Charleston and American 
  of Texas, was that of a â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicle or, in the alternative, a â€œhired 
  auto.â€Â  By making this determination, the referee concluded that the commercial 
  auto coverage, as defined in the garage coverage form under the policies issued 
  by National, provided applicable coverage to satisfy Appellantâ€™s claims.
The second conclusion of law asserted that, 
  regardless of how the court characterized the at-fault vehicle under the National 
  policies, coverage existed to pay Appellantâ€™s claims because at the time of 
  the accident the vehicle was being used for garage operations.Â  Thus, the special 
  referee concluded the vehicle, and by necessity the accident, were covered under 
  the commercial auto coverage section of the National policies.Â  In fact, the 
  referee went on to state that because the â€œclear and unambiguous language of 
  the policy provides coverage for garage operations,â€ and because the driver 
  of the truck was performing garage operations at the time of the accident, clearly 
  the National policies provided coverage.Â  
The special refereeâ€™s third conclusion of 
  law was that coverage was also available for Appellantâ€™s claims under the commercial 
  general liability coverage section of the National policies.Â  Specifically, 
  after interpreting the pertinent provisions of the policies, the referee held 
  that because there were no applicable exclusions placing the acts of the at-fault 
  driver outside the policy, coverage was available under the commercial general 
  liability coverage section of the policy. 
Appellantâ€™s motion for reconsideration of 
  the refereeâ€™s rulings was denied.
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I. 
         
  Did the referee err in excluding certain facts from his order of dismissal contained 
  in the partiesâ€™ stipulation of facts and relevant to the issues being ruled 
  upon?
      
      
         II.
         
  Did the referee err by concluding that the truck operated by Johnson at the 
  time of the accident was a â€œnon-owned autoâ€ or, in the alternative, a â€œhired 
  autoâ€ for purposes of the commercial auto coverage section of the insurance 
  policies issued by National to American of Charleston and American of Texas?
      
      
         III.
         
  Did the referee err in concluding that the commercial auto coverage section 
  of the insurance policies issued to American of Charleston and American of Texas 
  provided liability insurance to pay the claims of Appellant because Johnson 
  was involved in garage operations at the time of the accident?
      
      
         IV. 
         
  Did the referee err in concluding that the commercial general liability coverage 
  section of the policies issued to American of Charleston and American of Texas 
  provided coverage to pay the claims of Appellant?
      
      
         V. 
         
  Did the referee err in failing to conclude that there was a gap in coverage 
  between the at-fault vehicle and the policies issued to American of Charleston 
  and American of Texas?
      
      
         VI.
         
  Assuming coverage existed under the policies issued by National to American 
  of Charleston and American of Texas, did the referee err nevertheless in failing 
  to conclude that these policies should not be taken into consideration when 
  determining whether the vehicle was underinsured for purposes of receiving underinsured 
  motorist benefits?
      
    
  

 STANDARD OF REVIEW
Because declaratory judgment 
  actions are neither legal nor equitable, the standard of review depends on the 
  nature of the underlying issues.Â  Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 
  354 S.C. 274, 279, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).Â  
  When the purpose of the underlying dispute is to determine if coverage exists 
  under an insurance policy, the action is one at law.Â  Horry County v. Ins. 
  Reserve Fund, 344 S.C. 493, 497, 544 S.E.2d 637, 639-640 (Ct. App. 2001) 
  (citing State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Calcutt, 340 S.C. 231, 530 
  S.E.2d 896 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the 
  appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they 
  are found to be without evidence that reasonably supports those findings.Â  Townes 
  Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 
  (1976).Â  However, â€œâ€˜[w]hen an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, 
  an appellate court is free to review whether the trial court properly applied 
  the law to those facts.â€™â€Â  In re Estate of Boynton, 355 S.C. 299, 301, 
  584 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting WDW Props. v. City of Sumter, 
  342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000)).Â  In such a situation, the appellate 
  court does not have to defer to the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  Id. at 301-02, 
  584 S.E.2d at 155 (citations omitted).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

  I.                  
  Stipulation of Facts

Appellant argues the special referee erred 
  in selecting facts from the stipulation of facts submitted by the parties because 
  his order dismissing the case did not contain facts Appellant feels were pertinent 
  to the issue under consideration.Â  We disagree.
Although the referee premised the original 
  order dismissing the case by noting the parties â€œentered into the following 
  Stipulations of Facts,â€ this assertion was corrected in the refereeâ€™s order 
  ruling on Appellantâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  In the later order, the referee 
  corrected his previous assertion by noting that the facts in the original order 
  were taken from the partiesâ€™ stipulation of facts.Â  The referee stated that 
  the original order should have begun with the assertion that â€œ[t]he parties 
  entered into a Stipulation of Facts prior to the hearing in the above-captioned 
  action and this Court deemed the following facts salient to its decision.â€Â  

Thus, because the referee corrected any 
  possible error in his order on Appellantâ€™s motion for reconsideration, we find 
  this argument to be without merit.

  II.               
  Status of the At-Fault Vehicle

Appellant argues the referee erred in 
  his determination that the at-fault vehicle was either a â€œnon-owned autoâ€ or 
  a â€œhired autoâ€ under the commercial auto coverage section of the insurance policies.Â  
  We agree.Â  
The commercial auto coverage sections 
  in the National policies issued to American of Charleston and American of Texas 
  provide, in pertinent part, that the policies supply liability coverage in the 
  amount of $1,000,000.Â  The policies explain that the coverage will only apply 
  to â€œthose â€˜autosâ€™ shown as covered â€˜autosâ€™.Â  â€˜Autosâ€™ are shown as covered â€˜autosâ€™ 
  by the entry of one or more of the symbols from the COVERED AUTOS Section of 
  the Garage Coverage Form next to the name of the coverage.â€Â  Beside the coverage 
  section titled liability in the American of Charleston and American of Texas 
  policies appear the symbols 28 and 29.Â  
The definitions for symbols 28 and 29 
  are located in Section I of the garage coverage form contained in the commercial 
  auto coverage section of the policies.Â  Section I begins with a disclaimer which 
  provides, in pertinent part, that â€œ[t]he symbols entered next to a coverage 
  on the Declarations designate the only â€˜autosâ€™ that are covered â€˜autosâ€™.â€Â  Following 
  this disclaimer, section I goes on to define the available symbols, including 
  28 and 29.Â  The following definition is located next to symbol 28: â€œHIRED â€˜AUTOSâ€™ 
  ONLY.Â  Only those â€˜autosâ€™ you lease, hire, rent or borrow.Â  This does not include 
  any â€˜autoâ€™ you lease, hire, rent or borrow from any of your employees or partners 
  or members of their households.â€Â  The definition next to symbol 29 provides: 
  â€œNON-OWNED â€˜AUTOSâ€™ USED IN YOUR GARAGE BUSINESS.Â  Any â€˜autoâ€™ you do not own, 
  lease, hire, rent or borrow used in connection with your garage business described 
  in the Declarations.Â  This includes â€˜autosâ€™ owned by your employees or partners 
  or members of their households while used in your garage business.â€Â  
Before making the determination that the 
  at-fault vehicle was either a hired auto or non-owned auto, the special referee 
  stated that while â€œ[a]t first blush, one could believe that this Courtâ€™s job 
  was to determine the legal owner of the vehicle driven by Rickie Johnson in 
  order to determine coverage.Â  That is not the case.Â  The Court must determine 
  for purposes of the insurance policies what the status is of the vehicle driven 
  by Rickie Johnson.â€Â  We disagree with this statement.Â  We believe that legal 
  ownership is exactly what this court must determine before we can rule on whether 
  the vehicle was a covered auto.
As clearly stated in the policy language 
  in the excerpt above, the only autos covered under the policy are those falling 
  within the purview of symbols 28 and 29.Â  Symbol 28 refers to hired autos as 
  autos â€œyou lease, hire, rent or borrow.â€Â  Similarly, symbol 29 encompasses only 
  those autos that are not owned.Â  Therefore, to determine whether coverage exists, 
  this court must examine the ownership status of the at-fault vehicle.
 â€œThough a certificate of title constitutes 
  prima facie evidence of ownership for purposes of insurance coverage, this presumption 
  can be rebutted by evidence establishing someone other than the titleholder 
  is the true holder.â€Â  Pennell v. Foster, 388 S.C. 9, 15, 524 S.E.2d 630, 
  633 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Tollison v. Reaves, 277 S.C. 443, 445, 289 
  S.E.2d 163, 164 (1982)).Â  Although in this case, the at-fault vehicle was titled 
  and insured under the name of S.C. Auto Sales & Recovery, the evidence clearly 
  established that American of Charleston was its true owner.Â  American of Charleston 
  paid the purchase price of the truck, as well as all insurance, taxes, gas, 
  and required maintenance. Â Â Â Â  American of Charleston also maintained possession 
  of the truck and controlled the determination of how and when it would be utilized.Â  
  American of Charleston listed the truck as an asset on its financial statements 
  and claimed depreciation of the truck on the companyâ€™s tax returns.Â  Finally, 
  at the time of the incident, the truck was being utilized to repossess three 
  vehicles on behalf of American of Charleston.Â  
We find these additional facts adequate 
  to rebut the prima facie evidence of ownership established by the title alone.Â  
  Therefore, we hold that American of Charleston was the legal owner of the truck 
  at the time of the incident.Â  Accordingly, because American of Charleston owned 
  the truck at the time of the incident, it was neither a hired auto â€“ because 
  it was not leased, hired, rented, or borrowed â€“ nor a non-owned auto under the 
  policy issued by National to American of Charleston.Â  As such, we find the vehicle 
  was not a covered auto under the commercial auto coverage section of the policy.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â 

  III.           Commercial 
  auto coverage

The special referee held 
  that regardless of how the vehicle was characterized â€“ as either a hired auto, 
  non-owned auto, or owned auto â€“ coverage existed because the vehicle 
  was being used for garage operations at the time of the accident.Â  Appellant 
  argues this ruling was in error.Â  We affirm the special referee on alternate 
  grounds.
Insurance contracts are subject 
  to â€œthe general rules of contract construction.â€Â  Hansen ex rel. Hansen v. 
  United Auto. Assâ€™n, 350 S.C. 62, 68, 565 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (citing Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 
  301 S.C. 418, 421, 392 S.E.2d 460, 461 (1990)).Â  The primary purpose of all 
  rules of contract construction is to determine the intent of the parties.Â  Id. 
  (citation omitted).Â  â€œIf the contractâ€™s language is clear and unambiguous, the 
  language alone determines the contractâ€™s force and effect.â€Â  Schulmeyer v. 
  State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003) 
  (citation omitted).Â  
 â€œâ€˜[A] contract is ambiguous only when 
  it may fairly and reasonably be understood in more ways than one.â€™â€Â  Hansen, 
  350 S.C. at 68, 565 S.E.2d at 117 (quoting Universal Underwriters Ins. Co. 
  v. Metro. Prop. & Life Ins. Co., 298 S.C. 404, 407, 380 S.E.2d 858, 
  860 (Ct. App. 1989)).Â  â€œWhere language used in an insurance contract is ambiguous, 
  or where it is capable of two reasonable interpretations, that construction 
  which is most favorable to the insured will be adopted.â€Â  Id. (quoting 
  Poston v. Natâ€™l Fid. Life Ins. Co., 303 S.C. 182, 187, 399 S.E.2d 770, 
  772 (1990)).
The schedule of coverages and covered autos 
  contained in the commercial auto coverage section of the National policies provides:

This policy provides only those coverages where a charge 
  is shown in the premium column below.Â  Each of these coverages will apply 
  only to those â€˜autosâ€™ shown as covered â€˜autosâ€™. â€˜Autosâ€™ are shown as covered 
  â€˜autosâ€™ for a particular coverage by the entry of one or more of the symbols 
  from the COVERED AUTOS Section of the Garage Coverage Form next to the name 
  of the coverage.Â  Entry of a symbol next to LIABILITY provides coverage for 
  â€˜garage operationsâ€™.â€Â  

(emphasis added).
After considering this provision of the 
  policies, the special referee reasoned that because symbols 28 and 29 appear 
  beside the coverage titled liability, coverage also existed for garage operations.Â  
  Section VI of the garage coverage form contained in the commercial auto coverage 
  section of the policies defines garage operations as follows:

â€œGarage operationsâ€ means the ownership, maintenance or 
  use of locations for garage business and that portion of the roads or other 
  accesses that adjoin these locations.Â  â€œGarage operationsâ€ includes the ownership, 
  maintenance or use of the â€œautosâ€ indicated in SECTION I of this Coverage Form 
  as covered â€œautosâ€.Â  â€œGarage operationsâ€ also include all operations necessary 
  or incidental to a garage business.

(emphasis added).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The special referee considered the language 
  contained in this definition along with the appearance of symbols 28 and 29 
  on the declarations page, and stated that â€œthere can be no question but that 
  there is liability coverage for garage operations which includes all operations 
  necessary or incidental to a garage business.â€Â  The referee concluded that because 
  the at-fault driver was engaged in repossessions when the accident occurred, 
  he was performing tasks necessary and/or incidental to American of Charlestonâ€™s 
  garage business.Â  In fact, the referee stated, â€œThe clear and unambiguous language 
  of the policy provides coverage for garage operations.Â  [The at-fault driver] 
  was performing garage operations at the time [the decedent] was killed; thus, 
  coverage is provided by the [National] policies.â€Â  
To add support to this statement, 
  the referee examined Section II of the garage coverage form contained in the 
  commercial auto coverage section of the National policies, which explains the 
  liability coverage under that section.Â  First, the form defines who an insured 
  is for covered autos.Â  The form then defines who an insured is other than for 
  covered autos, stating, â€œâ€˜insuredsâ€™ for â€˜garage operationsâ€™ other than covered 
  â€˜autos,â€™â€ include American of Charleston or American of Texas and their 
  â€œpartners, employees, directors or shareholders but only while acting within 
  the scope of their duties.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Because the at-fault driver 
  was an employee of American of Charleston, the referee concluded that he was 
  an insured for purposes of the policy and that it did not matter whether the 
  at-fault vehicle was a covered auto or not.Â  
Finally, the referee examined the general 
  insuring agreement, which provided that National â€œwill pay all sums an â€˜insuredâ€™ 
  legally must pay as damages because of â€˜bodily injuryâ€™ or â€˜property damageâ€™ 
  to which this insurance applies, caused by an â€˜accidentâ€™ and resulting from 
  â€˜garage operations.â€™â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Taking all of the above excerpted 
  provisions together, the special referee concluded that coverage existed under 
  the commercial auto coverage section of the National policies because the at-fault 
  driver was an insured and because the decedentâ€™s injuries constituted bodily 
  injury, were caused by an accident, and resulted from garage operations.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We agree with the refereeâ€™s 
  conclusion that coverage existed under the commercial auto coverage section 
  of the National policies.Â  However, we disagree that the policy clearly and 
  unambiguously provided coverage under the facts of this particular case.Â  
As Appellant points out, the special refereeâ€™s 
  interpretation of the policy provisions at issue renders pointless the designation 
  of specific classes of autos included in the covered autos section of the policy.Â  
  American of Charleston chose to include only symbols 28 and 29 on the covered 
  autos section of the commercial auto coverage section of the National policies.Â  
  It had the option of choosing from among eleven possible auto designations, 
  but only chose two, indicating the covered autos under the commercial auto section 
  of the policies would include only hired autos and non-owned autos.Â  
The referee read the last sentence of 
  the garage operations definition together with the definition of insureds for 
  garage operations as preempting the designations of vehicles contained on the 
  garage coverage form in the commercial auto coverage section of the National 
  policies.Â  The last sentence of the garage operations definition states that 
  â€œâ€˜[g]arage operationsâ€™ also include all operations necessary or incidental to 
  garage business.â€Â  Further, the policy states that â€œâ€˜insuredsâ€™â€ for â€˜garage 
  operationsâ€™ other than covered â€˜autos,â€™â€ includes employees of American of Charleston 
  or American of Texas.Â  The special refereeâ€™s interpretation of these provisions 
  would have the policy providing coverage for any accident involving garage operations 
  no matter what designation of auto was involved.Â  Thus, even though American 
  of Charleston only chose to include hired autos and non-owned autos on the garage 
  coverage form, if an accident involving garage operations occurred with a vehicle 
  not falling within these designations, it would still be covered as garage operations 
  under the commercial auto section of the National policies.Â  
Because we find that the policy 
  language limiting coverage to non-owned and hired autos materially conflicts 
  with the policy language defining garage operations and insureds for garage 
  operations, we find that the policy provisions are open to more than one reasonable 
  interpretation.Â  Accordingly, we conclude that the policy provisions at issue 
  are ambiguous.Â  Hansen, 350 S.C. at 68, 565 S.E.2d at 117.Â  Therefore, 
  based on the premise that ambiguous or conflicting terms in an insurance contract 
  should be construed in favor of the insured and strictly against the insurer, 
  we affirm the special referee in finding the commercial auto liability coverage 
  section of the National policies provided coverage for Appellantâ€™s claims.Â  
  Diamond State Ins. Co. v. Homestead Indus., Inc., 318 S.C. 231, 236, 
  456 S.E.2d 912, 915 (1995).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

  IV.           Commercial 
  General Liability Coverage

The special referee ruled that coverage also 
  existed under the commercial general liability coverage section of the policies 
  issued by National to American of Charleston and American of Texas.Â  Appellant 
  maintains this ruling was in error.Â  We agree.
As noted in the discussion of the previous 
  issue, the general insurance agreement provides that National â€œwill pay all 
  sums an â€˜insuredâ€™ legally must pay as damages because of â€˜bodily injuryâ€™ or 
  â€˜property damageâ€™ to which this insurance applies.â€Â  An â€œinsured,â€ for purposes 
  of the commercial general liability coverage section of the National policies, 
  includes employees acting within the scope of their employment.Â  The referee 
  concluded Johnson was an insured under the commercial general liability coverage 
  section because he was engaged in the repossession of vehicles at the time of 
  the accident and thus, was acting within the scope of his employment.
The commercial general liability coverage 
  section contains an exclusion from coverage, however, which provides, in pertinent 
  part, that coverage does not apply to â€œâ€˜[b]odily injuryâ€™ or â€˜property damageâ€™ 
  arising out of the ownership, maintenance, use or entrustment to others of any 
  aircraft, â€˜autoâ€™ or watercraft owned or operated by or rented or loaned to any 
  insured.â€Â  
The referee found this exclusion did not 
  apply to American of Charleston because Appellant asserted multiple causes of 
  action in the underlying complaint that did not involve the use of an auto, 
  including a cause of action for negligent hiring and supervision.Â  The referee 
  further held that because the cause of action for negligent hiring and supervision 
  did not fall within the exclusion, coverage was provided under the policies.Â  
  On appeal, State Farm argues that Appellantâ€™s causes of action for negligent 
  hiring and supervision as well as negligence in failing to provide the financial 
  resources necessary to safely perform repossession, failing to maintain a proper 
  fleet of repossession equipment, requiring employees to undertake excessive 
  amounts of work, and requiring employees to mainly work at night fall outside 
  the auto exclusion in the commercial general liability coverage section.Â  We 
  disagree.Â  
In finding Appellantâ€™s causes of action did 
  not involve the use of an auto, both the refereeâ€™s order and State Farmâ€™s argument 
  on appeal fail to recognize the specific language contained in the auto exclusion.Â  
  The exclusion provides, â€œ[t]his insurance does not apply to . . . â€˜Bodily injuryâ€™ 
  or â€˜property damageâ€™ arising out of the ownership, maintenance, use or entrustment 
  of others of an . . . â€˜autoâ€™. . . .â€Â Â  The terms bodily injury and property 
  damage are both defined terms in the insurance contract.Â  Bodily injury is defined 
  as â€œbodily injury, sickness or disease sustained by a person, including death 
  resulting from any of these at any time.â€Â  Property damage is defined as â€œ(a)Â  
  [p]hysical injury to tangible property, including all resulting loss of uses 
  of that property; or (b) [l]oss of use of tangible property that is not physically 
  injured.â€Â  Neither of these definitions limits the application of the auto exclusion 
  only to causes of action that arise out of the use or entrustment of 
  an auto.Â  Rather, these definitions assure the parties that the auto exclusion 
  applies to all bodily injury and property damage arising out of the use or entrustment 
  of an auto.Â  See McPhearson v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 
  316, 320, 426 S.E.2d 770, 771 (1993) (â€œ[H]old[ing] that for the purpose of construing 
  an exclusionary clause in a general liability policy, â€˜arising out ofâ€™ should 
  be narrowly construed as â€˜caused by.â€™â€); MGC Mgmt. Of Charleston, Inc. v. 
  Kinghorn Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 549-50, 520 S.E.2d 820, 824 (Ct. App. 
  1999) (stating that an automobile exclusion applied to the occurrence itself 
  and not the type of damages, and because the death arose from use of a car, 
  the policy excluded damages emanating from the death). In this case, regardless 
  of what specific cause of action Appellant asserted in the complaint, Appellant 
  was seeking to recover damages for bodily injury.Â  Furthermore, Appellant was 
  seeking damages for bodily injury arising out of the use or entrustment of an 
  auto because decedentâ€™s injuries resulted from being struck by an auto driven 
  by an employee of American of Charleston.Â  As a result, we find no applicable 
  coverage under the commercial general liability coverage section of the National 
  policies because the auto exclusion specifically excluded coverage for decedentâ€™s 
  injuries.Â  

  V.               
  Gap in Coverage

Appellant asserts the special referee erred 
  in failing to conclude that the at-fault vehicle was not an underinsured vehicle 
  even if liability coverage existed under the National policies.Â  This argument 
  is premised on the idea that coverage under the National policies, if any, constituted 
  excess coverage because it was above and beyond the coverage required under 
  the South Carolina Motor Vehicle Financial Responsibility Act. [1] Â  As such, Appellant asserts there was a gap in coverage due 
  to the deductible contained in the National policies and that the State Farm 
  underinsured motorist benefits should apply to cover that gap.Â  The referee 
  declined to find such a gap in coverage.Â  We agree.
As State Farm correctly points out, the only 
  deductible contained in the National policies is a $25,000 per claim deductible 
  on bodily injury and property damage under the commercial general liability 
  coverage section of the policies.Â  Because we have previously determined that 
  coverage does not exist to cover Appellantâ€™s claims under the commercial general 
  liability coverage section, this deductible would be inapplicable.
Furthermore, even though we previously concluded 
  that coverage existed under the commercial auto section of the policies, that 
  section of the policies is not subject to a deductible.Â  As a result, we find 
  that the referee did not err in declining to find a gap in coverage.

  VI.           Consideration 
  of Other Policies

Appellant asserts that, even assuming coverage 
  existed under the National policies, the referee erred in failing to conclude 
  that these policies should not be taken into consideration when determining 
  whether the vehicle was underinsured for the purpose of receiving underinsured 
  motorist benefits.Â  Appellant argues that under the compulsory system of automobile 
  liability insurance established by the South Carolina Motor Vehicle Financial 
  Responsibility Act, only â€œmotor vehicle liability polic[ies],â€ as defined by 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-9-20(5) (Supp. 2003) 
  [2]  should be taken into consideration when determining whether an insured 
  is entitled to underinsured motorist benefits.Â Â  We disagree.
Section 56-9-20(5) of the South Carolina 
  Code (Supp. 2003) defines a motor vehicle liability policy, in relevant part, 
  as:

An ownerâ€™s or an operatorâ€™s policy of liability insurance 
  that fulfills all the requirements of Â§Â§ 38-77-140 through 38-77-230, certified 
  as provided in Â§ 56-9-550 or 56-9-560 as proof of financial responsibility and 
  issued, except as otherwise provided in Â§ 56-9-560, by an insurance carrier 
  duly authorized to transact business in this State, to or for the benefit of 
  the person or persons named therein as insured, and any other person, as insured, 
  using the vehicle described therein with the express or implied permission of 
  the named insured and subject to the following conditions . . . .

Appellant asserts that the National policies 
  at issue in this case did not constitute motor vehicle liability policies, even 
  if they do provide coverage for decedentâ€™s injuries, because the policies did 
  not provide vehicle specific coverage as required by the definition of a motor 
  vehicle liability policy.
In support of this argument, Appellant asks 
  this court to read the definition of â€œinsured motor vehicle,â€ found in the Financial 
  Responsibility Act, together with the definition of â€œunderinsured motor vehicle,â€ 
  found in the automobile insurance chapter 
  [3]  of the code, to find that the only relevant insurance policies, for 
  purposes of underinsured motorist coverage, are motor vehicle liability policies.
Section 56-9-20(1) of the South Carolina 
  Code (Supp. 2003) defines an insured motor vehicle as follows:

A motor vehicle as to which there is bodily injury 
  liability insurance and property damage liability insurance, meeting all of 
  the requirements of item (7) [4]  
  of this section, or as to which a bond has been given or cash or securities 
  delivered in lieu of such insurance or as to which the owner has qualified as 
  a self-insurer in accordance with the provisions of Â§ 56-9-60 . . . .

Section 38-77-30 (15) of the South Carolina 
  Code (2002 and Supp. 2003) defines an underinsured motor vehicle as:

[A] motor vehicle as to which there is bodily injury 
  liability insurance or a bond applicable at the time of the accident in an amount 
  of at least that specified in Section 38-77-140 and the amount of the insurance 
  or bond is less than the amount of the insuredsâ€™ damages.

We decline to limit the definition of underinsured 
  motor vehicle to those with vehicle specific liability insurance.Â  Courts must 
  take a statute as it is drafted and give effect to the legislative intent as 
  expressed in its language.Â  See State v. White, 338 S.C. 56, 58, 
  525 S.E.2d 261, 263 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  A subtle or forced construction of words 
  in a statute for the purpose of expanding the operation of a statute is prohibited.Â  
  See Moon v. City of Greer, 348 S.C. 184, 188, 558 S.E.2d 527, 
  530 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he lawmaking bodyâ€™s construction of 
  its language by means of definitions of the terms employed should be followed 
  in the interpretation of the act or section to which it relates and is intended 
  to apply.â€Â  Fruehauf Trailer Co., v. South Carolina Electric & Gas Co., 
  223 S.C. 320, 325, 75 S.E.2d 688, 690 (1953).Â Â  
Notably, the definition of an underinsured 
  motor vehicle does not contain the requirement that the applicable insurance 
  meet all the elements of a motor vehicle liability policy as the definition 
  of an insured motor vehicle does.Â  Rather, an underinsured motor vehicle is 
  defined as one to which there is bodily injury liability insurance [5]  at the time of the accident and the amount 
  of the insurance is less than the amount of the insuredâ€™s damages.Â  In this 
  case, there was bodily injury liability insurance at the time of the accident 
  from both the South Carolina Insurance Company policy and, as discussed above, 
  the commercial auto coverage section of the National policies.
Furthermore, the State Farm underinsured motorist coverage 
  contained the following provision:Â  â€œThere is no coverage until the limits of 
  liability of all applicable bodily injury liability and property damage liability 
  insurance policies or bonds that apply to the bodily injury or property damage 
  have been used up by payment of judgments or settlements.â€Â Â  An endorsement 
  to the State Farm policy contains a definition of an underinsured motor vehicle 
  almost identical to the definition of an underinsured motor vehicle contained 
  in section 38-77-30 (14).Â  The endorsement states that â€œa motor vehicle, as 
  to which there is bodily injury liability insurance or bond applicable at the 
  time of the accident in an amount of at least that specified in the Financial 
  Responsibility Act and the amount of insurance or bond is less than the 
  amount of the insuredâ€™s damages.â€Â  Because the National policies are applicable 
  bodily injury liability policies, we find the provision in the State Farm policy 
  excluding underinsured motorist coverage until the limits of liability of all 
  applicable bodily injury liability policies have been exhausted is effective 
  to bar Appellantâ€™s claim for underinsured motorist coverage under the State 
  Farm policy.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we 
  agree with the Appellant that the special referee erred in concluding the truck 
  operated by Johnson at the time of the accident was a non-owned or hired auto.Â  
  We further agree with Appellant that the referee erred in concluding that the 
  commercial general liability coverage section of the National policies provided 
  coverage for Appellantâ€™s claims.Â  However, because we find that coverage existed 
  under the commercial auto coverage section of the policies, that no gap in coverage 
  existed, and that the National polices should be considered in determining whether 
  the vehicle was underinsured for purposes of receiving underinsured motorist 
  benefits, we affirm the special refereeâ€™s decision to dismiss the action, as 
  modified by this opinion.
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.            
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

 
   
    [1]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 56-9-10Â  to -630 (1991 and Supp. 2003).

 
   [2]  This code section appears as Â§ 56-9-20(7) in the 
    1991 Code. 

 
   
    [3]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 38-77-10 to -1160 (2002 and Supp. 2003).Â  

 
   
    [4]  Presumably, the South Carolina General Assembly intended to amend 
    this section reference to read â€œitem (5)â€.Â  In the 1991 Code, item 7 defines 
    motor vehicle liability policy.Â  However, in the 2003 Supplement, item 5 defines 
    motor vehicle liability policy, while item 7 defines nonresident operating 
    privilege.Â  

 
   [5]  There is no statutory definition for bodily injury 
    liability insurance.
