THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Estalita Martin, on behalf of herself and all other similarly situated 
        individuals, Appellant,
v.
Companion HealthCare Corp., and Healthcare Recoveries, Inc., a Delaware 
        Corporation, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3750
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  1, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George H. McMaster, for Appellant.
Carolyn Courville, of Houston, James Theodore Gentry, W. Howard 
  Boyd, Jr., Jennifer E. Johnson, and Ronald K. Wray, II, all of Greenville, for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  


HEARN, C.J.: Estalita Martin sued both her 
  health maintenance organization, Companion HealthCare, and Healthcare Recoveries, 
  Inc., alleging, among other things, that the amount they collected from her 
  in an exercise of Companionâ€™s subrogation right exceeded the cost of her medical 
  bills.Â  The trial court granted the defendantsâ€™ motions for summary judgment, 
  finding Martinâ€™s action was barred by the statute of limitations and the doctrine 
  of voluntary payment.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Companion is a licensed health maintenance organization 
  that arranges for the provision of health care to its members by entering into 
  contracts with health care providers located throughout South Carolina.Â  Pursuant 
  to these arrangements, Companion compensates physicians, hospitals, clinics, 
  and other entities for health care provided to Companionâ€™s members. 
Appellant, Estalita Martin, was a member of Companion 
  when, on January 13, 1993, she was injured while riding a motorcycle.Â  Martin 
  brought suit against the other party to the accident.Â  The contract between 
  Companion and Martin gave Companion a subrogation right for amounts it paid 
  to health care providers on Martinâ€™s behalf for which she obtained compensation 
  from the at-fault driver in the motorcycle wreck litigation.Â  By letter dated 
  June 4, 1993, Martinâ€™s attorney assured Companion that he would â€œprotect [Companionâ€™s] 
  right of subrogation upon the settlement of the above matter and upon notification 
  from [his] client that these terms are acceptable.â€Â  
Through 1995, Companion paid total claims related 
  to Martinâ€™s accident in the amount of $13,721.45.Â  After Martin settled her 
  lawsuit against the at-fault driver, Companion instructed Healthcare Recoveries 
  to pursue a subrogation claim against Martin in the amount of $13,415.45. 
  [1] 
Acting on behalf of Companion, Healthcare Recoveries 
  executed a release of Companionâ€™s subrogation right, dated August 4, 1995.Â  
  In consideration for this release, Martin paid $13,415.45 to Healthcare Recoveries 
  on August 8, 1995.Â  
Martin initiated this lawsuit against Companion and 
  Healthcare Recoveries more than four years later, in December 1999.Â  Although 
  the complaint asserts twelve different causes of action, the gravamen of Martinâ€™s 
  claims is that Companion could not legally assert its contractual right to subrogation, 
  [2]  or in the alternative, that Companion was not entitled to the amount 
  it recovered in subrogation.
Throughout the discovery process, Martin demanded access 
  to Companionâ€™s â€œprovider contracts,â€ which Martin asserts would determine how 
  much Companion paid providers for Martinâ€™s medical expenses.Â  Companion failed 
  to respond to the request.
Companion and Healthcare Recoveries filed motions to 
  dismiss, which the trial court partially converted to motions for summary judgment.Â  
  The court granted the motions, and Martin appeals.
ISSUES

  
    
      
         1. 
         Did the trial court err in converting the defendantsâ€™ 
  motions to dismiss into motions for summary judgment?
      
      
         2.  
         Did the trial court err in granting summary judgment 
  when Companionâ€™s provider contracts were not produced during discovery?
      
      
         3. 
         Are Martinâ€™s claims barred by the Statute of Limitations?
      
      
         4. 
         Are Martinâ€™s claims barred by the â€œvoluntary paymentâ€ 
  doctrine?
      
    
  

 LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Propriety of the Motions for Summary 
  JudgmentÂ Â Â Â            

Martin first argues the trial court erred when 
  it converted the defendantsâ€™ motions to dismiss into motions for summary judgment.Â  
  We disagree.
In support of their motions to dismiss 
  based on the statute of limitations and the voluntary payment doctrine, Companion 
  and Healthcare Recoveries submitted affidavits from Rebecca Haberman, the claims 
  examiner who received the check from Martin in exchange for the release of subrogation 
  rights, and David Pankau, the senior vice-president of Companion who detailed 
  the amounts Companion paid on Martinâ€™s behalf. Martin filed a memorandum in 
  opposition to the defendantsâ€™ motions and provided affidavits from Timothy Schmidt, 
  an auditor for health benefits plans, and from Martin herself.
When a court is considering a motion to 
  dismiss and matters outside the pleadings are presented to and not excluded 
  by the court, â€œthe motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed 
  of as provided in Rule 56, and all parties shall be given reasonable opportunity 
  to present all material made pertinent to such a motion by Rule 56.â€Â  Rule 12(b), 
  SCRCP.Â  See also Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 511 
  S.E.2d 69, 73 (1999) (stating that conversion of a motion to dismiss into a 
  motion for summary judgment is proper when the parties are afforded a reasonable 
  opportunity to respond to such matters).Â  
With respect to Companionâ€™s and Healthcare 
  Recoveriesâ€™ motions to dismiss based upon the statute of limitations and voluntary 
  payment defenses, the trial court considered matters submitted by the parties 
  outside the pleadings.Â Â  Importantly, Martin had notice that matters outside 
  the pleadings would be considered because she was served with the affidavits 
  two months prior to the motion hearing and was afforded the opportunity to respond.Â  
  Indeed, Martin took advantage of this opportunity by submitting affidavits of 
  her own to the trial court along with her memorandum opposing the defendantsâ€™ 
  motions.Â  Thus, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s conversion of the defendantsâ€™ 
  motions to dismiss into motions for summary judgment.

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Summary Judgment

Martin next argues the trial court should not have granted 
  summary judgment to Companion and Healthcare Recoveries without first permitting 
  her to conduct discovery relating to alleged contracts in which the medical 
  providers who treated Martin may have given Companion year-end rebates.Â  We 
  disagree.
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate only if there is no genuine 
  issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter 
  of law.â€Â  Cunningham ex. rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 
  485, 491, 575 S.E.2d 549, 552 (2003).Â  When considering a motion for summary 
  judgment, the court views the evidence and all inferences that can be reasonably 
  drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id.
In this case, the trial court found Companion and Healthcare 
  Recoveries were entitled to summary judgment because Martinâ€™s claims were barred 
  by the three-year statute of limitations for causes of action for breach of 
  contract and fraud.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1)&(7) (Supp. 2003).Â  Because 
  we agree with this ruling, we find that Martinâ€™s inability to discover the provider 
  contracts is irrelevant.
According to the discovery rule, the three-year 
  statute of limitations found in section 15-3-350 begins to run when the underlying 
  cause of action reasonably ought to have been discovered.Â  Dean v. Ruscon 
  Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 363, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996).Â  Thus, the three-year 
  clock starts ticking on the â€œdate the injured party either knows or should have 
  known by the exercise of reasonable diligence that a cause of action arises 
  from the wrongful conduct.â€Â  Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t. of Transp., 344 S.C. 
  115, 123, 542 S.E.2d 736, 740 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This determination is objective, 
  rather than subjective.Â  Id.Â  As such, the question is not whether the 
  particular plaintiff in this case actually knew she had a claim.Â  Instead, we 
  approach this inquiry by deciding â€œwhether the circumstances of the case would 
  put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that some right of 
  his has been invaded, or that some claim against another party might exist.â€ 
  Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 719, 511 S.E.2d 413, 416Â  
  (Ct. App. 1999).
Here, Martin, through her attorney, received a release 
  of Companionâ€™s right to subrogation by paying $13,415.45 to Healthcare Recoveries 
  in August of 1995.Â  At this date, Martin unquestionably knew Companion was seeking 
  subrogation and knew the amount of money Companion was seeking.Â  She did not 
  commence the present case, however, until December of 1999, four years after 
  she had reimbursed Companion.Â  
Despite these uncontested facts, Martin 
  asserts the statute of limitations has not run because there is no evidence 
  that she knew or should have known at the time of payment that Companion and 
  Healthcare Recoveries may have been collecting more than the amount Companion 
  actually paid on her behalf.Â  Martin further argues she should be entitled to 
  review provider contracts between Companion and each of the health care providers 
  who treated her to determine whether the amount she paid Healthcare Recoveries 
  exceeded the amount Companion expended on her. 
Notably, during the four-year interim 
  between Martinâ€™s payment to Healthcare Recoveries and the filing of the instant 
  cause of action, Martin cannot point to any events, other than her original 
  payment of the claim and a meeting she had with attorneys, [3]  that caused her to â€œdiscoverâ€ 
  this claim.Â  In Dorman v. Campbell, 331 S.C. 179, 184, 500 S.E.2d 786, 
  789 (Ct. App. 1998), our court explained that the triggering of the statute 
  of limitations is â€œnot when advice of counsel is sought or a full-blown theory 
  of recovery developed,â€ but rather when the facts and circumstances of an injury 
  would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that a claim 
  exists.
We agree with the trial courtâ€™s finding that the very 
  latest Martin knew the facts and circumstances surrounding Companionâ€™s subrogation 
  lien was in August of 1995, when she paid $13,415.45 in exchange for a release 
  of Companionâ€™s subrogation rights.Â  Therefore, the statute of limitations began 
  to run at that time and expired in August of 1998.Â  Because the complaint in 
  this case was not filed until 1999, the trial court did not err in finding Martinâ€™s 
  claims were barred by the statute of limitations. 
  [4] 
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Healthcare Recoveries is in the business of pursuing subrogation 
    claims on behalf of health plans and other health care payers.Â  Healthcare 
    Recoveries does not provide health care services or insurance, or make payments 
    to health care providers.Â  Instead, Healthcare Recoveries merely relieves 
    health plans like Companion of the administrative burden of pursuing and recovering 
    subrogation payments due to them.Â  At all times relevant to this action, Healthcare 
    Recoveries was under contract to handle Companionâ€™s subrogation claims in 
    South Carolina.Â  In return for a fee, Healthcare Recoveries acted on Companionâ€™s 
    behalf to recover its subrogation amount from Martin. 

 
   
    [2]  The court found that health maintenance organizations are entitled 
    to subrogate under South Carolina law, and Martin does not appeal from this 
    ruling.Â  

 
   [3]  Martin is represented in this action by the same 
    law firm that represented her in the 1995 motorcycle accident litigation.

 
   [4]  Because the trial court properly found Martinâ€™s 
    action was barred by the statute of limitations, we need not address her other 
    arguments.

title: State v. Barnett
description: This case involves whether an indictment for grand larceny was sufficeint to confer subject matter jurisdiction, where the body of the indictment failed to allege the property's value was in excess of one thousand dollars.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John Barnett, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3751
Submitted June 9, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 HOWARD, J.:Â  John Barnett 
  was convicted of two counts of kidnapping, two counts of first-degree burglary, 
  and one count of grand larceny of a motor vehicle.Â  Subsequently, he was sentenced 
  to thirty years imprisonment for each of the kidnapping charges, forty years 
  imprisonment for each of the burglary charges, and five years imprisonment for 
  the grand larceny of a motor vehicle charge, all to run concurrently.Â  Barnett 
  appeals, arguing the indictment charging grand larceny of a motor vehicle was 
  insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction because the body of the indictment 
  failed to allege the motor vehicleâ€™s value was in excess of one thousand dollars.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
A grand jury indicted Barnett for 
  two counts of kidnapping, two counts of first-degree burglary, and one count 
  of grand larceny of a motor vehicle.Â  The indictment for grand larceny of a 
  motor vehicle was captioned â€œGRAND LARCENY OF MOTOR VEHICLE UNDER $5000 S.C. 
  Code:Â  16-13-30(B)(1),â€ and alleged: 

[t]hat John Barnett did in Richland County on or about March 
  10, 2000, feloniously take and carry away the personal property of Rosa 
  Daniels to wit:Â  1988 Pontiac 6000 with S.C. tag 542KJD, valued under $5000.00.Â  
  Against the peace and dignity of the State, and contrary to the statute in such 
  case made and provided. [1]   

(emphasis added).
Subsequently, Barnett was convicted on all the 
  charges and sentenced to thirty years imprisonment for each of the kidnapping 
  charges, forty years imprisonment for each of the burglary charges, and five 
  years imprisonment for the grand larceny of a motor vehicle charge, all to run 
  concurrently.Â Â Â Â Â  Barnett appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Barnett argues the indictment for grand 
  larceny of a motor vehicle was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction 
  because the body of the indictment did not allege the stolen vehicle was valued 
  at more than one thousand dollars.Â  We disagree.
In evaluating the sufficiency of an indictment, 
  this Court should â€œlook at the issue with a practical eye in view of the surrounding 
  circumstances.â€Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 78 
  (1993); see also State v. Thompson, 305 S.C. 496, 504 n. 1, 409 
  S.E.2d 420, 425 n. 1 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding when evaluating an indictment, 
  this Court should give â€œa common sense reading [to] the indictment as a wholeâ€).Â  
  If the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable 
  the trial court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know 
  what he is called upon to answer, the indictment is sufficient to confer subject 
  matter jurisdiction.Â  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 362, 495 S.E.2d 
  773, 777 (1998). â€œThe true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether 
  it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary 
  elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the 
  defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  Browning v. State, 320 
  S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995) (citations omitted).Â Â  â€œAn indictment 
  passes legal muster if it â€˜charges the crime substantially in the language of 
  the . . . statute prohibiting the crime or so plainly that the nature of the 
  offense charged may be easily understood . . . .â€™â€Â  State v. Reddick, 
  348 S.C. 631, 635, 560 S.E.2d 441, 443 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 17-19-20 (1985)).
South Carolina Code Annotated section 
  16-13-30(B) (2003) defines grand larceny as â€œ[larceny] of goods, chattels, instruments, 
  or other personalty valued in excess of one thousand dollars . . . .â€Â  See 
  State v. Parker, 351 S.C. 567, 570, 571 S.E.2d 288, 289 (2002) (â€œ[G]rand 
  larceny is the felonious taking and carrying away of the goods of another, where 
  the value exceeds $1,000.â€).Â  Larceny is the taking and carrying away of the 
  goods of another without consent.Â Â  State v. Brown, 274 S.C. 48, 49, 
  260 S.E.2d 719, 720 (1979).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
It is clear the indictment sufficiently alleges 
  larceny, a misdemeanor, as it alleged Barnett feloniously took a motor vehicle 
  from Rosa Daniels against the peace and dignity of the State.Â  See Brown, 
  274 S.C. at 49, 260 S.E.2d at 720 (holding larceny is the taking and carrying 
  away of the goods of another without consent).Â  However, the remaining inquiry 
  is whether the indictment sufficiently alleges the motor vehicle was worth more 
  than one thousand dollars, elevating the charge to grand larceny.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30(B).
This case is analogous to State v. Wilkes, 
  353 S.C. 462, 578 S.E.2d 717 (2003).Â  In Wilkes, the defendant was convicted 
  of one count of resisting arrest and two counts of assault on a correctional 
  facility employee.Â  One of the indictments was captioned, â€œASSAULT ON CORRECTIONAL 
  FACILITY EMPLOYEE Â§ 16-3-630,â€ and the other indictment was captioned â€œASSAULT 
  ON CORRECTIONAL FACILITY EMPLOYEE.â€Â  Both indictments alleged the defendant 
  â€œdid in Chester County on or about April 24, 1999[,] assault . . . [an officer] 
  while she[/he] was attempting to process him after his arrest.â€Â  Neither of 
  the indictments, within their bodies, alleged the officers were correctional 
  facility employees.Â  
On appeal, this Court vacated the two indictments 
  for assault on a correctional facility employee, holding the indictments were 
  jurisdictionally defective because they failed to allege the officer was a correctional 
  facility employee.Â  This Court further held the captions of the indictments 
  could not cure the otherwise defective indictments.Â  Id. at 464, 578 
  S.E.2d at 718.
On grant of certiorari, our supreme court reversed, 
  holding the indictments were sufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction 
  to the circuit court because, reading the captions in conjunction with the body 
  of the indictment, the indictments â€œstated the offense with sufficient certainty 
  and particularity to enable the trial court to know what judgment to pronounce 
  and . . . [the defendant] to know what he was being called upon to answer.â€Â  
  Id. at 465, 578 S.E.2d at 719.Â  
In the present case, although the body of the indictment 
  fails to specifically state the motor vehicleâ€™s value was in excess of one thousand 
  dollars, the caption of the indictment states the charge is â€œGRAND LARCENYâ€ 
  and cites â€œS.C. Code:Â  16-13-30(B)(1).â€Â  We conclude this language, coupled 
  with the language in the body of the indictment, is sufficient to state the 
  offense of grand larceny with certainty and particularity such that the circuit 
  court knew what judgment to pronounce and Barnett knew what to defend against.Â  
  Thus, the indictment is not jurisdictionally defective.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the 
  circuit court is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J., concurs.
BEATTY, J., dissenting in a separate 
  opinion.
BEATTY, J.:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  Barnett 
  maintains the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction of the grand 
  larceny charge because he was not properly indicted on the charge.Â  Specifically, 
  he contends the language of the indictment could be construed to mean he faced 
  the misdemeanor charge of petit larceny rather than grand larceny, which is 
  a felony.Â  Put differently, Barnett alleges the indictment failed to include 
  an essential element of grand larceny â€“ that the value of the property stolen 
  was in excess of $1,000.Â  I agree.
In July 2000, a grand jury indicted 
  Barnett for two counts of kidnapping, two counts of first-degree burglary, and 
  grand larceny.Â  The caption of Barnettâ€™s indictment for grand larceny readÂ  
  â€œGRAND LARCENY OF MOTOR VEHICLE UNDER $5000â€ and referenced S.C. Code Section 
  16-13-30(B)(1).Â  The body of the indictment alleged:Â  

That John Barnett did in Richland County on or about May 10, 
  2000, feloniously take and carry away the personal property of Rosa Daniels, 
  to wit:Â  1988 Pontiac 6000 with S.C. tag 542KJD, valued under $5000.00.

Grand larceny involves stolen property valued in 
  excess of $1,000, whereas petit larceny applies to stolen property valued at 
  $1,000 or less.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30, et seq. (Supp. 2002); 
  State v. Parker, 351 S.C. 567, 570, 571 S.E.2d 288, 289 (2002).Â  â€œThe 
  monetary value of the goods taken is an element of the offense of grand larceny.â€Â Â  
  Parker, 351 S.C. at 571, 571 S.E.2d at 290; see also Johnson 
  v. State, 319 S.C. 62, 64, 459 S.E.2d 840, 841 (1995) (grand larceny involved 
  taking and carrying away of goods valued at $200 or more; value is element of 
  grand larceny offense); Â State v. Ates, 297 S.C. 316, 318, 377 S.E.2d 
  98, 99 n.1 (1989) (â€œIn a grand larceny prosecution, value is critical 
  element; it is the State's burden to prove value of stolen goods exceeds $200.â€) 
  (emphasis added). [2] Â  
The circuit court lacks jurisdiction to convict 
  a defendant of an offense unless the defendant waives presentment, the offense 
  is a lesser-included offense of the crime charged in the indictment, or there 
  is an indictment that sufficiently states the offense.Â  State v. Owens, 
  346 S.C. 637, 648, 552 S.E.2d 745, 751 (2001).Â  â€œAn indictment is sufficient 
  if it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense intended 
  to be charged and apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared 
  to meet.â€Â  Granger v. State, 333 S.C. 2, 4, 507 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1998) 
  (emphasis added).Â  The indictment sufficiency criteria must be viewed with a 
  â€œpractical eyeâ€; all the surrounding circumstances must be weighed before an 
  accurate determination of whether a defendant was or was not prejudiced can 
  be reached.Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1993). 
  This includes looking both at the face of the indictment and the circumstances 
  surrounding the trial.Â  See State v. Reddick, 348 S.C. 631, 636, 
  560 S.E.2d 441, 443 (Ct. App. 2002) (examining the indictment â€œon its faceâ€ 
  and considering the â€œevents at trialâ€ to determine whether the appellants were 
  on notice and apprised of the charges against them).
The caption of the indictment charged 
  Barnett with violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30(B)(1). The caption read 
  that Barnett was charged with â€œGRAND LARCENY OF MOTOR VEHICLE UNDER $5000.â€Â  
  However, the body of the indictment failed to make specific reference to the 
  code section applicable to grand larceny, and did not list the elements of the 
  offense. â€œ[O]ne cannot infer the elements of an offense from the caption of 
  the indictment.â€Â  State v. McCloud, 354 S.C. 40, 47, 579 S.E.2d 534, 
  537 (Ct. App. 2003) (Shuler, J., dissenting) (citing State v. Lark, 64 
  S.C. 350, 353, 42 S.E. 175, 176-77 (1902)); see also State v. Tabory, 
  262 S.C. 136, 141, 202 S.E.2d 852, 854 (1974) (â€œ[T]he State may not support 
  a conviction for an offense intended to be charged by relying upon a caption 
  to the exclusion of the language contained in the body of the indictment.â€).Â  

Our supreme court used the phrase â€œpractical eyeâ€ 
  to determine whether an indictment is legally sufficient.Â  See Gunn, 
  313 S.C. at 130, 437 S.E.2d at 78.Â  Courts are called to examine the totality 
  of the circumstances to determine whether a defendant was aware of the crime 
  for which he was charged.Â  Id.Â  â€œAll the surrounding circumstances must 
  be weighed before an accurate determination of whether a defendant was or was 
  not prejudiced can be reached.â€ [3] Â  Viewing the indictment with a practical eye, 
  I believe the indictment was insufficient to apprise Barnett of the elements 
  of the crime he should have been prepared to meet.Â  Nothing in the record indicates 
  that Barnett was granted a preliminary hearing, whereby he could discover the 
  crimes for which he was being tried.Â  See McCloud, 354 S.C. at 
  44, 579 S.E.2d at 536.Â Â  Although the record reflects that the trial court and 
  solicitor made several references to Barnettâ€™s charges, doing so during the 
  trial did not allot Barnett sufficient notice to prepare his defense.Â  
In State v. Wilkes, our supreme court reversed 
  this Courtâ€™s decision to vacate two indictments for assault on a correctional 
  facility employee.Â  353 S.C. 462, 578 S.E.2d 717 (2003).Â  The body of the indictments 
  used the word â€œofficerâ€ to describe the victim, instead of â€œcorrectional facility 
  employee.â€Â  Otherwise, the body of each indictment included the elements of 
  the offense, as well as the title and code section of the charges. [4] Â  Moreover, the language in the body of the 
  indictment was phrased substantially in the language of the statute defining 
  the offense. See State v. Shoemaker, 276 S.C. 86, 275 S.E.2d 878 
  (1981).
Unlike Wilkes, the body of the indictment 
  in this matter does not include all of the elements of the offense of grand 
  larceny, nor does it include the code section.Â  Moreover, in Wilkes, 
  the gist of the issue was one of semantics, not elements of the offense. The 
  question was whether, in the context of the indictment, â€œofficerâ€ and â€œcorrectional 
  facility employeeâ€ were synonymous as used in the statute. Wilkes, 535 
  S.C. at 464, 578 S.E.2d at 718. It was patently clear the words were synonymous.Â  

However, in the instant case there is no such clarity.Â  
  In actuality, the body of the indictment merely charges petit larceny.Â  The 
  caption of the indictment lists the code section where grand larceny of more 
  than $1000 and less than $5000 is set forth.Â  This caption may assist the judge 
  in determining the proper sentence; however, it does not provide the missing 
  element required in the body of the indictment for grand larceny.Â  See 
  Tabory, 262 S.C. at 140, 202 S.E.2d at 854. Therefore, Barnett was not 
  on proper notice of the crime charged: the offense of petit larceny as charged 
  in the body of the indictment or, grand larceny as stated in the caption.Â  An 
  indictment should not leave this question for criminal defendants to decipher; 
  the law requires indictments to clearly answer this question. 
Weighing the circumstances surrounding Barnettâ€™s 
  indictment and subsequent conviction, I believe Barnett was not sufficiently 
  apprised of the elements of the crime of grand larceny.Â  I believe the indictment 
  could have been construed to involve stolen property valued at less than $1,000, 
  making the crime petit larceny, a misdemeanor.Â  Therefore, Barnett was prejudiced 
  by the missing property value from the indictment. For the foregoing reasons, 
  I believe the conviction for grand larceny should be vacated.

 
   
    [1]  The indictment originally alleged Clanda James owned the motor vehicle.Â  
    However, the indictment was amended to name Rosa Daniels as the owner of the 
    motor vehicle.Â  The amendment of the name of the victim under these circumstances 
    is not a jurisdictional flaw.Â  See State v. Johnson, 314 S.C. 
    161, 166, 442 S.E.2d 191, 194 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding an amendment changing 
    the name of the owner of the property listed in an indictment for breach of 
    trust did not change the nature of the offense); State v. Sweat, 221 
    S.C. 270, 273-74, 70 S.E.2d 234, 235-36 (1952) (holding an amendment to a 
    larceny indictment did not change the nature of the offense, where the indictment 
    changed the name of the victim); see also State v. Guthrie, 
    352 S.C. 103, 111-12, 572 S.E.2d 309, 313-14 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding an element 
    is an essential ingredient of the crime when an amendment to that element 
    would materially change the proof required to convict the defendant of the 
    crime);Â  41 Am. Jur. 2d Indictments and Informations Â§ 168 (1995) (stating 
    an amendment is substantive and thus not permitted unless â€œthe same defense 
    is available to the defendant both before and after the amendment and upon 
    the same evidenceâ€).

 
   
    [2]  Previously, the value of goods for grand larceny was $200 or more.Â Â  
    See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30 (1985).Â Â  The statute has been amended 
    to set the value of goods for grand larceny at more than $1,000.Â  S.C. Code 
    Ann Â§ 16-13-30 (B)(1) (Supp. 2002).

 
   
    [3]  Reddick, 348 S.C at 633, 560 S.E.2d at 443 (citing State 
    v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 81, 276 S.E.2d 163, 167 (1981); State v. Shoemaker, 
    276 S.C. 86, 275 S.E.2d 878 (1981); State v. Evans, 216 S.C. 328, 57 
    S.E.2d 756 (1950)).

 
   
    [4]  Both indictments contained the titles of the charges in the body 
    that state the victim was a correctional facility employee.Â  Additionally, 
    both indictments cite S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-360, appropriately apprising the 
    defendant of the charges he would be called to meet. Wilkes, 353 S.C. 
    at 465, 578 S.E.2d at 719.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Anthony A. Heyward, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3752
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh,Â  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson,Â  
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor 
  Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  Anthony A. Heyward was 
  convicted for kidnapping, criminal sexual conduct in the first degree (â€œCSCâ€), 
  and carjacking.Â  Subsequently, the circuit court sentenced him to life imprisonment 
  without parole for kidnapping, life imprisonment without parole for CSC, and 
  fifteen years imprisonment for carjacking, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  
  Heyward appeals, arguing the circuit court erred by failing to start the jury 
  selection process de novo, where the circuit court found a juror to have been 
  struck in violation of Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).Â  We affirm.Â Â Â  

FACTUAL/PROECDURAL BACKGROUND
A grand jury indicted Heyward for kidnapping, 
  CSC, and carjacking.Â  During jury selection, the State moved for a Batson 
  hearing, arguing Heywardâ€™s strikes were exercised in a gender-based, discriminatory 
  manner.Â  The circuit court agreed.Â  However, rather than strike the entire jury 
  and begin the jury selection process de novo, the circuit court seated the juror.Â  

Following the trial, the jury found Heyward 
  guilty of kidnapping, CSC, and carjacking, and the circuit court sentenced him 
  to life imprisonment without parole for kidnapping, life imprisonment without 
  parole for CSC, and fifteen years imprisonment for carjacking, the sentences 
  to run concurrently.Â  
On appeal, Heywardâ€™s appellate counsel reviewed the record, 
  concluded the appeal lacked merit, and filed a petition to be relieved.Â  Pursuant 
  to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), this court reviewed the record and brief, 
  denied counselâ€™s request, and ordered the following issue to be briefed:

Did the trial court err in seating a juror, whom it found 
  to have been struck in violation of Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986), 
  rather than ordering the process of selecting the jury to start de novo as set 
  forth in State v. Jones, 293 S.C. 54, 58, 358 S.E.2d 701, 704 (1987), 
  abrogated on other grounds by State v. Chapman, 317 S.C. 302, 
  454 S.E.2d 317 (1995)?Â Â  

(S.C. Ct. App. Order dated June 11, 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Heyward argues the circuit court committed reversible 
  error by failing to strike the jury and start the jury selection process de 
  novo, where the circuit court found a juror to have been struck in violation 
  of Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).Â  We disagree.
â€œThe Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth 
  Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venireperson 
  on the basis of race.â€Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 628, 515 S.E.2d 
  88, 90 (1999); see Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79, 85 (1986) 
  (holding the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits 
  a state prosecutor from exercising peremptory challenges to strike potential 
  jurors solely on the basis of race); see also Georgia v. McCollum, 
  505 U.S. 42, 50-55 (1992) (holding a prosecutor may challenge a defendantâ€™s 
  use of peremptory strikes); J.E.B. v. Alabama ex rel. T.B., 511 U.S. 
  127, 129 (1994) (holding the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution 
  is violated if the State strikes a juror on the basis of gender).
Our supreme court has set forth a â€œbright line 
  testâ€ for determining if a juror has been struck in violation of Batson.Â  
  See State v. Jones, 293 S.C. 54, 57-58, 358 S.E.2d 701, 703-04 
  (1987), abrogated by, State v. Chapman, 317 S.C. 302, 306, 
  454 S.E.2d 317, 320 (1995)).Â  Furthermore, if the circuit court finds a juror 
  has been struck in violation of Batson, our supreme court has mandated 
  that the circuit court strike the entire jury and begin the jury selection process 
  de novo.Â  Id. at 58, 358 S.E.2d at 704.Â  This mandate seeks to:Â  1) protect 
  the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial; 2) protect each venirepersonâ€™s right 
  not to be excluded from jury service for discriminatory reasons; and 3) preserve 
  public confidence in the fairness of our system of justice by seeking to eradicate 
  discrimination in the jury selection process.Â  Haigler, 334 S.C. at 628-29, 
  515 S.E.2d at 90.
In this case, forty-one qualified jurors were randomly 
  drawn from the jury pool, and their names were placed on a consecutively numbered 
  list.Â  The remaining jurors in the pool were then excused from the courtroom.Â  
  Beginning with the first name on the list, the circuit court called out each 
  juror in order, giving first the State and then the defendant the right to strike 
  the juror.Â  The jurors did not know who was struck by either side.
Following jury selection, both parties made a Batson 
  challenge.Â  All of Heywardâ€™s strikes removed female jurors, and the State asserted 
  his strikes were exercised in a gender-based, discriminatory fashion.Â  Ultimately, 
  the circuit court concluded Heywardâ€™s reason for striking the sixteenth juror 
  on the list was pretextual, finding it to be a gender-based discriminatory strike.Â  
  However, rather than striking the entire jury, the circuit court seated the 
  juror.Â  
Having seated the sixteenth juror on the list as juror number 
  nine (â€œjuror number nineâ€™), the circuit court moved the last juror of the twelve-person 
  jury to the first alternate jurorâ€™s position, removing the last alternate juror 
  completely. [1] Â  The court then 
  revisited each of the three remaining jurors selected in the initial process 
  in their original order, noting that Heyward had the option of striking another 
  juror because the court had denied his strike of juror number nine.Â  Heyward 
  declined to strike any of the three remaining jurors included on the original 
  panel.Â  
Initially, we agree the circuit court erred by 
  seating the juror in violation of Jones. [2] Â  However, this does not end our inquiry.Â  Rather, 
  we must determine whether a harmless error analysis is appropriate, and if so, 
  whether the error in this case was harmless.
In State v. Franklin, 318 S.C. 47, 456 S.E.2d 
  357 (1995), the circuit court quashed a jury, finding the defendant struck a 
  juror in a discriminatory manner.Â  Subsequently, upon starting the jury selection 
  process de novo, the defendant attempted to strike the same juror again, and 
  the circuit court seated the juror.Â  Id. at 51, 456 S.E.2d at 359.Â  Our 
  supreme court affirmed, holding â€œâ€˜a partyâ€™s right to use peremptory challenges 
  can be subordinated to a venirepersonâ€™s constitutional right not to be improperly 
  removed from jury service.â€™â€Â  Id. at 52, 456 S.E.2d at 359-360 (quoting 
  Jefferson v. State, 595 So.2d 38, 41 (Fla. 1992)). 
  [3] 
Subsequently, in State v. Short, 333 S.C. 
  473, 511 S.E.2d 358 (1999), our supreme court, analyzing a Batson challenge, 
  ruled, â€œno showing of actual prejudice is required to find reversible error 
  for the denial or impairment of the right to a peremptory challenge.â€Â  
  Short, 333 S.C. at 477, 511 S.E.2d at 360.Â  (emphasis added).Â  
As we interpret Franklin, seating a juror 
  who has once been improperly struck by a party in violation of Batson 
  is not, in and of itself, an impairment or denial of that partyâ€™s right to peremptory 
  challenges.Â  Consequently, under the circumstance of this case, a harmless error 
  analysis is appropriate and does not offend State v. Short. 
Viewing the facts of this case, in light of the above, 
  we conclude no prejudice resulted from the failure to select a jury de novo, 
  as Heywardâ€™s right to exercise peremptory strikes was not impaired, and the 
  selection process provided Heyward with the same choices he enjoyed in the first 
  instance, with the exception of the unconstitutional strike of juror number 
  nine.Â  Thus, under the limited circumstances of this case, we hold the error 
  was harmless. State v. Wright, 304 S.C. 529, 534, 405 S.E.2d 825, 828 
  (1991) (ruling there is no prejudice to defendant where he received what Batson 
  was intended to provide); see also Franklin, 318 S.C. at 
  52, 456 S.E.2d at 360.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Heywardâ€™s conviction is 
  AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

 
   [1]  No alternates were needed in the trial.

 
    [2]  We note that in Jones, the solicitorâ€™s 
    juror strikes were the subject of challenge.Â  Jones 293 S.C. at 57, 
    358 S.E.2d at 703.Â  In pertinent part, the court stated that when â€œthe solicitor 
    has failed to give a racially neutral reason for the contested peremptory 
    strikes, the process of selecting the jury shall start de novo.â€Â  Id.Â  
    Thus, Jones did not deal with the situation in this case, in which 
    the party who improperly strikes a juror demands a de novo jury selection 
    as a result of his/her own impropriety.Â  However, absent further guidance 
    from our supreme court, we conclude Jones is controlling on the issue.Â Â  
  

 
   [3] 
    We recognize the facts in Franklin are dissimilar in that the seating 
    of the juror over defense objection occurred during the de novo selection 
    mandated by Jones.Â  In that regard, the Courtâ€™s ruling was limited 
    by those facts. See Franklin, 318 S.C. at 53, 456 S.E.2d at 
    360 (â€œWe hold once a new venire has been selected in compliance with Jones, 
    supra, â€˜that it is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion to fashion the appropriate 
    remedy under the particular facts of each case and, as long as neither partyâ€™s 
    constitutional rights are infringed, that remedy may include the seating of 
    an improperly challenged juror.â€™â€ (emphasis added) (quoting Jefferson, 
    595 So.2d at 47).Â  We also note the Court took pains not to undermine the 
    requirement of Jones. Id. (â€œOur decision today does not impact 
    Jones.â€).Â  However, the Court did recognize that Jones was not 
    intended to cover all situations. Id. (â€œJones did not consider 
    the case where a party attempts repeatedly to strike a prospective juror in 
    violation of Batson. We do not accept the argument that Jones 
    mandates . . . the trial judge in all instances to â€˜give the offending party 
    exactly what he wanted, namely,â€™ a jury panel which unconstitutionally excludes 
    a particular juror.â€) (quoting People v. Moten, 603 N.Y.S.2d 940, 947 
    (N.Y. App. Div. 1993)).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Deloitte & Touche, LLP, Appellant,
v.
Unisys Corporation, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  3753
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John E. Schmidt, III, Dwight F. Drake and C. Mitchell Brown, all of Columbia, for Appellant. 
James T. Hewitt, of Greenville, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.: Â Deloitte & Touche, L.L.P. appeals a circuit court order 
  denying its motion seeking arbitration.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In 1996, Deloitte commenced an action 
  against Unisys Corporation based on a contractual dispute. Unisys then gave 
  notice of and filed a demand for arbitration. Unisys also subsequently moved 
  to have the case dismissed under Rules 12(b)(1) and 12(b)(8), SCRCP. At the 
  time, Deloitte was opposed to arbitration and argued against Unisysâ€™s arbitration 
  demand.Â  The circuit court held that Deloitte could not be forced to arbitrate 
  its claims against Unisys, reasoning that the arbitration provision of the contract 
  under which Unisys made its request was unenforceable under South Carolina law 
  and incapable of being â€œrescuedâ€ by the Federal Arbitration Act. [1] Â  Unisys appealed the ruling, but the appeal 
  was dismissed as being interlocutory and premature. 
Following the dismissal of the appeal, 
  the parties resumed litigation. That process has lasted for nearly five and 
  one-half years.Â  The discovery phase has generated thousands of documents and 
  numerous motions and hearings. A three-day â€œPhase Iâ€ bench trial was conducted, 
  where Deloitte was allowed to present one of its claims. 
  [2]  The trial judge ruled in favor of Unisys. Deloitte then moved for arbitration 
  in August 2002, shortly before Unisys was to present its counter-claims in â€œPhase 
  IIâ€ of the trial. Deloitte asserted that it could â€œjoinâ€ Unisys in â€œvoluntary 
  arbitrationâ€ since Unisys had continued to maintain an open file with the American 
  Arbitration Association even after its demand for arbitration was denied. 
The trial judge denied Deloitteâ€™s motion 
  for arbitration on August 15, 2002. He found Deloitteâ€™s motion to be duplicative 
  of Unisysâ€™s 1997 motion to compel arbitration. The trial judge reasoned that 
  Deloitte, having successfully contested Unisysâ€™s motion nearly six years earlier, 
  could not now argue in favor of arbitration.Â  In the alternative, the trial 
  judge found that Deloitte waived its right to seek arbitration by litigating 
  the case for five and one-half years.Â  
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I.   
         
  Did the trial judge err in finding Deloitteâ€™s motion duplicative of Unisysâ€™s 
  1997 motion to compel arbitration?
      
      
         II. 
         Did the trial judge err in holding that Deloitte waived its right to seek arbitration 
  by engaging in the litigation process?
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
 â€œThe question of the arbitrability of 
  a claim is an issue for judicial determinationÂ  . . . [and is] subject to de 
  novo review.â€ Stokes v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 606, 609, 
  571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002) (citation omitted). However, the circuit 
  courtâ€™s factual findings underlying the ruling will be disturbed only if there 
  is no evidence to reasonably support them.Â  Liberty Builders, Inc. v. Horton, 
  336 S.C. 658, 664, 521 S.E.2d 749, 753 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Arbitration Motion   
Deloitte argues that the trial judge erred in finding its 
  motion duplicative of Unisysâ€™s 1997 motion to compel arbitration.Â  Specifically, 
  Deloitte contends that the 1997 order merely held that Unisys could not force 
  Deloitte into arbitration under the arbitration clause in the contract, not 
  that the parties could not voluntarily arbitrate their dispute.Â  Therefore, 
  according to Deloitte, the 1997 order has â€œno effect in an instance, such as 
  this, where the parties agree to arbitrate.â€Â  We disagree.
We note at the outset that if Unisys were willing 
  to arbitrate the dispute, this current appeal would not exist.Â  In fact, Unisys 
  stated in its brief that there has not been an â€œopen invitationâ€ to arbitrate 
  from Unisys since the 1997 order. Indeed, the trial judge found in his 2002 
  order that â€œ[t]he arbitration has been inactive and dormant for five and one-half 
  years, and the parties have not conducted any activity in that forum pursuant 
  to the ruling of [the circuit court] in 1997.â€Â  Deloitte maintains that parties 
  to a dispute reserve the right to choose arbitration even after the start of 
  litigation. And that may well be true. But such is not the case here. Unisys 
  wanted arbitration, but Deloitte opposed it. Unisys was forced to comply with 
  that wish following the circuit courtâ€™s 1997 ruling. That Unisys has â€œnever 
  withdrawn its demand for arbitrationâ€ is immaterial since the motion was denied. 
  Given that no arbitration is currently taking place between the parties, what 
  Deloitte is attempting to do here is to force Unisys into arbitration under 
  the contractual clause the circuit court found unenforceable in 1997. 
  [3]  We decline to do so. 
We find that the trial judge did not err in ruling that Deloitteâ€™s 
  motion was duplicative of Unisysâ€™s 1997 motion to compel arbitration.
II.Â  Waiver
Deloitte also argues that the trial judge erred 
  in finding that Deloitte waived its right to arbitrate.Â  Again, we disagree.
â€œIt is generally held that the right to enforce 
  an arbitration clause may be waived.â€ Liberty Builders, 336 S.C. at 665, 
  521 S.E.2d at 753 (citation omitted). â€œThere is no set rule as to what constitutes 
  a waiver of the right to arbitrate; the question depends on the facts of each 
  case." Id. To establish that there has been a waiver, a party must 
  show it has been unduly burdened by the other partyâ€™s delay in seeking arbitration.Â  
  Sentry Engâ€™g & Constr., Inc. v. Marinerâ€™s Cay Dev. Corp., 287 S.C. 
  346, 351, 338 S.E.2d 631, 634 (1985). 
The trial judge relied primarily on Liberty Builders 
  in concluding that Deloitte waived its right to seek arbitration. There, the 
  parties sought assistance from the trial court on numerous occasions, and submitted 
  several motions, including motions to amend, compel, add parties, and dismiss. 
  Liberty Builders, 336 S.C. at 666, 521 S.E.2d at 753. Those proceedings 
  lasted for more than two years. Id. The time and work necessary to resolve 
  these motions resulted in substantial attorneysâ€™ fees for the non-moving party.Â  
  This Court found that the non-moving party was prejudiced by the delay and that 
  the moving party had â€œwaived its right to enforce the arbitration clause by 
  submitting the dispute to the court and availing itself of that system for two 
  and one-half years.â€Â  Id. at 668, 521 S.E.2d at 754.
In the current case, Deloitte has availed itself of the litigation 
  process for approximately five and one-half years.Â  The parties have conducted 
  a significant amount of discovery, resulting in the production of thousands 
  of documents.Â  Significantly, Deloitte has also been permitted to try one of 
  its claims against Unisys.Â  Therefore, just like the non-moving party in Liberty 
  Builders, Unisys, the non-moving party here, has been prejudiced since it 
  was forced to start and maintain the litigation process. The trial judge was 
  correct in finding that Deloitte waived its right to seek arbitration.
Deloitte argues that Liberty Builders is not controlling 
  because that defendant had not repeatedly argued that the dispute should be 
  arbitrated; it was only the plaintiff that belatedly demanded arbitration.Â  
  We find this factual difference to be inconsequential.Â  Deloitte could have 
  submitted its case for arbitration when Unisys first sought arbitration in 1997.Â  
  In fact, Deloitte could have chosen arbitration at any time, but it did not.Â  
  Instead, after pursuing litigation for nearly six years, culminating in an unsuccessful 
  trial, Deloitte now wants to compel Unisys to arbitrate. That, it cannot do. 

 CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s rulings are
AFFIRMED.  
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur.Â Â  

 
   [1] The Federal Arbitration Act, 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1, et 
    seq.Â  (2003).

 
   
    [2] The trial judge had granted Deloitteâ€™s 2000 motion to bifurcate the 
    case. 

 
   [3] The trial judge was correct to explain that â€œone 
    circuit judge does not have the power to review, modify, affirm or reverse 
    the findings of another circuit judge.â€Â  State ex rel Medlock v. Love Shop, 
    Ltd., 286 S.C. 486, 488, 334 S.E.2d 528, 529 (Ct. App. 1985).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
LaRue D. Penny, Jr., Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Sally Z. Green, f/k/a Sally Z. Penny, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Rolly W. Jacobs, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3754
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
and REMANDED 


  
    
      
Michael R. Ellisor, of Lexington, for Appellant-Respondent.
Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland, N.C.; J. Mark Taylor 
  and C. Vance Stricklin, Jr., both of West Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  LaRue D. Penny, Jr. (Husband) 
  and Sally Z. Green (Wife) both appeal from a family court order reducing Husbandâ€™s 
  child support and alimony obligations.Â  Husband also appeals Wifeâ€™s award of 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Husband and Wife were divorced in February 1998.Â  
  The family court judge adopted the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement and ordered 
  Husband to pay $2,750 per month in alimony until May 2002, with incremental 
  decreases after that date.Â  Husband was also ordered to pay $1,500 per month 
  in child support until May 2002, with the amount decreasing to $1,000 per month 
  after that date.
In 1999, between the 
  divorce and the initiation of this action, Wife moved to Atlanta with the children.Â  
  In the fall of 2000, Husband left his Columbia pediatric practice and moved 
  to Atlanta, in part to be closer to his children.Â  Another factor in his relocation 
  was that Husband remarried and his current wifeâ€™s two children also live near 
  Atlanta. [1] Â  Husband filed this 
  action for a reduction in his support obligations, claiming his financial circumstances 
  had changed significantly.Â  Wife answered, denying Husband was entitled to a 
  decrease, and requested an increase in alimony, admonishment of Husband for 
  late support payments, enforcement of Husbandâ€™s debt payment obligations under 
  the divorce decree, and payment of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.
In the 1998 divorce 
  proceeding approving the partiesâ€™ agreement, Husbandâ€™s sworn financial declaration 
  stated his annual income wasÂ  $140,000.Â  In this action for a reduction, however, 
  Husband claimed his income at the time of the divorce was actually $165,226.Â  
  He testified that his new employment in Atlanta provided him with a minimum 
  salary of $100,000, based on a three-day work week.
Following a merits hearing, the 
  family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation to $2,000 per month and set 
  his child support obligation at $1,206 per month. 
  [2] Â  The family court based its decision to grant Husband a reduction on 
  Husbandâ€™s decreased income, finding Husband had actually earned $168,996 [3]  at the time of the divorce and imputing a salary of $120,000 
  to Husband at the time of this action. Â The family court also awarded 
  Wife the value of $24,627 in attorneyâ€™s fees by directing Husband to pay $7,000 
  in addition to the offset credit from his support overage.Â  Wife appeals both 
  orders, arguing the family court erred in reducing Husbandâ€™s support obligations.Â  
  Husband appeals the final order, arguing the family court should have further 
  reduced his support obligations and asserting that the court should have awarded 
  him, not Wife, attorneyâ€™s fees.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 
  157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this 
  court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither is the court required 
  to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was 
  in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight 
  to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 
  541, 541 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wifeâ€™s appeal
Wife argues the family court erred in reducing Husbandâ€™s 
  child support obligation at the temporary hearing and in reducing Husbandâ€™s 
  alimony and child support obligations at the final hearing.Â  We agree.
â€œFamily courts are empowered to modify child support 
  upon a proper showing of a change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting 
  parentâ€™s financial ability.â€Â  Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 196, 
  379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989) (citation omitted); see Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. at 477, 279 S.E.2d at 617 (finding the issue of child support is subject 
  to continuing review by the family court).Â  â€œTo warrant a modification in child 
  support, the change of circumstances must be either substantial or material.â€Â  
  Fischbach v. Tuttle, 302 S.C. 555, 557, 397 S.E.2d 773, 774 (Ct. App. 
  1990).
Similarly, to justify modification of an alimony 
  award, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  Thornton 
  v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997); see also 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985) (stating that changed conditions may warrant 
  a modification or termination of alimony).Â  Further, the change in circumstances 
  must be unanticipated.Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 486, 477 S.E.2d 
  727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Several considerations relevant to the initial determination 
  of alimony may be applied in the modification context as well, including the 
  partiesâ€™ standard of living during the marriage, each partyâ€™s earning capacity, 
  and the supporting spouseâ€™s ability to continue to support the other spouse.Â  
  Id.Â  
We find Husband failed to show a substantial or 
  material change in circumstances.Â  The family courtâ€™s decision to reduce Husbandâ€™s 
  support was ostensibly based on two reasons, both of which we find to be erroneous.Â  
  First, the family court found that Wifeâ€™s income had increased at the time of 
  the final hearing.Â  At the time of the divorce, Wifeâ€™s 1997 financial declaration 
  stated her gross monthly income was $1,273, and, at the time of the present 
  action, her 2001 financial declaration indicates monthly income of $2,269.92.Â  
  It was error to base a reduction on this ground, however, because such a change 
  was expected.Â  By agreement of the parties, Husbandâ€™s alimony payments were 
  to be reduced over time, beginning only six months after the final order granting 
  modification.Â  Although the divorce decree does not explain the reason for the 
  automatic decreases in Husbandâ€™s support obligations, the record supports the 
  family courtâ€™s finding that they were in anticipation of Wife increasing her 
  income.Â  It thus was error for the family court judge to grant Husband a reduction 
  on this basis.Â  See, e.g., Brown v. Brown, 278 S.C. 43, 
  44, 292 S.E.2d 297, 297 (1982) (finding that while the wifeâ€™s income increased 
  since the divorce, this increase cannot be used to justify a reduction in alimony 
  because it was contemplated by the parties at the time of the divorce).Â Â  
The family courtâ€™s second basis for reducing support 
  was the Husbandâ€™s reduction in reported income.Â  We find, however, that Husbandâ€™s 
  reduced income failed to constitute a substantial change impacting his ability 
  to pay the obligations to which he originally agreed.Â  This conclusion is based 
  on our review of the family courtâ€™s analysis of the Husbandâ€™s initial income, 
  his current income, and his imputed income.
Financial declarations are sworn documents required 
  by Rule 20 of the South Carolina Rules of Family Court.Â  Here the family court, 
  which approved the partiesâ€™ agreement in February 1998, relied on Husbandâ€™s 
  representation of $140,000 in annual income, as reflected in his financial declaration.Â  
  In this action for reduction, however, Husband testified his income in 1997 
  had been under-reported by him and that it was actually $165,226.Â  The family 
  court then utilized this inflated figure as support for its decision to reduce 
  Husbandâ€™s support obligation, finding that Husbandâ€™s income had decreased substantially 
  since the 1998 divorce.Â  This was error.
A party cannot misrepresent income and expenses 
  on a financial declaration for purposes of having an agreement approved and 
  then refute the accuracy of that document in a subsequent modification action.Â  
  SeeÂ  Rogers v. Rogers, 343 S.C. 329, 332, 540 S.E.2d 840, 841 
  (2001) (relying on original financial declaration rather than other records 
  indicating an increased income in evaluating change of circumstances); see 
  also Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 336 S.E.2d 884 (Ct. App. 1985) 
  (concluding husband was barred by res judicata from subsequent 
  challenge of cost of living index incorporated in divorce decree).Â  Therefore, 
  we find the family court erred in allowing Husband to contradict his previous 
  financial declaration in an effort to demonstrate a larger disparity from his 
  present income.Â  It was error for the family court to utilize Husbandâ€™s inflated 
  income of $168,996 rather than relying on the figure of $140,000 reported in 
  Husbandâ€™s original financial declaration.Â  We find the correct annual income 
  to attribute to Husband for purposes of evaluating his claim of changed circumstance 
  is $140,000, as reflected in his 1998 financial declaration.
Regarding Husbandâ€™s current income, we believe 
  the family court was correct in imputing to Husband an annual income of $120,000, 
  rather than the $100,000 per year urged by Husband.Â Â  Initially we note that 
  Husbandâ€™s purported salary with his new practice in Atlanta is based on a one-year 
  contract that guarantees him a minimum of $100,000, based on a three-day work 
  week. 
Moreover, under the Child Support Guidelines, â€œincomeâ€ 
  is defined as â€œthe actual gross income of the parent, if employed to full capacity, 
  or potential income if unemployed or underemployed.â€Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 
  114-4720(A)(1) (Supp. 2002).Â  The Guidelines provide further that â€œ[i]n order 
  to impute income to a parent who is unemployed or underemployed, the court should 
  determine the employment potential and probable earnings level of the parent 
  based on that parentâ€™s recent work history, occupational qualifications, and 
  prevailing job opportunities and earning levels in the community.â€Â  Id. 
  at 114-4720(A)(5)(b).Â  Where a parent voluntarily lessens his or her earning 
  capacity, this court will closely scrutinize the facts to determine the parentâ€™s 
  capacity to earn, rather than his or her actual earnings.Â  See Robinson 
  v. Tyson, 319 S.C. 360, 363, 461 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct. App. 1995). 
Â We recognize that following the partiesâ€™ divorce, 
  Husbandâ€™s medical practice underwent some detrimental financial changes. We 
  agree with the family courtâ€™s conclusion that Husbandâ€™s salary in Columbia before 
  he moved to Atlanta was roughly $120,000 per year.Â  This conclusion is supported 
  by Husbandâ€™s 1999 W-2 indicating his salary was approximately $130,000, and 
  his 2000 W-2 showing his salary at approximately $118,000.Â  The family court 
  correctly noted the recent reduction in Husbandâ€™s salary was brought about by 
  Husbandâ€™s voluntary decision to leave his Columbia medical practice and move 
  to Atlanta.Â  We reiterate that Husbandâ€™s purported $100,000 salary from his 
  Atlanta medical practice is a guaranteed minimum salary and is achieved by working 
  only three days per week.Â  When a spouse voluntarily undertakes a move that 
  will reduce his or her income, the family court may properly impute income to 
  that spouse.Â  Id.Â  The family courtâ€™s imputation of income to Husband 
  was tantamount to finding Husband underemployed.Â  As such, the court was justified 
  in examining Husbandâ€™s earning potential based upon recent work history and 
  qualifications.Â  Since Husband was earning approximately $120,000 before he 
  voluntarily moved to Atlanta, the family court did not err in imputing that 
  level of income to him.Â  This is especially true considering Husbandâ€™s current 
  job in Atlanta seems to allow Husband the opportunity to work more hours and 
  increase his annual salary.
Comparing Husbandâ€™s initial income to the income properly 
  imputed to him, Husbandâ€™s annual salary has decreased from $140,000 to $120,000.Â  
  We find this decrease is not significant enough to severely impact his standard 
  of living or his ability to pay support obligations, particularly where that 
  decrease is due to a voluntary relocation.Â  See Townsend v. Townsend, 
  356 S.C. 70, 587 S.E.2d 118 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding that husbandâ€™s decrease 
  in income from $250,000 to $186,000 per year without showing of inability to 
  pay support obligations is not a substantial change in circumstances); Kielar 
  v. Kielar, 311 S.C. 466, 429 S.E. 2d 851 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating that involuntary 
  resignation resulting in a salary decrease from over $300,000 to roughly $180,000 
  per year did not amount to substantial change in circumstances because it had 
  no impact on standard of living and ability to pay obligations).Â  Because there 
  was no substantial change in circumstances sufficient to support a reduction 
  of Husbandâ€™s alimony and child support obligation, we find the family court 
  erred in reducing Husbandâ€™s support obligations.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s 
  decision is reversed, and the partiesâ€™ previous alimony and child support agreement 
  as incorporated in the 1998 divorce decree is reinstated.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Husbandâ€™s appeal

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony

Husband argues the family court erred in not further 
  decreasing or terminating his alimony obligation.Â  Husband also contends the 
  family court erred in imputing to him a $120,000 annual income.Â  We disagree.
As discussed above, we find the family court erred 
  in reducing Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation.Â  Therefore, we cannot find, as Husband 
  argues, that the court did not reduce his obligation enough.Â  As also 
  explained above, we believe the family court was correct in imputing to Husband 
  an annual income of $120,000.Â  Thus, we find no merit to either one of Husbandâ€™s 
  alleged errors regarding his support obligations.

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s fees

Husband argues the family court erred in failing to 
  award attorneyâ€™s fees in his favor.Â  Further, Husband argues the family court 
  erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We disagree.
Before awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court 
  should consider: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) the 
  beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial 
  conditions; and (4) the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard 
  of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 
  (1992).Â  An award of attorneyâ€™s fees will not be overturned absent an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 
  901, 903 (1988).Â Â  
We find the family court was correct in granting 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife and not to Husband.Â  Though Wifeâ€™s annual income has 
  nearly doubled since the partiesâ€™ divorce in 1997, Husband has a much greater 
  earning potential as a pediatrician.Â  As such, Husband is clearly more able 
  to pay both his own attorneyâ€™s fees and those accrued by Wife.Â  Along those 
  lines, Husbandâ€™s standard of living will be better able to absorb the fees in 
  view of his income.Â  Finally and most importantly, Wife has now prevailed in 
  the Husbandâ€™s attempt to alter the support obligations.Â  Accordingly, the family 
  court judge did not err in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to her.
CONCLUSION
Â The family courtâ€™s temporary and final orders decreasing 
  Husbandâ€™s child support and alimony obligations based on change of circumstances 
  are reversed, thereby reinstating the alimony and child support plan outlined 
  in the divorce decree of February 6, 1998.Â  We remand this matter to the family 
  court for a determination of alimony and child support arrearages.Â  The award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife is affirmed.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
 HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Husbandâ€™s current wife, while living in Columbia, earned between $20,000 
    and $54,000 per year working as a registered nurse. Â For the purposes 
    of this action, the parties stipulated that current wifeâ€™s income would not 
    be merged into Husbandâ€™s; however, testimony of the indirect benefit of her 
    financial contribution to Husbandâ€™s household expenses was admitted.Â  Â Â 

 
   
    [2] At the temporary hearing, the family court reduced Husbandâ€™s child 
    support obligation to $1,063 per month, and ordered Husband to pay Wife $2,500 
    in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  

 
   
    [3] We acknowledge the slight discrepancy between Husbandâ€™s testimony 
    that his 1997 income was $165,226 and the family courtâ€™s finding that Husbandâ€™s 
    income was $168,996, but view it as inconsequential.

description: William Hatfield, individually and on behalf of Hyman Law Firm, brought an action against Susan Van Epps to recover attorney's fees she owed Law Firm.
