THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Frances Walsh as Personal Representative of the Estate of Jerome Walsh, 
        Deceased, and in her individual capacity, Appellant,
v.
Joyce K. Woods, f/k/a Joyce K. Walsh, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3758
Heard December 11, 2003 â€“ Filed March 15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Russell H. Putnam, Jr., of Hinesville; for Appellant
John S. Nichols, of Columbia; Kelli Lister Sullivan, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, J.:Â  Frances Dudley Walsh (Frances), 
  individually and in her capacity as personal representative of the estate of 
  her deceased husband, Jerome J. Walsh (Walsh), brought this action against Walshâ€™s 
  former wife, Joyce K. Woods (Joyce). In her complaint, Frances seeks relief 
  pertaining to the disposition of surviving spouse benefits made available through 
  Walshâ€™s retirement plan.Â  Frances appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order granting 
  Joyceâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Walsh married his first wife, Joyce, 
  in 1957, and the two separated in 1970. Although they continued to live apart, 
  Walsh and Joyce remained married for twenty years after their separation. Â In 
  1989, Walsh retired from E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company (DuPont) after 
  approximately forty years of employment.Â  During his tenure at DuPont, Walsh 
  participated in a DuPont sponsored pension benefits plan governed by the Employee 
  Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, 29 U.S.C. 1001 et. seq. 
  (â€œERISAâ€). Contemporaneously with his retirement, Walsh signed a Post Retirement 
  Company-Paid Survivor Benefits and Spouse Benefit Option designating Joyce, 
  to whom he was still married, as the sole beneficiary of his surviving spouse 
  benefits plan in the event he predeceased her. Walshâ€™s monthly benefit was therefore 
  reduced by the amount necessary to cover the cost of the survivor benefit plan.Â  

Walsh and Joyce were divorced by order 
  of the family court dated August 24, 1990. Â Incident to the divorce, 
  Walsh and Joyce entered into an agreement which the family court approved, adopted, 
  and incorporated into the divorce decree.Â  The decree provided, in relevant 
  part:
[T]he parties shall sign whatever documents or other paperwork 
  that is necessary to enforce this Agreement.Â  I find that the parties have further 
  agreed that each shall retain what .Â  .Â  . retirement plans, pension plans .Â  
  .Â  . etc., that he or she has in his or her possession.Â  If the wife is required 
  to sign any papers concerning the husbandâ€™s retirement or benefit options from 
  DuPont of Westinghouse, then she shall sign those. 
It is undisputed Walsh 
  never presented Joyce with any documents to sign regarding his retirement benefits, 
  and that neither party attempted to obtain a Qualified Domestic Relations Order 
  (QDRO) reassigning the surviving spouse benefits during Walshâ€™s lifetime.
On May 31, 1991, Walsh advised DuPont 
  he was divorced from Joyce and desired to change the beneficiary of his pension 
  plan to his wife Frances and requested the paperwork for this purpose 
  [1] .Â  In 1994, Walsh married Frances, with whom he had been involved since 
  1980. Â Â Â On November 30, 1994, Walsh wrote to DuPont again advising the 
  company that he was married to Frances and wished to designate her as beneficiary 
  under his retirement plan, and that the company should send him any documentation 
  necessary to effectuate the change in beneficiary.Â  Despite the May 31, 1991 
  letter and other subsequent communications with DuPont wherein Walsh referred 
  to Frances as his designated beneficiary, the change Walsh requested 
  was never made legally effective.Â  
Walsh died testate on January 27, 1996. Pursuant 
  to the terms of his will, Frances became the sole beneficiary and the Personal 
  Representative of his estate.Â  
In 1997, Frances instituted an 
  action against DuPont, which was removed to federal court; seeking a judicial 
  finding that Walshâ€™s surviving spouse benefits (SSB) should be paid to her and 
  not Joyce.Â  DuPont moved for and was granted summary judgment based on the fact 
  that no QDRO existed terminating Joyceâ€™s right to receive the benefits at the 
  time of Walshâ€™s retirement. 
Thereafter, Frances contacted John W. 
  Harte, the attorney who represented Walsh in his divorce from Joyce, and requested 
  that he prepare and submit a QDRO to DuPont.Â  Harte prepared the QDRO, then 
  contacted Vickie Johnson, the attorney who represented Joyce in the divorce 
  action, and requested that she obtain Joyceâ€™s signature on the document. Joyce 
  did not sign the QDRO but authorized Johnson to sign it on her behalf.Â  Joyce 
  noted on the document, however, that she authorized her signature under protest 
  and out of concern she would be held in contempt of court if she refused to 
  sign.Â  
In August of 1998, Harte submitted the 
  QDRO to DuPont.Â  In a letter dated September 16, 1998, DuPont advised Harte 
  that the document was unenforceable as a QDRO inasmuch as â€œ[a] QDRO cannot be 
  entered after the death of the participant. A participant must be a living person.Â  
  There was no QDRO in effect at the participantâ€™s death that awarded any benefits 
  to an alternate payee.Â  Therefore, there are no benefits payable pursuant to 
  a QDRO.â€ In addition, the letter from DuPont advised that even if the document 
  had been prepared at some point prior to Walshâ€™s death, it would nonetheless 
  be ineffective to divest Joyce of her surviving spouse benefits inasmuch as 
  ERISA requires that married participants be offered qualified joint and survivor 
  annuities and their spouses must be offered the option to accept or waive the 
  benefit.Â Â  Once this election is made, it is irrevocable. 
Frances filed the instant action against 
  Joyce on December 18, 2000, seeking recovery under seven theories of relief: 
  1) unjust enrichment; 2) â€œlaw of the caseâ€; 3) res judicata; 4) collateral estoppel; 
  5) breach of contract; 6) bad faith breach of contract; and 7) conversion. Joyce 
  answered, denying Frances was entitled to the relief sought in her complaint, 
  and asserted as defenses: 1) expiration of the statute of limitations; 2) failure 
  to state a claim upon which relief can be granted; 3) laches; and 4) res
judicata. 

The parties filed cross motions for summary 
  judgment.Â  Joyce argued, inter alia, that all of Francesâ€™s causes 
  of actions failed because the surviving spouse benefits vested in Joyce in 1989, 
  at the time of Walshâ€™s retirement, and she could not now be divested of her 
  right to the benefits.Â Â  Joyce further asserted the applicable statute of limitations 
  bars the claims.Â  In support of her cross motion, Frances asserted generally 
  that no genuine issues of material fact existed and specifically that Joyce 
  had waived her rights to the benefits in the divorce decree.Â  In addition, Frances 
  asserted that the court could enforce the property settlement agreement by requiring 
  Joyce to disgorge herself of all surviving spouse benefit payments she had received 
  in the past and will receive in the future by transferring the payments to Frances.
 By order dated January 28, 2001, the trial 
  court granted Joyceâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Specifically, the court 
  cited Hopkins v. AT&T, 105 F.3d 153, 157 (4th Cir. 1997), for the 
  propositions that 1) surviving spouse benefits vest in a plan participantâ€™s 
  current spouse on the date the participant retires, whether or not spouses are 
  married at the time the participant dies, and 2) surviving spouse benefits may 
  not be paid to a spouse who marries a participant after the participantâ€™s retirement. 
  The trial court expressly determined the holding in Hopkins was determinative 
  of the entire case and, therefore, declined to address Joyceâ€™s other grounds 
  for summary judgment and further declined to reach Francesâ€™s cross motion for 
  summary judgment.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Joyce argues in her Petition for Rehearing that 
  the dispositive issue on appeal is whether Francesâ€™s claims based on contract 
  and/or conversion are barred by the applicable statute of limitations.Â  We agree. 

The statute of limitations begins to run at the 
  time the cause of action accrues.Â  Harvey v. S.C. Dept. of Corrections, 
  338 S.C. 500, 508, 527 S.E.2d 765, 769 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Matthews v. 
  City of Greenwood, 305 S.C. 267, 269, 407 S.E.2d 668, 669 (Ct. App. 1991)).Â  
  In analyzing a limitations defense, â€œ[t]he fundamental test for determining 
  whether a cause of action has accrued is whether the party asserting the claim 
  can maintain an action to enforce it.â€Â  Id. (quoting Matthews, 
  305 S.C. at 269, 407 S.E.2d at 669).Â  Thus, a particular cause of action accrues 
  â€œat the moment when the plaintiff has a legal right to sue on it.â€Â  Id.
The statute of limitations for both an action upon 
  a contract and a conversion claim is three (3) years. S.C. Code Ann. Â§15-3-530(1) 
  and (5) (Supp. 2003).Â  Additionally, under Â§15-3-535 an action predicated on 
  an injury to the person or rights of another not arising on contract must be 
  brought within three years after the person knew â€œor by the exercise of reasonable 
  diligence should have known that he had a cause of action.â€Â  Thus, under the 
  discovery rule the statute of limitations begins to run from the date the injured 
  party either knows or should have known by the exercise of due diligence that 
  a cause of action arises from the wrongful conduct.Â  Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 
  321 S.C. 360, 363, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996).Â  A cause of action arises when 
  it â€œshould have been discovered through exercise of reasonable diligence when 
  the facts and circumstances would have put a person of common knowledge and 
  experience on notice that some right had been invaded or a claim against another 
  party might exist.â€Â  Maher v. Tietex Corp., 331 S.C. 371, 377, 500 S.E.2d 
  204, 207 (Ct. App. 1998).
To determine whether the statute of limitations 
  has run, the Court does not consider whether the particular plaintiff in the 
  case before it knew he or she had a claim but rather â€œwhether the circumstances 
  of the case would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice 
  that some right of his has been invaded, or that some claim against another 
  party might exist.â€Â  Young v. S.C. Department of Corrections, 333 S.C. 
  714, 719, 511 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1999).
In the instant case, Frances retained counsel to enforce 
  her rights to her husbandâ€™s SSB when she learned that DuPont was paying the 
  SSB to Joyce regardless of any waiver of her rights to the benefits or approval 
  of that waiver by the family court.Â  On November 20, 1997, United States District 
  Judge Matthew Perry dismissed the claims Frances brought against DuPont.Â  We 
  hold that this dismissal should have put Frances on notice, and would put any 
  person of common knowledge and experience on notice, that she individually and 
  on behalf of Mr. Walshâ€™s estate had a cause of action against Joyce.Â  Because 
  Frances did not file her complaint against Joyce until December 11, 2000, over 
  three years after Judge Perry issued his order, Francesâ€™s claims against Joyce 
  are barred by the statute of limitations. [2] Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court 
  is
AFFIRMED.Â Â  
STILWELL and HOWARD, JJ., concur.Â 

 
   [1]  Apparently, Walsh thought he had a common law 
    marriage with Frances.

 
   [2]  Having decided that the cause of action is barred 
    by the applicable statute of limitations, we need not address the remaining 
    issues raised on appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
QZO, Inc., d/b/a Palmetto Ambulance Service,
Respondent,
v.
Darrin Moyer, Jerry Benenhaley, Alice Childers,
Of Whom Darrin Moyer is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3759
Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kevin S. Little, of Atlanta, GA; and William E. Hopkins, 
  Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Blaney A. Coskrey, III, John E. Schmidt, III, Travis Dayhuff, 
  and Daniel J. Westbrook, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Darrin Moyer (â€œAppellantâ€) appeals several rulings from 
  the Circuit Court in favor of QZO, Inc., d/b/a Palmetto Ambulance Service (â€œPalmettoâ€), 
  including the denial of Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss based on lack of personal 
  jurisdiction, the granting of a temporary restraining order (â€œTROâ€), the imposition 
  of sanctions for violating the TRO, and the courtâ€™s decision to strike Appellantâ€™s 
  answer and declare him in default.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case arises out of a dispute between former business partners.Â  Appellant, 
  a citizen and resident of Richmond County, Georgia, is a fifty percent owner/shareholder 
  in Palmetto, a corporation organized under the laws of the state of Georgia.Â  
  Palmetto provides ambulance services and maintains offices in Augusta, Georgia, 
  and Columbia, South Carolina. 
Keith Stille, the president of Palmetto and the 
  other fifty percent shareholder, commenced this action by verified complaint 
  dated February 28, 2002.Â  The complaint alleged Stille had reason to believe 
  Appellant intended to open a competing ambulance service in violation of the 
  South Carolina Trade Secrets Act. [1] Â  The complaint stated that Palmetto 
  had reason to believe a computer belonging to the company, but in Appellantâ€™s 
  possession, contained evidence of Appellantâ€™s wrongful acts.
The complaint requested a TRO enjoining Appellant from using any 
  proprietary information and ordering Appellant to surrender the computer either 
  to Palmetto or a neutral third party.
Having determined that the information in Palmettoâ€™s computer was 
  in danger of being altered or destroyed before a hearing on the matter could 
  be accomplished, and that irreparable harm would result if the TRO were not 
  issued, the Circuit Court granted the TRO on the same day the original complaint 
  was filed.Â  The TRO ordered Appellant to immediately surrender Palmettoâ€™s computer 
  upon receipt of the order.
Although the TRO was issued on February 28, 2002, and served on the 
  Appellant that same day, Appellant did not turn over the computer until seven 
  days later.Â  Upon receipt, counsel for Palmetto hired a computer expert to inspect 
  and retrieve any pertinent information that might be located on the computerâ€™s 
  hard drive.Â  However, the expertâ€™s examination revealed that the hard drive 
  was reformatted a day before the computer had been turned over to Palmetto, 
  effectively erasing any information the computer may have contained.
On March 8, 2002, and again on March 22, 2002, Palmetto filed amended 
  complaints adding additional grounds of liability as well as two more defendants.Â  
  In a motion dated April 24, 2002, Appellant moved to dismiss the case pursuant 
  to Rule 12(b), SCRCP.Â  Specifically, Appellant averred the case should be dismissed 
  based on Rule 12(b)(1) â€“ lack of subject matter jurisdiction; 12(b)(2) â€“ lack 
  of personal jurisdiction; and 12(b)(8) â€“ that another action was pending between 
  the parties concerning the same subject matter as the current suit.
Before Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss was heard, Palmetto moved pursuant 
  to Rule 37, SCRCP, for sanctions to be imposed on Appellant for what Palmetto 
  alleged was a willful violation of the TRO issued by the court on February 28, 
  2002.Â  On July 9, 2002, a hearing was held concerning both motions.Â  In an order 
  dated July 30, 2002, the trial court denied Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss and 
  granted Palmettoâ€™s motion for sanctions.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
Specifically, the court found Appellant willfully destroyed evidence 
  relevant to Palmettoâ€™s case.Â  Thereafter, while recognizing the severity of 
  the sanction, the trial court struck Appellantâ€™s pleadings and entered a judgment 
  of liability in favor of Palmetto.
Appellant filed a motion to reconsider and a hearing was held on 
  September 30, 2002.Â  In an order dated October 8, 2002, the trial court reaffirmed 
  its earlier rulings and denied Appellantâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment.
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I.   
         
  Did the trial court err in denying Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss based on lack 
  of personal jurisdiction?
      
      
         II.  
         
  Did the trial court err in issuing a TRO that provided no opportunity for Appellant 
  to be heard?
      
      
         III. 
         
  Did the trial court err in sanctioning Appellant for an alleged violation of 
  the TRO?
      
      
         IV.   
         Did the 
  trial court err in striking Appellantâ€™s answer and entering a default judgment 
  of liability in favor of Palmetto?
      
    
  

  LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Denial of 
  Motion to Dismiss
Appellant argues the trial court erred in failing to grant its motion to dismiss 
  based on lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  We disagree.
Although a pre-trial motion to dismiss based on lack of personal jurisdiction 
  is not usually immediately appealable, it can be considered when other appealable 
  issues are presented to an appellate court.Â  See Mid-State Distribs., 
  Inc. v. Century Imps., Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 426 S.E.2d 777 (1993); Cox 
  v. Woodmen ofÂ  the World Ins. Co., 347 S.C. 460, 556 S.E.2d 397 (Ct. App. 
  2001).
A two-step process is utilized to determine whether or not a South Carolina 
  court may exercise personal jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant.Â  Southern 
  Plastics Co. v. Southern Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992).Â  
  The trial court must first consider whether South Carolinaâ€™s long-arm statute 
  applies. [2] Â  Should the court 
  find the statute does apply, it must then determine whether the defendantâ€™s 
  contacts with South Carolina are such that an exercise of personal jurisdiction 
  would comport with due process.Â  Id.Â  
As the trial court correctly pointed out in its order denying Appellantâ€™s motion 
  to dismiss, Appellantâ€™s conduct clearly falls within the purview of the long-arm 
  statute.Â  First, when Appellant was an officer and director working for Palmetto, 
  his office was located in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  After leaving Palmetto, 
  Appellant began operating a competing ambulance service under the name of Regional 
  Ambulance Service, Inc., with its principal place of business in West Columbia, 
  South Carolina.Â  Because Appellant was transacting business in this state, the 
  long-arm statute is satisfied.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803(1)(a) (2003) 
  (stating a court may exercise jurisdiction over a person transacting business 
  in South Carolina).
Moreover, the long-arm statute is satisfied because Palmetto averred in its 
  complaint that the alleged wrongful conduct occurred within South Carolina.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803(1)(c) (2003) (jurisdiction exists over 
  a person committing a tortious act in whole or in part in South Carolina).
Significantly, the nature of Appellantâ€™s current business in South Carolina 
  would subject him to general jurisdiction as well under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-802 
  (2003).Â  Section 802 reads as follows:Â  â€œA court may exercise personal jurisdiction 
  over a person domiciled in, organized under the laws of, doing business, 
  or maintaining his or its principal place of business in, this State 
  as to any cause of action.â€Â  Id. (emphasis added).
Furthermore, Appellantâ€™s contacts with South Carolina are such that the exercise 
  of jurisdiction would comport with due process.Â  In order for states to exercise 
  jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant, due process requires that the defendant 
  have minimum contacts with the forum state â€œsuch that maintenance of the suit 
  does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.â€Â  
  World-Wide Volkswagen Corp. v. Woodson, 444 U.S. 286, 291-92 (1980).
The due process analysis involves a two-step inquiry.Â  First, it must be determined 
  if the party has minimum contacts with the forum state.Â  One way to determine 
  whether a party has minimum contacts with a state is to determine whether he 
  or she â€œshould reasonably anticipate being haled into court there.â€Â  Burger 
  King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 462, 474 (1985).Â  Clearly, Appellantâ€™s 
  contacts were such in South Carolina that he should reasonably anticipate â€œbeing 
  haled into court [here].â€Â  He currently owns and operates a business in South 
  Carolina, worked for Palmetto in South Carolina, and allegedly committed the 
  complained of acts in South Carolina.Â  Thus, Appellant has the requisite minimum 
  contacts with the state to satisfy due process.
Similarly, the traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice would 
  not be offended by exercise of jurisdiction over Appellant.Â  To determine whether 
  an exercise of jurisdiction would comport with this standard, a number of factors 
  must be considered, including: (1) the duration of Appellantâ€™s activity in this 
  state; (2) the nature and circumstances of Appellantâ€™s acts; (3) inconvenience 
  to the parties by either the exercise or refusal to exercise jurisdiction; and 
  (4) South Carolinaâ€™s interest in exercising jurisdiction over the action.Â  Clark 
  v. Key, 304 S.C. 497, 405 S.E.2d 599 (1991).Â  This standard is met as well.Â  
  Appellant maintained activity in South Carolina the entire time he worked for 
  Palmetto, and currently runs another business in this state.Â  All the acts of 
  which Palmetto complains occurred in South Carolina.Â  The exercise of jurisdiction 
  would not inconvenience the parties because Appellant currently runs a business 
  located in this state.Â  Finally, South Carolina has an interest in exercising 
  personal jurisdiction over this action because the acts complained of occurred 
  here.
Because we find Appellantâ€™s conduct falls within the purview of the long-arm 
  statute and comports with due process, we hold that the trial court did not 
  err in its refusal to grant Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss.
Appellant avers that South Carolinaâ€™s â€œdoor closing statuteâ€ [3]  prevents a non-resident corporation from bringing 
  an action against a non-resident citizen within South Carolina.Â  Indubitably, 
  the â€œdoor closing statuteâ€ does NOT involve subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
  See Farmer v. Monsanto Corp., 353 S.C. 553, 579 S.E.2d 325 (2003).Â  
  Because Appellant did not raise this argument below, it is not preserved for 
  our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 
  731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal.â€).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  TRO
Appellant makes a number of arguments concerning the TRO the court 
  issued on Palmettoâ€™s behalf.Â  However, these issues were not raised in the court 
  below and they are not preserved for our review.Â  See Regions Bank 
  v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).
III.Â Â Â  Sanctions and Default Judgment
Because issues three and four are related, we find it prudent to 
  address them simultaneously.Â  Appellant contends the trial court erred by granting 
  sanctions, ordering Appellantâ€™s answer to be struck, and entering a default 
  judgment.Â  We disagree.
The decision of whether or not to award sanctions is generally entrusted to 
  the discretion of the trial court.Â  See Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. 
  Orangeburg, 354 S.C. 445, 581 S.E.2d 489 (Ct. App. 2003) (decision of what 
  kind and whether to impose discovery sanctions is left to sound discretion of 
  Circuit Court); Karppi v. Greenville Terrazzo Co., 327 S.C. 538, 489 
  S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting that imposition of sanctions is generally 
  entrusted to sound discretion of Circuit Court); see also Stone v. 
  Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 369 S.E.2d 840 (1988) (stating that contempt 
  decision should be reversed only when without evidentiary support or upon an 
  abuse of discretion by the trial court).Â  An appellate court will not disturb 
  this decision unless the trial court abused its discretion.Â  Griffin Grading 
  & Clearing, Inc. v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., 334 S.C. 193, 511 S.E.2d 
  716 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Karppi, 327 S.C. at 542, 489 S.E.2d 
  at 681 (stating that trial courtâ€™s exercise of its discretionary powers with 
  respect to sanctions imposed in discovery matters will be interfered with by 
  the Court of Appeals only if abuse of discretion has occurred).
The burden is on the appealing party to show the trial court abused its discretion 
  in imposing sanctions for failing to comply with a discovery order. Halverson 
  v. Yawn, 328 S.C. 618, 493 S.E.2d 883 (Ct. App. 1997); Karppi, 327 
  S.C. at 542, 489 S.E.2d at 681.Â  An abuse of discretion may be found where the 
  appellant shows that the conclusion reached by the trial court was without reasonable 
  factual support and resulted in prejudice to the rights of appellant, thereby 
  amounting to an error of law.Â  Kershaw County Bd. of Educ. v. United States 
  Gypsum Co., 302 S.C. 390, 396 S.E.2d 369 (1990); Karppi, 327 S.C. 
  at 542, 489 S.E.2d at 681.
When a party fails to obey an order relating to discovery, the trial court 
  may strike that partyâ€™s pleadings and enter a default judgment.Â  Griffin, 
  334 S.C. at 198, 511 S.E.2d at 718 (citing Rule 37(b)(2)(c), SCRCP); see 
  also Karppi, 327 S.C. at 542, 489 S.E.2d at 682 (explaining that 
  Rule 37, SCRCP, expressly grants trial court power to order judgment by default 
  for either the violation of a court order or, upon motion, for partyâ€™s failure 
  to respond to certain discovery requests).Â  When a court orders a sanction that 
  results in default or dismissal, â€œthe end result is harsh medicine that should 
  not be administered lightly.â€Â  Griffin, 334 S.C. at 198, 511 S.E.2d at 
  718; see also Karppi, 327 S.C. at 547, 489 S.E.2d at 684 (Anderson, 
  J., concurring) (â€œA sanction which results in a default or dismissal is harsh 
  punishment which should be imposed only if there is some showing of willful 
  disobedience or gross indifference to the rights of the adverse party.â€).Â  The 
  sanction should be aimed at the specific misconduct of the party sanctioned 
  and should not be used improvidently to prevent a decision on the merits.Â  Griffin, 
  334 S.C. at 198, 511 S.E.2d at 719; Karppi, 327 S.C. at 543, 489 S.E.2d 
  at 682.Â  The sanction imposed should be reasonable, and the court should not 
  go beyond the necessities of the situation to foreclose a decision on the merits 
  of a case.Â  Karppi, 327 S.C. at 543, 489 S.E.2d at 682.Â  Finally, when 
  a sanction â€œwould be tantamount to granting a judgment by default, the moving 
  party must show bad faith, willful disobedience or gross indifference to its 
  rights to justify the sanction.â€Â  Griffin, 334 S.C. at 198-99, 511 S.E.2d 
  at 719; see also Karppi, 327 S.C. at 543, 489 S.E.2d at 682 (â€œBefore 
  invoking this severe remedy, the trial court must determine that there is some 
  element of bad faith, willfulness, or gross indifference to the rights of other 
  litigants.â€).
Appellant essentially argues there is no evidence to suggest he intentionally 
  violated the TRO.Â  We disagree.Â  The record contains evidence to support the 
  trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  The trial court heard Appellantâ€™s testimony and found 
  it lacked credibility.Â  In fact, the trial judge commented at the hearing that 
  Appellantâ€™s reasons for not complying with the TRO were â€œa great mysterious 
  sequence of coincidences that strain credulity.â€Â  When, as here, there is conflicting 
  evidence on an issue, it is up to the court as trier of facts to judge credibility.Â  
  See Halbersberg v. Berry, 302 S.C. 97, 394 S.E.2d 7 (Ct. App. 
  1990).Â  
Additionally, it is undisputed that Appellant did not turn the computer over 
  to Palmetto until seven days after issuance of the TRO.Â  When the computer was 
  eventually turned over, it became clear that the hard-drive had been formatted 
  the day before, effectively erasing any information contained therein.Â  We conclude 
  there was evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding that Appellant willfully 
  violated the TRO.
Appellant asserts the trial court did not consider 
  the severity of the sanction when he ordered Appellantâ€™s pleadings struck.Â  
  We disagree.Â  The trial court specifically mentioned in its order that â€œ[a]lthough 
  it is a severe sanction, the Court strikes [Appellantâ€™s pleadings] . . . in 
  response to [Appellantâ€™s] intentional defiance of this Courtâ€™s order of February 
  28, 2002 and his willful destruction of evidence.â€
Appellant cites Karppi v. Greenville Terrazzo Co., 327 S.C. 
  538, 489 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 1997), in support of his argument.Â  However, Karppi 
  is factually distinguishable from the present case.Â  In Karppi, this 
  Court held that the trial courtâ€™s sanction of striking the answer of a defendant 
  was unduly harsh under the circumstances, especially because of the profound 
  effect it had on the co-defendant to the litigation.Â  Here, the only party punished 
  is the Appellant, the party who clearly and willfully committed the misconduct.
The sanction imposed in the case of Griffin Grading & Clearing, 
  Inc. v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., 334 S.C. 193, 511 S.E.2d 716 (Ct. App. 
  1999), is similar to the sanction in the case sub judice.Â  After 
  Griffin Grading filed suit against Tire Service, the circuit judge struck Tire 
  Serviceâ€™s answer as a discovery sanction.Â  On appeal, the Court of Appeals determined 
  that the striking of Tire Serviceâ€™s answer as a discovery sanction was warranted 
  based on Tire Serviceâ€™s failure to comply meaningfully with four prior orders 
  compelling discovery, even after the imposition of the assessment of attorney 
  fees and after Tire Service was warned of the consequences of its failure to 
  comply with the courtâ€™s order.
The trial court in the instant case complied with the standards articulated 
  in Karppi v. Greenville Terrazzo Co., 327 S.C. 538, 489 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. 
  App. 1997), and Griffin Grading & Clearing, Inc. v. Tire Serv. Equip. 
  Mfg. Co., 334 S.C. 193, 511 S.E.2d 716 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Concomitantly, 
  the trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding sanctions or ordering 
  Appellantâ€™s answer stricken.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s rulings are
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  
    See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 39-8-10 to â€“130 (Supp. 2003).

 
   [2]  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803 (2003).

 
   [3]  
    See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150 (1977).

title: Rogers v. State
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed Brandon Heath Rogersâ€™s appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of his conviction in municipal court for criminal domestic violence (CDV).  On appeal, Rogers argued the circuit court erred in (1) upholding the decision of the municipal court finding him guilty of CDV; (2) failing to hold that the municipal court erred by not granting a directed verdict to him; and (3) failing to file an order setting forth its findings of fact and conclusions of law pursuant to Rule 52(a), SCRCP. On the first issue, the court noted that it was not able to conduct a de novo review, as urged by Rogers, but instead was limited to review errors of law in criminal appeals from magistrateâ€™s or municipal courts.  Because Rogers alleged no legal error, the court affirmed his conviction.  The court found the second issue, regarding Rogersâ€™s directed verdict motion, unpreserved because he failed to raise it to the circuit court, which was acting as an intermediate appellate court.  Concerning the third issue, the court found the rule of civil procedure cited by Rogersâ€™s was inapplicable in this criminal matter.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Brandon Heath Rogers, Appellant,
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
J. C. Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3760Â Â 
Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 15, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Cheree  Gillespie, of Clemson, for Appellant,
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, of 
  Columbia; Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.: Â Brandon Heath Rogers appeals 
  his conviction of criminal domestic violence (CDV), arguing the circuit court 
  erred by (1) upholding the decision of the municipal court, which was the trial 
  court, finding him guilty of CDV; (2) failing to hold that the municipal court 
  erred by not granting a directed verdict to him; and (3) failing to file an 
  order setting forth its findings of fact and conclusions of law pursuant to 
  Rule 52(a), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On the morning of March 24, 2002, Brandonâ€™s 
  wife, Rebecca Lynn Rogers, went to the Westminster Police Department to report 
  an incident of CDV allegedly perpetrated by Brandon against her.Â  According 
  to Rebeccaâ€™s written and signed statement, Brandon and she argued the previous 
  night while riding in their car.Â  Rebecca told police that while they were arguing, 
  Brandon â€œwas smacking me in my face and in my head.â€Â  Later, when they arrived 
  at a gas station, Rebecca stated Brandon â€œsmashed my face there.â€Â  The couple 
  then drove to their home, where Rebecca claimed in her written statement to 
  police that Brandon â€œbusted my windshield,â€ â€œsmacked me in the head,â€ and â€œpunched 
  me in the side of the stomach.â€Â  According to Rebeccaâ€™s statement, when the 
  couple entered their house, Brandon made Rebecca â€œget into bed,â€ â€œdared me out 
  with a knife,â€ â€œhit me again,â€ and told her he would â€œhurt me really badâ€ if 
  she contacted law enforcement.Â  Among other things, Rebecca stated that Brandon 
  â€œthreaten[ed] to kill my parents and my brother.â€
At trial before the municipal court on 
  May 9, 2002, Rebecca confirmed she had written and signed the statement.Â  Brandonâ€™s 
  attorney initially objected to having Rebecca read the statement into evidence.Â  
  However, she agreed to allow Rebecca read the statement into evidence â€œsentence 
  by sentence[,] and at the end of each sentenceâ€ allow Rebecca to acknowledge 
  whether she made that portion of the statement, and make additional comments 
  about that portion of the statement. 
Rebecca proceeded to read the statement 
  into evidence, frequently reacting to portions of the statement with claims 
  that she did not remember the incidents cited in the report.Â  However, when 
  she read a sentence that stated Brandon had â€œsmackedâ€ her at the gas station, 
  she did not refute its accuracy or question her memory of the incident.Â  Among 
  other things, she also acknowledged that Brandon hit her â€œin the sideâ€ but claimed 
  that his action was accidental.Â  Furthermore, when asked under cross-examination 
  whether Brandon â€œthreatened [her] with a knife,â€ she responded, â€œYeah.Â  I mean[,] 
  he didnâ€™t have a knife but he told be he could get something but he didnâ€™t have 
  one he didnâ€™t point one at me or anything.â€
At the trialâ€™s conclusion, the municipal 
  court found Brandon guilty of CDV, noting that he found Rebeccaâ€™s signed and 
  written statement more credible than her testimony in court.Â  Brandon received 
  a time-served sentence, which amounted to twenty days in jail.
Brandon then appealed to the circuit court, only 
  â€œupon the grounds of inadequate evidence to support a conviction and utilization 
  of improper evidence.â€Â  Following a hearing, the circuit court affirmed the 
  municipal court.Â  Brandon then filed a Rule 52, SCRCP, motion seeking a written 
  order from the circuit court that enumerated its findings of fact and conclusions 
  of law.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, rejecting Brandonâ€™s efforts to 
  invoke civil procedural rules in a criminal appeal.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Finding of Guilt on CDV Charge
Brandon argues the municipal court erred 
  in finding him guilty of CDV.Â  We are constrained to disagree, for the simple 
  reason that Brandon seeks to pursue specious arguments and to assign error to 
  matters that were not raised in the lower courts.
Brandon was charged with CDV under S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-20 (Supp. 2001), which provides that â€œ[i]t is unlawful to: 
  (1) cause physical harm or injury to a personâ€™s own household member, (2) offer 
  or attempt to cause physical harm or injury to a personâ€™s own household member 
  with apparent present ability under circumstances reasonably creating fear of 
  imminent peril.â€Â  Here, Brandon does not allege an error of law, but instead 
  argues that evidence in the record fails to support either the municipal courtâ€™s 
  conclusion of his guilt or the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of his conviction.Â  
  Brandon clearly misconstrues our standard of review, for in criminal appeals 
  we sit to review errors of law only.Â  See City of Landrum v. Sarratt, 
  352 S.C. 139, 141, 572 S.E.2d 476, 477 (Ct.App. 2002) (â€œIn criminal appeals 
  from magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de 
  novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate 
  exception.Â  In reviewing criminal cases, [the court of appeals] may review 
  errors of law only.â€) (emphasis added). 
  [1] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict
Brandon argues that the circuit court erred in 
  failing to hold that the municipal court erred by not granting Rogers a directed 
  verdict.Â  However, Brandon neither made a directed verdict motion in the trial 
  court nor raised the issue in his intermediate appeal to the circuit court.Â Â  
  Thus, the issue is not preserved, and we cannot address it.Â  See City 
  of Columbia v. Ervin, 330 S.C. 516, 519-20, 500 S.E.2d 483, 485 (1998)Â  
  (an issue not raised in an intermediate appeal cannot be considered in a subsequent 
  appeal to the court of appeals or supreme court); Graniteville Mfg. Co. v. 
  Renew, 113 S.C. 171, 171, 102 S.E. 18, 19 (1920) (an issue not made before 
  the circuit court on appeal from a magistrate is not properly before the appellate 
  court.).
III.Â Â Â  Rule 52(a), SCRCP, Motion 
Brandon argues the circuit court erred in denying 
  his motionÂ  pursuant to Rule 52(a), SCRCP, seeking an order setting forth the 
  circuit courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  We find this argument 
  unavailing, because the CDV charge against Brandon was a criminal matter to 
  which the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure do not apply.Â  See 
  Rule 1, SCRCP (stating â€œ[t]hese rules govern the procedures in all South Carolina 
  courts in all suits of a civil nature â€¦.).Â  Moreover, as noted above, the circuit 
  court, sitting in its appellate capacity, may not engage in fact finding.Â  We 
  find this issue meritless.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the judgment 
  of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â  The standard of appellate review in circuit court from a civil 
    judgment in magistrate court differs markedly from its criminal counterpart 
    in magistrate or municipal court.Â  See Parks v. Characters Night 
    Club, 345 S.C. 484, 490, 548 S.E.2d 605, 609 (Ct. App. 2001) (construing 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 and noting that in a civil appeal from magistrateâ€™s 
    court, the circuit court may make its own findings of fact.).

title: Fleet Capital v. Seal Jet
description: This case involves whether Michigan courts acquired personal jurisdiction over a defendant such that a judgment creditor can enforce a Michigan judgment in South Carolina.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Fleet Capital Leasing â€“ Technology Finance, formerly Sanwa Leasing Corporation,
        Respondent,
v.
Seal Jet of the Carolinas, Inc. f/k/a American High Performance Seals, 
        Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3761
Heard October 7, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  15, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Brian Dumas and Joseph M. McCulloch, Jr., both of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Anthony D. Hoefer, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HOWARD, J.: Â Â  Fleet Capital Leasing â€“ Technology 
  Finance (â€œFleetâ€) sought to enforce a Michigan default judgment against Seal 
  Jet of the Carolinas, Inc. (â€œSeal Jetâ€) pursuant to the Uniform Enforcement 
  of Foreign Judgments Act, South Carolina Code Annotated section 15-35-900 â€“ 
  960 (Supp. 2002).Â  Seal Jet defended, asserting the default judgment was void 
  because the Michigan court did not have personal jurisdiction over it.Â  The 
  circuit court found Seal Jet made a general appearance in the Michigan case, 
  and thus, the Michigan court had personal jurisdiction.Â  Furthermore, the circuit 
  court entered the judgment of $18,345.97, plus interest, against Seal Jet.Â  
  Seal Jet appeals, arguing the circuit court erred by holding res judicata precluded 
  Seal Jet from raising the issue of personal jurisdiction as a defense to the 
  South Carolina proceeding.Â  We reverse and remand. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Fleet brought suit in Michigan against 
  Seal Jet, alleging it was formerly known as American High Performance Seals, 
  Inc. (â€œAmericanâ€), and was liable for breach of various leases signed by American.Â  
  The complaint alleged the leases were subject to Michigan law. 
Daniel Hughes, President of Seal Jet, was served 
  with the summons and complaint.Â  Hughes responded to the suit by writing a letter 
  to the Michigan District Court denying Seal Jet was a party to the leases and 
  asking for a jury trial. 
The Michigan court viewed this letter 
  as Seal Jetâ€™s answer to the lawsuit.Â  Fleet moved to strike the answer, arguing 
  a corporation can only appear through a licensed attorney.Â  Fleet asserted the 
  answer was therefore void and should be stricken. 
The Michigan District Court granted Fleetâ€™s motion, 
  striking Hughesâ€™ letter.Â  Further, because this meant Seal Jet had not answered 
  the complaint, the Michigan court entered a default judgment against Seal Jet. 

Fleet then submitted its Notice of Filing 
  of Foreign Judgment to the South Carolina circuit court to enroll the Michigan 
  judgment in South Carolina pursuant to the Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments 
  Act.Â  Seal Jet filed a motion for relief from the judgment.Â  Seal Jet asserted 
  that the Michigan court did not have personal jurisdiction over Seal Jet and 
  that Seal Jet and American were separate entities.Â  Seal Jet also contested 
  the merits of the underlying suit.Â  
The circuit court ruled Seal Jet could 
  not contest the merits of the Michigan action because to do so would be an impermissible 
  collateral attack in violation of the Full Faith and Credit clause of the United 
  States Constitution. U.S. Const. art. IV, Â§ 1.Â  Relying upon this courtâ€™s opinion 
  in Colonial Pacific Leasing Corp. v. Taylor, 326 S.C. 529, 484 S.E.2d 
  595 (Ct. App. 1997), the circuit court concluded Seal Jet had made a general 
  appearance in Michigan by means of Hughesâ€™ letters [1]  and was precluded by principles of res judicata from arguing 
  the Michigan court did not have personal jurisdiction.Â  The court entered judgment 
  against Seal Jet in the amount of $18,345.97 plus interest.Â  Seal Jet appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Seal Jet argues the circuit court erred by holding 
  res judicata precluded Seal Jet from raising the issue of personal jurisdiction 
  as a defense in the South Carolina proceeding.Â  We agree and remand.
The Full Faith and Credit Clause of the United 
  States Constitution requires the courts of one state give â€œsuch force and effect 
  to a foreign judgment as the judgment would receive in its own state.â€Â  Taylor, 
  326 S.C. at 532, 484 S.E.2d at 597; see U.S. Const. art. IV, Â§ 1 (â€œFull 
  Faith and Credit shall be given in each State to the public acts, records, and 
  judicial proceedings of every other State.â€).Â  However, â€œ[t]he Full Faith and 
  Credit Clause does not prevent the litigation of personal jurisdiction in an 
  action to enforce a foreign judgmentâ€ if the party did not make a general appearance 
  in the foreign jurisdiction. Taylor, 326 S.C. at 532-33, 484 S.E.2d at 
  596-97 (â€œOnly a defendant who â€˜remains aloofâ€™ by not making an appearance and 
  has a default judgment entered against him may contest the issue of personal 
  jurisdiction in a later proceeding.â€); see Alladin Plastics, Inc. 
  v. Wintenna, Inc., 301 S.C. 90, 92, 390 S.E.2d 370, 371 (Ct. App. 1990) 
  (â€œ[A] court is bound to enforce the judgment of a court in another state only 
  if the court in the other state had jurisdiction to render the judgment.â€); 
  see also Taylor, 326 S.C. at 533, 484 S.E.2d at 597 (â€œâ€˜A defendant 
  who appears [in the foreign jurisdiction] to litigate the merits without properly 
  preserving an objection to personal jurisdiction waives the right to raise the 
  objection in the initial proceeding and is bound by the resulting judgment.â€™â€ 
  (quoting Charles A. Wright, Arthur R. Miller, Edward H. Cooper, Federal Practice 
  and Procedure Â§ 4430 (1981))).
In determining whether a party made a 
  general appearance in the foreign jurisdiction, the laws of the state that rendered 
  the judgment must be applied.Â  Loyd & Ringâ€™s Wholesale Nursery, Inc. 
  v. Long & Woodley Landscaping and Garden Center, Inc., 315 S.C. 88, 
  91, 431 S.E.2d 632, 634 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œThe validity and effect of a foreign 
  judgment must be determined by the laws of the state that rendered the judgment.â€).Â  
  Therefore, we look to Michigan law to resolve the issue of whether Hughesâ€™ letter 
  served as a general appearance by the corporation, Seal Jet. 
In Michigan, â€œany action on the part of a defendant 
  that recognizes the pending proceedings, with the exception of objecting to 
  the courtâ€™s jurisdiction, will [normally] constitute a general appearance.â€ 
  Penny v. ABA Pharm. Co., 511 N.W.2d 896, 897 (Mich. Ct. App. 1993); see 
  Ragnone v. Wirsing, 367 N.W.2d 369, 370 (Mich. Ct. App. 1985) (â€œTwo requirements 
  must be met to render an act adequate to support the inference that there is 
  an appearance: (1) â€˜knowledge of the pending proceedingsâ€™ and (2) â€˜an intention 
  to appear.â€™â€ (quoting Rhodes v. Rhodes, 142 N.W.2d 508, 511 (Mich. Ct. 
  App. 1966)));Â  Deeb v. Berri, 325 N.W.2d 493, 496 (Mich. Ct. App. 1982) 
  (â€œThis Court has held that â€˜appearâ€™ as it is used in default proceedings should 
  be taken â€˜in its generic senseâ€™ as any act of a party acknowledging jurisdiction 
  of a court or invoking court action on his behalf.â€ (quoting Rhodes, 
  142 N.W.2d at 510)). Thus, as an initial matter, we note a letter sent to the 
  Michigan District Court that denies liability and asks for a jury trial is one 
  means of making a general appearance in Michigan.
Our inquiry then becomes whether, under Michigan 
  law, a corporation makes a general appearance when its president sends such 
  a letter to the court.
According to Michigan law, â€œ[a] party who enters 
  a general appearance and contests a cause of action on the merits submits to 
  the courtâ€™s jurisdiction.â€Â  Penny, 511 N.W.2d at 897.Â  A corporation 
  named as a party in a Michigan lawsuit can only appear through an attorney.Â  
  Detroit Bar Assâ€™n v. Union Guardian Trust Co., 281 N.W. 432, 433 (Mich. 
  1938) (â€œWhile an individual may appear in proper person, a corporation, because 
  of the very fact of its being a corporation, can appear only by attorney, regardless 
  of whether it is interested in its own corporate capacity or in a fiduciary 
  capacity.â€); Peters Production, Inc. v. Desnick Broadcasting Co., 429 
  N.W.2d 654, 655 (Mich. Ct. App. 1988) (â€œAn individual may appear in propria 
  persona; a corporation, however, can appear only by attorney regardless 
  of whether it is interested in its own corporate capacity or in a fiduciary 
  capacity.â€). 
After being served with a summons and complaint, 
  Hughes responded to the suit by writing a letter to the Michigan District Court 
  denying Seal Jet was a party to the lease and asking for a jury trial. 
At the Michigan hearing, Fleet moved to strike 
  Hughesâ€™ letter, arguing the letter did not constitute an appearance by the corporation 
  and was void.Â  The Michigan District Court agreed.
It stands to reason that a person who is legally 
  incapable of representing a corporation in a court proceeding and whom the court 
  refuses to recognize for that purpose cannot bind the corporation by his actions.Â  
  Although it may be true that Hughes intended to contest the merits of the lawsuit, 
  it is inconsistent to state Hughesâ€™ letter must be stricken from the court record 
  because Hughes was not authorized to speak for the corporation, and the letter 
  must be imputed to Seal Jet for purposes of determining if the corporation made 
  a general appearance.Â  
Once the letter was struck as not being an action 
  of the corporation, there was no evidence of a general appearance by the corporation 
  in the Michigan court proceedings.Â  In addition, there is no indication 
  in the record that the issue of personal jurisdiction has been previously litigated 
  by Seal Jet.Â  Thus, the circuit court erred by concluding res judicata precluded 
  Seal Jet from raising the issue of personal jurisdiction as a defense in this 
  proceeding. [2] 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the judgment 
  of the court is REVERSED, and the case is REMANDED for further 
  proceedings.Â  
REVERSED and REMANDED.
STILWELL and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Hughes wrote several letters to the Michigan District Court arguing 
    the merits of his defense and asking for procedural guidance.Â  All of the 
    letters were written by Hughes as the president and presiding officer of Seal 
    Jet.Â  There was no intercession by an attorney on behalf of Seal Jet, and 
    ultimately, none of Hughesâ€™ letters was recognized by the Michigan court as 
    a basis for relief.

 
   
    [2]  Seal Jet also argues the circuit court erred by enrolling the Michigan 
    judgment because the Michigan court did not have sufficient evidence to conclude 
    Seal Jet was the same entity as American.Â  This issue involves the merits 
    of the case.Â  Thus, we decline to rule on this issue.Â  See Hamilton 
    v. Patterson, 236 S.C. 487, 492, 115 S.E.2d 68, 70 (1960) (â€œâ€˜[T]he full 
    faith and credit clause of the Constitution precludes any inquiry into the 
    merits of the cause of action, the logic or consistency of the decision, or 
    the validity of the legal principles on which the judgment is based.â€™â€ (quoting 
    Milliken v. Meyer, 311 U.S. 457, 462 (1940))). Â

In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Calvin L. Jeter and Quantilla B. Jeter, Respondents,
v.
The South Carolina Department of Transportation,
Appellant,
v.
Phyllis P. Brown, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3762
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, and Charles V. Verner, of Newberry, for Appellant.
Albert V. Smith, of Spartanburg, and Henry Hammer, Howard 
  Hammer and Arthur K. Aiken, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This is an action under the 
  South Carolina Tort Claims Act. Â The South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (SCDOT) appeals the damages awards to Calvin L. Jeter, Quantilla Jeter, and 
  Phyllis P. Brown, arguing the trial court erred in (1) moving the action to 
  Fairfield County, (2) directing a verdict on the issue of Brownâ€™s negligence, 
  and (3) refusing to charge the defense of unavoidable accident.Â  We affirm in 
  part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Calvin Jeter was operating a motorcycle on Secondary 
  Road 37, also known as Herbert Road, in Union County on July 12, 1997.Â  SCDOT 
  had recently resurfaced a portion of the road and left behind loose gravel.Â  
  Phyllis Brown, Jeterâ€™s sister, was driving her vehicle in the opposite direction 
  when she saw a deer on the side of the road and applied her brakes.Â  Brown 
  lost control of her car, which collided with Jeterâ€™s motorcycle before falling 
  down a ravine. 
Several people who saw the road at or near the 
  time of the accident testified there was enough loose gravel on the road to 
  scoop up handfuls of it.Â  At trial, there was conflicting testimony from 
  eyewitnesses and SCDOT employees regarding whether any signs warning of loose 
  stones were posted at the time of the accident.Â  Brown maintained excess 
  gravel left on the road during the resurfacing caused her car to swerve into 
  Jeterâ€™s lane of travel when she applied her brakes.Â Â  
Jeter and his wife Quantilla filed two complaints 
  against SCDOT in the Union County Court of Common Pleas under the South Carolina 
  Tort Claims Act, alleging SCDOT had failed to maintain the road in a safe condition 
  and to warn travelers on the road that dangerous conditions existed.Â  Contending 
  Brown was a necessary party to the litigation so as to allow for apportionment 
  of fault under section 15-78-100(c) of the Act, [1]  SCDOT filed a third-party complaint in each action naming Brown 
  as a third-party defendant.Â  Brown then filed an answer and counterclaim 
  against SCDOT under the Act for personal injuries she allegedly sustained during 
  the accident.
Brown later settled with the Jeters and 
  then moved under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, to dismiss the third-party complaint 
  filed against her.Â  The trial court ruled that, under Rule 19, SCRCP, 
  Brown was a necessary party to the action â€œsolely for the purposes of satisfying 
  the statutory requirement of section 15-78-100(c), that the trier of fact must 
  apportion liability in a special verdict specifying the proportion of monetary 
  liability of each defendant.â€ 
Brown then filed an amended answer and counterclaim, 
  in which she objected to venue in Union County.Â  Several days later, 
  she moved for a change of venue to Fairfield County based on the fact that she 
  was a resident of that county.Â  Over SCDOTâ€™s objection, the trial court 
  granted the motion and transferred the case to Fairfield County.Â  
During the merits hearing, Brown moved for directed 
  verdicts on the issue of her negligence and SCDOTâ€™s defense of unavoidable accident.Â  
  The Jeters joined in the motions.Â  After hearing arguments from counsel, 
  the trial court granted both motions.Â  Based on the finding that Brown 
  was not negligent as a matter of law, the trial court declined to submit to 
  the jury a special verdict form that would have allowed the jury to apportion 
  fault pursuant to South Carolina Code section 15-78-100(c).
The jury returned verdicts of $1,950,000 for Calvin 
  Jeter, $100,000 for Quantilla Jeter, and $150,000 for Brown.Â  By consent 
  order, the trial court reduced the verdicts in accordance with the statutory 
  caps set forth in the Act. [2] Â  After unsuccessfully moving for a new trial absolute 
  on numerous grounds, SCDOT filed this appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  SCDOT argues the trial court erred in trying 
  the case in Fairfield County instead of Union County.Â  We disagree.
The Jeters brought this action under the South 
  Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  Section 15-78-100(b) of the Act provides that â€œ[j]urisdiction 
  for any action brought under this chapter is in the circuit court and brought 
  in the county in which the act or omission occurred.â€ 
  [3] Â  
SCDOT argues section 15-78-100(b) â€œprovides that 
  only the Circuit Court in the county where the act or omission occurred has 
  subject matter jurisdiction over an action brought pursuant to the Tort Claims 
  Act.â€Â  According to SCDOTâ€™s reasoning, because the accident occurred 
  in Union County, the Union County Court of Common Pleas had exclusive subject 
  matter jurisdiction to hear this action.
We agree, however, with Brown and the Jeters that 
  section 15-78-100(b) addresses the issue of jurisdiction only so far as to confer 
  jurisdiction to hear such cases in the â€œcircuit courtâ€ [4]  while the remaining language in that section, â€œand brought 
  in the county in which the act or omission occurred,â€ addresses the issue of 
  venue. [5] Â  The caption to section 
  15-78-100 reads in pertinent part â€œWhen and where to institute action.â€ 
  [6] Â  Moreover, nothing in part (b) of the statute can be read to require 
  that a case arising under the Act must be â€œheardâ€ or â€œtriedâ€ in â€œthe county 
  in which the act or omission occurred.â€ 
  [7]   
We therefore hold section 15-78-100(b) did not 
  prohibit the trial court from considering Brownâ€™s motion to change venue.Â  Moreover, 
  considering the fact that Brown resided in Fairfield County, we hold the trial 
  court acted within its discretion in granting the motion. [8] Â  Because the action was originally 
  brought in Union County, where the accident occurred, we further hold the requirements 
  of section 15-78-100(b) were satisfied. [9] 
2.Â  We agree, however, with SCDOTâ€™s argument that the 
  trial court erred in directing a verdict in favor of Brown on the issue of her 
  negligence and in not allowing the jury to apportion fault among all potential 
  tortfeasors, including Brown, as provided in South Carolina Code section 15-78-100(c). 
  [10] 
In South Carolina, motorists have a common law duty 
  to keep a reasonable lookout to avoid hazards on the roadway. 
  [11]  Â In addition, motorists are required by statute to adjust their speeds 
  to reasonable and prudent levels considering the â€œactual and potential hazards 
  then existingâ€ [12]  and to drive their vehicles 
  within their lanes of travel. [13] 
  Â  
Several witnesses testified 
  â€œloose stoneâ€ warning signs were in place at the time of the accident.Â  Larry 
  Crocker, a sign foreman for SCDOT, testified he was working in the area the 
  day before the accident and made sure signs warning of loose stones were in 
  place.Â  In addition, Junior Jenkins, who worked on Crockerâ€™s crew, testified 
  â€œthey have to put the signs up before anything hits the highway.â€Â  Finally, 
  Martha Jolly, a resident maintenance foreman for SCDOT, testified (1) the road 
  was resurfaced the day before the accident, (2) she was on the site the day 
  before the accident and saw warning signs erected on the road, and (3) such 
  signs normally stay up a few days after the work is done.Â  Although there 
  was some testimony suggesting the signs were not easily visible when the accident 
  occurred, the evidence to the contrary created a jury question on this 
  issue. [14] Â  A finding by the jury the signs had been in place could have 
  led to the inference that Brown had failed to keep her vehicle under control 
  and adjust her speed to conditions of which she either was or should have been 
  aware.
Similarly, there was evidence the hazards were open 
  and obvious.Â  Dr. Robert B. Roberts, who investigated the scene seventeen days 
  after the accident testified he could observe clearly where the road had been 
  re-surfaced.Â  Dr. Larry Josey, the Jetersâ€™ expert witness, opined a reasonable 
  person could visually recognize the road had been re-surfaced and Brown â€œshould 
  have been able to tell that this is a new piece of roadway.â€Â  In addition, 
  Quantilla Jeter testified she could see where the road construction started 
  when she arrived at the scene.Â  Even if SCDOT had not installed adequate 
  warning signs, then, the jury could have found Brown, in overlooking readily 
  apparent hazards in the roadway, had failed to maintain a proper lookout. [15] 
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to 
  SCDOT, we agree there is more than one reasonable inference regarding whether 
  Brown was at fault in the accident.Â  We therefore hold that, under South Carolina 
  Code section 15-78-100(c), the trial court should have given the jury the opportunity 
  to apportion fault among all tortfeasors, including Brown.
3.Â  It appears from SCDOTâ€™s brief that the question 
  of whether the trial court erred in refusing to charge the defense of unavoidable 
  accident becomes an issue in this appeal only if the directed verdict in favor 
  of Brown is affirmed. [16] Â  
  We have reversed the directed verdict; therefore, we do not reach the issue 
  of whether the trial court should have charged the defense of unavoidable accident. 

AFFIRMED IN PART, AND REVERSED IN PART, AND 
  REMANDED.
ANDERSON, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Section 15-78-100(c) of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act provides 
    that â€œ[i]n all actions brought pursuant to this chapter when an alleged joint 
    tortfeasor is named as party defendant in addition to the governmental entity, 
    the trier of fact must return a special verdict specifying the proportion 
    of monetary liability of each defendant against whom liability is determined.â€Â  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(c) (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [2] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120 (Supp. 2003) (limiting liability 
    â€œ[f]or any action or claim for damages brought underâ€ the South Carolina Tort 
    Claims Act).

 
   
    [3] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(b) (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [4] Â  See S.C. Const. Art. V, Â§ 1 (â€œThe judicial power shall be 
    vested in a unified judicial system, which shall include a Supreme Court, 
    a Court of Appeals, a Circuit Court, and such other courts of uniform jurisdiction 
    as may be provided for by general law.â€).

 
   
    [5] Â  See Ellis v. Oliver, 307 S.C. 365, 367, 415 S.E.2d 
    400, 401 (1992) (citing section 15-78-100(b) for the proposition that under 
    the Tort Claims Act, â€œvenue is proper where the act or omission occurredâ€) 
    (emphasis added).

 
   
    [6] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100 (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [7] Â  See In re Asbestosis Cases, 276 S.C. 579, 581, 281 
    S.E.2d 112, 114 (1981) (â€œâ€˜Venueâ€™ refers to the county where the action should 
    be brought.â€) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [8] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (1976) (stating â€œthe action 
    shall be tried in the county in which the defendant resides at the time of 
    the commencement of the actionâ€); Durant v. Black River Elec. Co-op., 
    271 S.C. 466, 467, 248 S.E.2d 264, 265 (1978) (â€œIt is well settled that motions 
    to change the venue of a trial are addressed to the sound discretion of the 
    trial court.â€); McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 
    334, 479 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œWhere the facts concerning a defendantâ€™s 
    residence are uncontradicted, the trial court must, as a matter of law under 
    Â§ 15-7-30, change venue to the county where the defendant resides.â€).

 
   
    [9] Â  SCDOT further argues that, even under the interpretation of section 
    15-78-100(b) as a venue provision, the trial courtâ€™s decision to transfer 
    venue was error because (1) when the action was commenced, the sole defendant 
    was SCDOT, for whom venue was proper in Union County and (2) Brownâ€™s residence 
    in Fairfield County should not have â€œtrumpedâ€ the Jetersâ€™ original venue choice.Â  
    Although these arguments appear in SCDOTâ€™s new trial motion, there is nothing 
    in the record to indicate that they were expressly raised to the trial court 
    before it issued the order transferring the case to Fairfield County.Â  Because 
    these arguments concern venue rather than subject matter jurisdiction, we 
    are not at liberty to disregard the rule that, unless issues are timely raised 
    to the trial court, we cannot address them on appeal.Â  See Wilder 
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic 
    that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have 
    been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate 
    review.â€).Â  We further note that after venue was changed to Fairfield County, 
    SCDOT unsuccessfully moved for a change of venue and did not appeal the order 
    denying its motion.

 
   
    [10]  This section provides that â€œ[i]n all actions brought pursuant to 
    this chapter when an alleged joint tortfeasor is named as party defendant 
    in addition to the governmental entity, the trier of fact must return a special 
    verdict specifying the proportion of monetary liability of each defendant 
    against whom liability is determined.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(c) (Supp. 
    2003).

 
   [11]  Thomasko v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 12, 561 
    S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002).Â  

 
   
    [12]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-1520 (1991 and Supp. 2003).Â  

 
   
    [13] Â  Id. Â§ 56-5-1810 (1991).

 
   
    [14]  See Brown v. Smalls, 325 S.C. 547, 558, 481 S.E.2d 
    444, 450 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œOrdinarily, the negligence of a party is a question 
    of fact for the jury.â€).

 
   
    [15]  See Brown v. Howell, 284 S.C. 605, 609, 327 S.E.2d 
    659, 661 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding it was proper to deny the plaintiffâ€™s motion 
    for a directed verdict because the jury could reasonably infer that the plaintiff 
    â€œdid not exercise due care for his own safety in that he failed to keep a 
    proper lookout, drove too fast for conditions, violated the laws regulating 
    traffic at a stop intersection, and failed to take evasive actionâ€).Â Â  

 
   
    [16] Â  SCDOTâ€™s brief reads in pertinent part:Â  â€œIf the lower court was 
    correct in directing a verdict and/or striking SCDOTâ€™s defenses that Phyllis 
    Brownâ€™s negligence caused the accident, then clearly the court at the very 
    least erred in refusing to charge the law on unavoidable accident.â€
