THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Frances Adena Fuller, individually and as personal representative of 
        the Estate of Robert Ray Fuller, deceased, Respondent,
v.
Gerald E. Blanchard, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3763
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., George C. Beighley and S. Elizabeth 
  Brosnan, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Charles L. Henshaw, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Frances Adena Fuller (â€œMrs. 
  Fullerâ€) brought wrongful death, survival, and loss of consortium claims against 
  Dr. Gerald E. Blanchard, alleging he committed medical malpractice in negligently 
  failing to advise her husband, Robert (â€œMr. Fullerâ€), of the adverse results 
  of a cancer screening test.Â  Dr. Blanchard moved for summary judgment on his 
  defenses that the action was barred as a matter of law by the exclusive remedy 
  provision of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and because he owed 
  no duty of care to Mr. Fuller.Â  The circuit court granted Mrs. Fullerâ€™s cross-motion 
  for summary judgment on the two defenses, and Dr. Blanchard appeals.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Mr. Fuller worked as a chemical 
  engineer at Westinghouse.Â  In 1996, Westinghouse offered a Prostate Specific 
  Antigen (PSA) test to its male employees as part of the blood work done for 
  their required annual physical examinations.Â  The usual procedure was for the 
  employee to have blood drawn for lab testing and then report to the physician 
  for a physical examination a week to ten days later.Â  At that time, the physician 
  would review the test results, report them to the employee, and give the employee 
  a copy.Â  An abnormal PSA result indicated that the patientâ€™s prostate gland 
  could be diseased and that the patient needed to seek further treatment.Â Â Â  

Pursuant to an agreement between Westinghouse 
  and Doctors Care, Dr. Blanchard, an employee of Doctors Care, performed physical 
  examinations for the employees of Westinghouse and was on site twice a week 
  to perform these services for a total of about four hours each week.Â  Dr. Blanchard 
  and a nurse, who was a full-time Westinghouse employee, received all blood test 
  results and reviewed them before Dr. Blanchard conducted the physical examinations.Â  
  Dr. Blanchardâ€™s established procedure was to report to each employee any abnormal 
  test results, give the employee one copy of the lab work, and recommend that 
  the employee see his family physician.Â  
Westinghouse employees saw Dr. Blanchard 
  only for routine employment physicals or for examination prior to returning 
  to work after surgery or illness.Â  On average, he saw between ten and fifteen 
  employees during each session at Westinghouse.Â  Dr. Blanchard was paid by Doctors 
  Care and did not receive any payment for his services from Westinghouse.Â  
In October 1996, Mr. Fullerâ€™s blood was 
  drawn and sent for lab testing, which included a PSA test.Â  The report showed 
  a 5.0 PSA level.Â  Dr. Blanchard stated that upon seeing a PSA level of 5.0 he 
  routinely would have recommended to the employee that he consult his personal 
  physician.Â  He could not, however, specifically recall whether he informed Mr. 
  Fuller of the elevated PSA level or advised him to see his family physician.Â  
  There was no notation in the medical chart completed by Dr. Blanchard that Mr. 
  Fuller was ever informed of the elevated PSA level.
In August 1997, Mr. Fuller again had a 
  PSA test performed as part of his annual physical at Westinghouse.Â  This time 
  Mr. Fullerâ€™s PSA level was more than double its previous reading.Â  Dr. Blanchard 
  advised Mr. Fuller that he should see his family physician.Â  Mr. Fuller sought 
  further treatment.Â  In September 1997, his urologist diagnosed him with prostate 
  cancer and informed him that his treatment options were limited because of the 
  progression of the cancer.Â  Mr. Fuller died from prostate cancer on November 
  25, 1998.Â  
Mrs. Fuller brought this action against Dr. Blanchard 
  alleging medical negligence in the wrongful death of her husband.Â  Dr. Blanchard 
  answered and asserted as affirmative defenses that the action was barred as 
  a matter of law because (1) the court did not have jurisdiction as the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Act was the exclusive remedy, and (2) he was acting as a company 
  physician and therefore did not have a physician-patient relationship with Mr. 
  Fuller giving rise to a duty of care.Â  Mrs. Fuller and Dr. Blanchard filed cross-motions 
  for summary judgment.Â Â Â  
The circuit court granted summary judgment to Mrs. 
  Fuller on Dr. Blanchardâ€™s two defenses.Â  The court found Dr. Blanchard was an 
  independent contractor, not an employee of Westinghouse, and that Mr. Fullerâ€™s 
  death was not a work-related injury.Â  The court additionally found that Dr. 
  Blanchard owed a duty of care, although limited, to Mr. Fuller.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
Dr. Blanchard first contends the circuit court 
  erred in granting summary judgment to Mrs. Fuller on his defense that he was 
  immune from suit because any medical malpractice claim was barred as a matter 
  of law by the exclusivity provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  We disagree.
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is the exclusive 
  remedy against an employer for an employeeâ€™s work-related accident or injury. 
  [2] Â  The Actâ€™s exclusivity provision provides in relevant part as follows:

The rights and remedies granted by this Title to an employee 
  when he and his employer have accepted the provisions of this Title, respectively, 
  to pay and accept compensation on account of personal injury or death by accident, 
  shall exclude all other rights and remedies of such employee, his personal 
  representative, parents, dependents or next of kin as against his employer, 
  at common law or otherwise, on account of such injury, loss of service or death. [3] 

â€œThe exclusive remedy doctrine was enacted to balance 
  the relative ease with which the employee can recover under the Act:Â  the employee 
  gets swift, sure compensation, and the employer receives immunity from tort 
  actions by the employee.â€ [4] Â Â  

Further, as a general rule, this â€œimmunity is conferred 
  not only on the direct employer, but also on co-employees.â€ 
  [5] Â  Thus, an employee negligently injured by a co-employee conducting 
  the employerâ€™s business may not hold the co-employee personally liable in tort, 
  but must instead rely upon the remedies provided by the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act. [6] Â  
Such immunity does not extend, however, to third-party 
  tortfeasors who injure an employee acting within the course and scope of his 
  employment; in such cases, the employee may file a claim for workersâ€™ compensation 
  benefits for the injury and may also bring an action against the third party.Â  
  Any recovery against the third party, however, is subject to subrogation. [7] Â  
â€œ[I]n general, treating physicians, as third parties 
  to the employer-employee relationship, do not fall within the immunity provisions 
  of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and are subject to suit.â€ 
  [8]   
In the case before us, the circuit court found 
  Dr. Blanchard was not entitled to blanket immunity under the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act because he provided his services to Westinghouse as an independent contractor, 
  not its employee; further, even if Dr. Blanchard were a co-employee, Mr. Fullerâ€™s 
  death from cancer was not work-related.Â  
On appeal, Dr. Blanchard contends the circuit court 
  erred in granting summary judgment to Mrs. Fuller on his defense that her claim 
  was barred by the exclusive remedy provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  
  Dr. Blanchard asserts that he and Mr. Fuller were co-employees and that Mr. 
  Fullerâ€™s death was a work-related injury.Â  
â€œWhether or not an employer-employee relationship 
  exists is aÂ  jurisdictional question.â€ 
  [9] Â  When the issue on appeal involves jurisdiction, we can take our own 
  view of the preponderance of the evidence. 
  [10] Â  
â€œWhether a worker is an employee or independent 
  contractor is a fact-specific matter resolved by applying certain established 
  principles.â€ [11] Â  Our supreme 
  court has stated the general test concerns the extent of the employerâ€™s right 
  of control:

â€œThe general test applied is that of control by the employer.Â  
  It is not the actual control then exercised, but whether there exists the right 
  and authority to control and direct the particular work or undertaking, as to 
  the manner or means of its accomplishment.â€ [12] 

â€œThere are four elements which determine the right 
  of control:Â  1) direct evidence of the right or exercise of control; 2) furnishing 
  of equipment;Â  3) right to fire; and 4) method of payment.â€ 
  [13] 
We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s determination 
  that Dr. Blanchard provided services to Westinghouse not as its employee, but 
  as an independent contractor.Â  As to the evidence of the right of control and 
  the furnishing of equipment, although Westinghouse apparently established Dr. 
  Blanchard would be available on its premises four hours per week and provided 
  a Westinghouse employee to assist as his nurse, the only evidence in the record 
  indicates that Dr. Blanchard scheduled employee visits, conducted a personal 
  review of the test results, and made his recommendations without any direct 
  supervision or instruction from Westinghouse, as such reviews came within the 
  scope of his own professional expertise.Â  Regarding the right to fire and the 
  method of payment, as noted by the circuit court, Dr. Blanchard was not employed 
  directly by Westinghouse; rather, he was on site four hours a week to provide 
  services pursuant to a contractual agreement Westinghouse had with Doctors Care.Â  
  It was undisputed that Dr. Blanchard was not on Westinghouseâ€™s payroll and received 
  no compensation whatsoever from Westinghouse.Â  Rather, he was paid directly 
  by Doctors Care for his professional services.Â  Dr. Blanchard testified he was 
  not involved in negotiating the contract Doctors Care had with Westinghouse 
  and he was unaware of its terms.Â  Finally, there is no evidence in the record 
  that Westinghouse could have fired Dr. Blanchard.Â  
In Garcia v. Iserson, relied upon by Dr. 
  Blanchard, the Court of Appeals of New York held â€œthat the claim of an employee 
  for alleged malpractice [by] a physician whose professional services were made 
  available to the employee at the employerâ€™s expense and on its premises [fell] 
  within the scope of the Workmenâ€™s Compensation Law.â€ [14] Â  In Garcia, a physician 
  provided by the employer, Imperial Paper Box Corp., on the employerâ€™s premises 
  allegedly gave an Imperial employee an injection in a negligent manner.Â  The 
  court explained its reasoning as follows:Â  â€œThere was here a professional service 
  made available by the employer to its employees; the services were not available 
  generally to members of the public; [and the] plaintiff obtained the services 
  not as a member of the public but only in consequence of his employment.â€ [15] Â  The court concluded the plaintiffâ€™s exclusive remedy was 
  workersâ€™ compensation rather than a common-law action for malpractice because 
  the injury arose out of and in the course of the plaintiffâ€™s employment as a 
  result of the alleged negligence of another in the same 
  employ. [16] Â  
We find Garcia distinguishable in a major 
  respect - in Garcia it was undisputed that the physician was a co-employee 
  of the injured worker.Â  The court noted that the doctor was employed by Imperial 
  at a weekly salary to give medical care to its employees, that â€œ[t]he usual 
  payroll deductions were made from the doctorâ€™s salary check and he was covered 
  under Imperialâ€™s medical plan and its workmenâ€™s compensation insurance policy.â€ [17] Â Â Â  
The other cases cited by Dr. Blanchard are also 
  distinguishable on this basis. [18] Â  
Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not 
  err in finding Dr. Blanchard was an independent contractor and not a co-employee 
  of Mr. Fuller; therefore, Mrs. Fullerâ€™s malpractice claim is not barred by the 
  exclusive remedy provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. 
  [19] Â  
II.
Dr. Blanchard additionally asserts the circuit 
  court erred in granting summary judgment to Mrs. Fuller on his defense that 
  he owed no duty of care to Mr. Fuller as a matter of law because there never 
  was a physician-patient relationship.Â  We disagree.
The circuit court ruled Dr. Blanchard â€œowe[d] a 
  duty of care, albeit limited,â€ to Mr. Fuller.Â  The court concluded Mrs. Fuller 
  was â€œentitled to go forward . . . [on] allegations that the defendant failed 
  to timely advise an employee of abnormal medical findings and failed to recommend 
  follow-up with another physician for testing, diagnosis or treatment.â€Â  The 
  court noted that â€œ[t]he parties stipulated that [Mrs. Fuller] will be able to 
  produce expert testimony that the defendant deviated from standard medical care.â€Â  

We find there is evidence to support the circuit 
  courtâ€™s ruling since there was an established protocol, which Dr. Blanchard 
  claimed to follow, which required him to inform employees of any adverse test 
  results and to advise them to seek additional medical treatment as necessary.Â  
  In this case, irrespective of Dr. Blanchardâ€™s status as either a company doctor 
  or an independent contractor, Dr. Blanchard failed to inform Mr. Fuller of the 
  adverse results of a prostate cancer screening test and to advise him to seek 
  follow-up care from another physician.Â  Due to this omission, Mr. Fullerâ€™s PSA 
  level had doubled by the time the test was again performed, and Mr. Fuller died 
  from prostate cancer.Â  
We note that, ordinarily, â€œ[t]he existence of a 
  physician-patient relationship is a question of fact for the jury.â€ 
  [20] Â  Dr. Blanchard does not contend that questions of fact remain in this 
  case, so we do not consider that point here.Â  Rather, Dr. Blanchardâ€™s only contention 
  is that, based on the facts of this case as they are, the court committed an 
  error of law in granting summary judgment to Mrs. Fuller; he maintains his defense 
  should have prevailed.Â  Consequently, we find no basis on which to disturb the 
  courtâ€™s ruling. [21] 
AFFIRMED. 
CURETON, A.J., concurs.Â  KITTREDGE, J., concurs in a separate 
  opinion.
KITTREDGE, J.:Â  I concur.Â  However, I write 
  separately to express my concern with the jurisdiction of this court to entertain 
  this appeal.Â  In my judgment, Appellantâ€™s challenge on appeal is limited to 
  the circuit courtâ€™s failure to grant him summary judgment. [22] Â  The refusal to grant summary judgment 
  is not appealable.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, 354 S.C. 161, 
  580 S.E.2d 440 (2003); Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 443 S.E.2d 379 
  (1994).
Pursuant to cross-motions for summary 
  judgment, the circuit court granted Respondentâ€™sÂ  motion.Â  On appeal, Appellant 
  claims error solely on the basis that the underlying action was barred as a 
  matter of law by the exclusive remedy provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act and because he owed no duty of care to Respondentâ€™s husband.Â  It is significant 
  to note that these issues, as recognized by the majority, are predominantly 
  fact-driven.Â  See Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 
  564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002) (â€œWhether a worker is an employee or independent 
  contractor is a fact-specific matter resolved by applying certain established 
  principles.â€); Tumblin v. Ball-Incon Glass Packaging Corp.,Â  324 S.C. 
  359, 365, 478 S.E.2d 81, 85 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œThe existence of a physician-patient 
  relationship is a question of fact for the jury.â€).Â  The final brief and reply 
  brief of Appellant make no claim that there exists a genuine issue as to any 
  material fact.Â  As the majority correctly concludes, Appellant â€œdoes not contend 
  that questions of fact remain in this case.â€Â  In reaching the merits of this 
  appeal, the majority is essentially rehearing the cross-motions for summary 
  judgment.Â  I believe we have neither the authority to reconsider the denial 
  of Appellantâ€™s summary judgment motion nor the authority to grant him judgment 
  as a matter of law on the fact-specific issues presented. 
Thus, the issue as presented 
  by Appellant is the functional equivalent of an appeal of the refusal to grant 
  summary judgment.Â  I would decline to address the merits and dismiss the appeal.Â  


 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  Strickland v. Galloway, 348 S.C. 644, 560 S.E.2d 448 (Ct. 
    App. 2002).

 
   
    [3] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-540 (1985) (emphasis added).

 
    
 [4] Â  Strickland, 
    348 S.C. at 646-47, 560 S.E.2d at 449.

 
    
 [5] Â  Id. at 647, 
    560 S.E.2d at 449; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-5-10 (1985) (â€œEvery 
    employer who accepts the compensation provisions of this Title shall secure 
    the payment of compensation to his employees . . . .Â  While such security 
    remains in force he or those conducting his business shall only be 
    liable to any employee . . . to the extent and in the manner specified in 
    this Title.â€ (emphasis added)).

 
    
 [6] Â  Strickland, 
    348 S.C. at 647, 560 S.E.2d at 449.

 
    
 [7]  Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560 (1985) 
    (providing for remedies to be obtained from third parties). 

 
   [8] Â  Tatum v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 
    346 S.C. 194, 202, 552 S.E.2d 18, 22 (2001).

 
   
    [9] Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 
    112 (2002).Â  For additional background information, see 6 Arthur Larson & 
    Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 112.02(1) to (4) 
    (2003).

 
   [10]  Nelson, 349 S.C. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 
    112.

 
    
 [11]  Id.

 
   
    [12]  Id. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 112-13 (quoting Young v. Warr, 
    252 S.C. 179, 189, 165 S.E.2d 797, 802 (1969)).

 
    
 [13]  Id. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 113.

 
   [14]  309 N.E.2d 420, 421 (N.Y. 1974).

 
   [15]  Id.  

 
    
 [16]  Id. at 422.

 
   [17]  Id. at 421.

 
    
 [18]  See, e.g., Scott v. Wolf Creek 
    Nuclear Operating Corp., 928 P.2d 109, 112 (Kan. Ct. App. 1996) (finding, 
    in a case where an employee was allegedly negligently treated for a heart 
    attack by a physician who worked for Wolf Creek, that there was a causal connection 
    between his employment and his negligent medical treatment; the court stated:Â  
    â€œScott received treatment because he was an employee of Wolf Creek.Â  The physicianâ€™s 
    assistants who treated Scott were employees of Wolf Creek whose purpose was 
    to provide medical treatment to Wolf Creek employees for both occupational 
    and nonoccupational diseases and injuries.Â  In other words, Scott would not 
    have been equally exposed to the risk of negligent medical treatment by Wolf 
    Creek physicianâ€™s assistants apart from his employment at Wolf Creek.â€); Marange 
    v. Slivinski, 684 N.Y.S.2d 199, 200 (App. Div. 1999) (holding the fellow-employee 
    rule of the workersâ€™ compensation exclusive remedy provision served to bar 
    a plaintiffâ€™s malpractice action against a company physician, who was employed 
    as a corporate medical director, for his alleged negligent failure to diagnose 
    cancer in the plaintiffâ€™s wife, it being undisputed that the wife and the 
    physician â€œwere co-employees . . . at all times relevant to this actionâ€); 
    Franke v. Durkee, 413 N.W.2d 667, 669 (Wis. Ct. App. 1987) (finding 
    workersâ€™ compensation was the exclusive remedy for the alleged negligence 
    of an employerâ€™s in-house medical staff in a malpractice action brought by 
    the surviving spouse of an employee against a company doctor for his negligent 
    failure to diagnose the employeeâ€™s nonwork-related lung tumor; the court noted 
    the surviving spouse had conceded that her husband and the physician in question 
    were co-employees).

 
   
    [19]  Having affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s determination on this point, 
    we need not address Dr. Blanchardâ€™s additional argument that the circuit court 
    erred in also finding this was not a work-related incident.Â  Even assuming 
    the incident was work-related, as an independent contractor, Dr. Blanchard 
    would still be subject to suit because he would simply be treated as a third-party 
    tortfeasor.

 
   [20]  Tumblin v. Ball-Incon Glass 
    Packaging Corp., 324 S.C. 359, 365, 478 S.E.2d 81, 85 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
    In Tumblin we observed that a physician who has been retained by a 
    third party to conduct an examination normally is not subject to a malpractice 
    claim by the individual examined unless the physician offered or intended 
    to treat, care for, or otherwise benefit the individual or injured the individual 
    in the course of the examination.Â  Id. at 365-66, 478 S.E.2d at 85.Â  
    In the current appeal, Dr. Blanchard did not perform the screening tests merely 
    for the benefit of Westinghouse, the employer.Â  Rather, Dr. Blanchard acknowledged 
    that his practice was to inform the Westinghouse employees of any adverse 
    results from the cancer-screening tests and to advise them of the need to 
    seek further evaluation when necessary.Â  We believe this constitutes a benefit 
    to the employee and care that would fall within the exceptions delineated 
    in Tumblin.Â  
  We note that in Tumblin, we held that 
    a physician fulfilled any responsibility he had to an employee by informing 
    her of an elevated blood pressure reading and suggesting that she follow up 
    with her private doctor.Â  Id. at 367, 478 S.E.2d at 86.Â  In contrast, 
    in the case before us Dr. Blanchard allegedly failed to inform Mr. Fuller 
    of the adverse results of a cancer-screening test and to advise him to seek 
    further treatment as necessary.Â  

 
    
 [21] This case concerned 
    cross-motions for summary judgment regarding two of Dr. Blanchardâ€™s defenses; 
    the circuit court simultaneously granted Mrs. Fullerâ€™s motion for summary 
    judgment and denied Dr. Blanchardâ€™s motion.Â  On appeal, the parties have blurred 
    the distinction between the two motions.Â  Because the granting of a 
    motion for summary judgment is appealable while the denial of a motion 
    for summary judgment is not, we are addressing Dr. Blanchardâ€™s arguments to 
    the extent he appears to challenge the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment 
    to Mrs. Fuller as an error of law based on the facts of the case, although, 
    as stated, there has been an overlapping of these issues due to the procedural 
    posture of the case.Â  To the extent Dr. Blanchard appears to argue the court 
    should have granted his motion for summary judgment, the denial of summary 
    judgment is not properly before us and we do not address it.Â  See Silverman 
    v. Campbell, 326 S.C. 208, 486 S.E.2d 1 (1997) (reiterating that the denial 
    of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable, even after final judgment); 
    Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 443 S.E.2d 379 (1994) (stating the 
    denial of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable).Â  Neither party 
    makes this distinction in the briefs and Mrs. Fuller does not assert that 
    Dr. Blanchard is only arguing about the denial of his own motion for summary 
    judgment, so we have addressed the issues in the manner outlined above.

 
   
    [22]  This is not an appeal from a merits hearing.Â  The appeal comes to 
    us in the posture of a grant of summary judgment.Â  While Appellantâ€™s final 
    brief and reply brief purport to appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s grant of 
    summary judgment in favor of Respondent, his argument is focused solely on 
    the lower courtâ€™s failure to grant him judgment as a matter of law.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Louie D. Hawkins, individually and d/b/a Servicemaster of Greenville, 
        Servicemaster of Greenville, LLC, and Dixie P. Hawkins, Appellants,
v.
City of Greenville, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3764
Submitted February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  March 22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert C. Childs, III, of Greenville, for Appellants.
W. Howard Boyd, Jr., Luanne L. Runge and Fred W. Suggs, III, all of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

 ANDERSON, J.:Â  Louie D. 
  Hawkins brought this action, claiming the city of Greenville (â€œCityâ€) improperly 
  and negligently designed and maintained its municipal drainage system in the 
  area where his business was located.Â  He alleged the Cityâ€™s malfeasance caused 
  his property to flood after a rainstorm in 1997.Â  The trial court granted summary 
  judgment in favor of the City on all of Hawkinsâ€™ claims.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS/ PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On July 24, 1997, Hawkinsâ€™ business, Servicemaster 
  of Greenville, was flooded during a heavy rainfall, causing substantial damage 
  to the business and surrounding property.Â  Hawkins blamed the City for the damage, 
  arguing the flooding was caused by the Cityâ€™s neglect in designing and maintaining 
  its stormwater drainage system.Â  Accordingly, he brought the present action 
  asserting various causes of action stemming from the Cityâ€™s alleged acts and 
  failures to act.
I.Â  The Servicemaster Property and 
  Surrounding Drainage System
The Servicemaster property is located in a low-lying 
  area on the east side of Greenville.Â  This part of Greenville has been heavily 
  developed with retail businesses and other large commercial developments.
The immediate area surrounding the Servicemaster 
  property forms a 3.24-square-mile stormwater basin.Â  Rainwater falling into 
  the basin drains downhill into nearby Laurel Creek.Â  Over the years, the City 
  and private developers made several improvements to the drainage system in the 
  basin.Â  When Hawkins moved Servicemaster to its Haywood Road location, drainage 
  around the property was handled primarily by two ninety-six-inch pipes installed 
  in Laurel Creek to expand the creekâ€™s ability to effectively handle runoff in 
  the area.Â  After a severe storm in 1991 caused flooding in the area, the City 
  installed an additional large, elliptical arched pipe in Laurel Creek to further 
  increase the creekâ€™s stormwater capacity.Â  In early July 1997, the City installed 
  â€œriprapâ€ along the banks of the creek to stem erosion that had occurred. 
  [2] 
II.Â  The 1991 Flood, Lawsuit and 
  Settlement
A heavy rainstorm in July 1991 caused 
  the Servicemaster property and surrounding area to flood.Â  The Servicemaster 
  property suffered substantial damage when the excess runoff flooded into the 
  building, bringing mud and other debris.Â  As in the present case, Hawkins brought 
  suit against the City, claiming its actions caused the flooding.Â  Hawkins specifically 
  alleged the City was negligent â€œin failing to designâ€ and â€œmaintain a reasonably 
  adequate surface water drainage systemâ€ and â€œin failing to properly supervise 
  the surface water drainage system to ensure adequate flow of water during periods 
  of inc[l]ement weather.â€
The case was settled in 1994.Â  The City 
  paid Hawkins $4,000 in exchange for a â€œfull, complete and final release of all 
  damages arising out of the design, construction, maintenance, and operation 
  of the water drainage system on or adjacent to Bryland [sic] Drive.â€Â  This release 
  was executed in March 1994.Â  It provides:

[Servicemaster] does hereby release, 
  relieve and forever acquit the City of Greenville, South Carolina, a municipal 
  corporation, their agents, employees, officers, successors, and assigns from 
  any and all liability arising out of or in any way connected with the water 
  and mud damage to [Hawkinsâ€™] place of business located at 1 Byrdland Drive which 
  occurred on or about July 30, 1991 and it is the intention in executing this 
  Release to forever discharge the City of Greenville from any and all claims, 
  demands, actions or causes of action which may exist, known or unknown, of any 
  and all damages, past, present and future, in any way connected with or arising 
  out of the aforesaid damages.
. . . .
It is acknowledged and understood 
  that this is a full, complete and final release of all damages arising out of 
  the design, construction, maintenance, and operation of the water drainage system 
  on or adjacent to Bryland [sic] Drive, that no future or further payments will 
  be paid as a result thereof and that the persons and corporations in whose favor 
  this Release runs are herewith fully finally and forever discharged from any 
  and all liability with respect to the aforementioned property. 

III.Â  The 1997 Flood and the Present 
  ActionÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
On July 24, 1997, a record amount of rain fell 
  in and around Greenville in a short period of time. [3] Â  Stormwater draining into Laurel 
  Creek overwhelmed the creekâ€™s capacity, causing water to flood onto the Servicemaster 
  property and several nearby businesses.
In July 1999, Hawkins brought the present action 
  against the City, alleging causes of action for: (1) inverse condemnation, (2) 
  negligence in the Cityâ€™s design and maintenance of its stormwater drainage system, 
  (3) violation of South Carolina Code section 5-31-450, (4) trespass, (5) conversion, 
  and (6) nuisance.Â  Finding no genuine issue of material fact with respect to 
  any of these claims, the trial court granted the Cityâ€™s motion for summary judgment.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court should grant a motion for summary 
  judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; accord Trivelas v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 130, 558 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct. App. 
  2001); Wells v. City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 301, 501 S.E.2d 746, 
  749 (Ct. App. 1998); see also Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 
  S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997) (â€œSummary judgment is proper where 
  there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law.â€).Â  
â€œThe party seeking summary judgment has the burden 
  of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.â€Â  McNair 
  v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 342, 499 S.E.2d 488, 493 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing 
  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 (1991); 
  Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 301 S.C. 
  418, 392 S.E.2d 460 (1990)).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of 
  fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Lanham 
  v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 361-62, 
  563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002) (citing Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 
  492 S.E.2d 55 (1997)); accord Strother v. Lexington County Recreation 
  Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  â€œSummary judgment 
  is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable 
  to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Lanham, 349 S.C. at 362, 563 
  S.E.2d at 333 (citing Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 
  534 S.E.2d 688 (2000)).Â  
â€œAll ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising 
  from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party.â€Â  
  Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (citing Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 
  413 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œEven when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, 
  but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary 
  judgment should be denied.â€Â  Id. at 173-74, 561 S.E.2d at 656.Â  â€œBecause 
  it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked so no 
  person will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.â€Â  
  Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 138, 542 S.E.2d 743, 747 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (citing Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 523 S.E.2d 795 (1999)).Â Â  

In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court: Summary 
  judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and 
  that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP; accord Baughman, 306 S.C. at 114-15, 410 S.E.2d at 545; 
  Murray, 344 S.C. at 138, 542 S.E.2d at 747 (citing Brockbank, 
  341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688; Wells, 331 S.C. at 301, 501 S.E.2d at 749). 

LAW/ANALYSIS
Hawkins contends genuine issues of fact 
  exist for each of his claims that should have compelled the trial court to deny 
  the Cityâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Inverse Condemnation
Hawkins first argues the trial court erred 
  in granting summary judgment to the City on his inverse condemnation claim, 
  contending he was deprived of his full rights to the Servicemaster property 
  without just compensation as a result of the Cityâ€™s design and maintenance of 
  the drainage system.Â  We disagree.
An action for inverse condemnation is appropriate where 
  the government takes private property for public use.Â  Quality Towing Inc. 
  v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 29, 38, 530 S.E.2d 369, 373 (2000).Â  Inverse 
  condemnation is a cause of action against a governmental defendant to recover 
  the value of property which has been taken in fact by the governmental defendant, 
  even though no formal exercise of the power of eminent domain has been attempted 
  by the taking agency.Â  Horry County v. Ins. Reserve Fund, 344 S.C. 493, 
  498, 544 S.E.2d 637, 640 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  While the typical taking occurs when 
  the government acts to condemn property in the exercise of its power of eminent 
  domain, the entire doctrine of inverse condemnation is predicated on the proposition 
  that a taking may occur without such formal proceedings.Â  Horry County, 
  344 S.C. at 498, 544 S.E.2d at 640.Â  â€œThe term â€˜inverse condemnationâ€™ describes 
  an action grounded, not on statutory condemnation power, but on the constitutional 
  proscription against the taking or damaging of property for public use without 
  just compensation.â€Â  Vicks v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 347 S.C. 
  470, 480, 556 S.E.2d 693, 698 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œOne basic difference between 
  condemnation and inverse condemnation is that in condemnation proceedings, the 
  governmental entity is the moving party, whereas, in inverse condemnation, the 
  property owner is the moving party.â€Â  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t 
  v. Moody, 267 S.C. 130, 136, 226 S.E.2d 423, 425 (1976) (quoting 27 Am.Jur.2d 
  Eminent Domain Â§ 829 (1996)).Â  The action is not based on tort, but on 
  the constitutional prohibition of the taking of property without compensation.Â  
  Horry County, 344 S.C. at 498, 544 S.E.2d at 640.
An inverse condemnation occurs when a 
  government agency commits a taking of private property without exercising its 
  formal powers of eminent domain.Â  To establish an inverse condemnation, a plaintiff 
  must show: â€œ(1) an affirmative, positive, aggressive act on the part of the 
  governmental agency; (2) a taking; (3) the taking is for a public use; and (4) 
  the taking has some degree of permanence.â€ Marietta Garage, Inc. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 352 S.C. 95, 101, 572 S.E.2d 306, 308 (Ct. 
  App. 2002); Gray v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 
  311 S.C. 144, 149, 427 S.E.2d 899, 902 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
In the present case, Hawkins has failed 
  to allege any affirmative acts by the City which damaged the Servicemaster property 
  or otherwise diminished his rights in the property.Â  Most of the Cityâ€™s â€œactsâ€ 
  he avers support his inverse condemnation claim are merely failures to act. 
  Â Specifically, Hawkins asserts the City improperly allowed the development of 
  neighboring parcels of commercial property which altered the elevation of the 
  area and added strain to the Laurel Creek drainage pipes beyond their capacity 
  and then failed to replace these pipes.Â  The South Carolina cases addressing 
  inverse condemnation are uniform in requiring that the claim be proved by â€œaffirmative, 
  positive, aggressiveâ€ acts by the governmental agency. Allegations of mere failure 
  to act are insufficient.Â  See, e.g., Berryâ€™s On Main, Inc. v. City 
  of Columbia, 277 S.C. 14, 16, 281 S.E.2d 796, 797 (1981) (holding that proof 
  of inverse condemnation requires that â€œthere must be an affirmative, positive, 
  aggressive act on the part of the governmental agencyâ€); Gray v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 311 S.C. 144, 149, 427 S.E.2d 899, 
  902 (Ct. App. 1993) (listing as an element of inverse condemnation the requirement 
  that there be â€œan affirmative, positive, aggressive act on the part of the governmental 
  agencyâ€).
The only affirmative acts Hawkins cites as forming 
  the basis of his inverse condemnation claim are the replacement of the double-box 
  culvert with the large arched pipe in Laurel Creek in 1994 and the installation 
  of the riprap material along the banks of the creek in 1997.Â  The record contains 
  no evidence that either of these acts caused the flooding of the Servicemaster 
  property in 1997.Â  Hawkinsâ€™ own expert testified that the installation of the 
  large arched pipe likely improved the drainage situation in the stormwater basin.Â  
  Regarding the effect of the riprap material on drainage in the Laurel Creek 
  basin, experts for both the City and Hawkins either offered no opinion on the 
  impact of the riprap or opined that it was impossible to determine whether installing 
  the riprap negatively or positively affected drainage.
Based on the lack of any evidence showing an affirmative, 
  positive, aggressive act on the part of the City which would tend to prove the 
  Cityâ€™s actions caused or precipitated the flooding of the Servicemaster property, 
  we are compelled to affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on Hawkinsâ€™ 
  inverse condemnation claim.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Negligence
Hawkins argues the trial court erred in 
  finding his negligence claim against the City was barred under the South Carolina 
  Tort Claims Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 to 15-78-200 (Supp. 2003).Â  We 
  disagree.
The Tort Claims Act governs all tort claims 
  against governmental entities.Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 203, 
  584 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  It is the exclusive civil remedy available 
  for any tort committed by a governmental entity or its employees or agents.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann Â§ 15-78-70(b) (Supp. 2003); Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, 
  Inc., 344 S.C. 194, 215, 544 S.E.2d 38, 49 (Ct. App. 2001); Wells v. 
  City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 302, 501 S.E.2d 746, 749 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
  The Tort Claims Act provides that the State, its agencies, political subdivisions, 
  and other governmental entities are â€œliable for their torts in the same manner 
  and to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances,â€ subject 
  to certain limitations and exemptions provided in the Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  15-78-40 (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œGovernmental entityâ€ is defined by the act as â€œthe 
  State and its political subdivisions.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-30(d) (Supp. 
  2002); Flateau, 355 S.C. at 204, 584 S.E.2d at 416.Â  The provisions of 
  the Act establishing limitations on and exemptions to the liability of the State, 
  its political subdivisions, and employees, while acting within the scope of 
  official duty, must be liberally construed in favor of limiting liability of 
  the State.Â  S.C. Code Ann Â§ 15-78-20(f) (Supp. 2003); Steinke v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 396, 520 S.E.2d 142, 
  154 (1999); Arthurs v. Aiken County, 338 S.C. 253, 270, 525 S.E.2d 542, 
  551 (Ct. App. 1999); Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 331 S.C. 192, 205, 
  500 S.E.2d 160, 167 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The governmental entity asserting the 
  Act as an affirmative defense bears the burden of establishing a limitation 
  upon liability or an exception to the waiver of immunity.Â  Strange v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 430, 445 S.E.2d 
  439, 440 (1994); Steinke, 336 S.C. at 393, 520 S.E.2d at 152; Arthurs, 
  338 S.C. at 270, 525 S.E.2d at 551.Â  The Act does not create a new substantive 
  cause of action against a governmental entity.Â  Moore v. Florence Sch. Dist. 
  No. 1, 314 S.C. 335, 339, 444 S.E.2d 498, 500 (1994); Bayle v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 121, 542 S.E.2d 736, 739 (Ct. App. 
  2001).Â  The Plaintiff must present evidence of the governmental entityâ€™s duty 
  to act in order to recover under the Act.Â  Arthurs, 338 S.C. at 270, 
  525 S.E.2d at 551.Â  The Tort Claims Act expressly preserves all existing common 
  law immunities.Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 277, 246, 553 S.E.2d 496, 
  507 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The Tort Claims Act is a limited waiver of governmental 
  immunity.Â  Arthurs, 338 S.C. at 270, 525 S.E.2d at 551.Â  Section 15-78-60 
  sets out thirty-seven â€œexceptionsâ€ to this waiver of sovereign immunity.Â  These 
  exceptions significantly limit the tort liability of government entities.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Several of these exceptions bear directly upon 
  the alleged acts and failures to act by the City with respect to the municipal 
  drainage system.Â  Specifically, under section 15-78-60, the City is not liable 
  for a loss resulting from: (1) â€œlegislative, judicial, or quasi-judicial action 
  or inactionâ€; (2) â€œadministrative action or inaction of a legislative, judicial, 
  or quasi-judicial natureâ€; (3) â€œadoption, enforcement, or compliance with any 
  law or failure to adopt or enforce any law, whether valid or invalid, including, 
  but not limited to, any charter, provision, ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation, 
  or written policiesâ€; (4) â€œthe exercise of discretion or judgment by the governmental 
  entity or employee or the performance or failure to perform any act or service 
  which is in the discretion or judgment of the governmental entity or employeeâ€; 
  or (5) â€œregulatory inspection powers or functions, including failure to make 
  an inspection, or making an inadequate or negligent inspection, of any property 
  to determine whether the property complies with or violates any law, regulation, 
  code, or ordinance or contains a hazard to health or safety.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 15-78-60 (1), (2), (4), (5), and (13) (Supp. 2003).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
For each of these specific provisions, 
  the determination of immunity from tort liability turns on the question of whether 
  the acts in question were discretionary rather than ministerial.Â  A finding 
  of immunity under the Act â€œis contingent on proof the government entity, faced 
  with alternatives, actually weighed competing considerations and made a conscious 
  choice using accepted professional standards.â€ Wooten ex rel. Wooten v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 333 S.C. 464, 468, 511 S.E.2d 355, 357 (1999).Â  
  â€œThe governmental entity bears the burden of establishing discretionary immunity 
  as an affirmative defense.â€Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 
  S.C. 416, 428, 567 S.E.2d 231, 237 (2002).
Although our courts have not applied the 
  Tort Claims Act to facts similar to those of the present case, the Supreme Court 
  of Texas has held that municipalities are not liable for the design and planning 
  of their sewage and drainage systems because these acts are considered quasi-judicial, 
  discretionary functions for which a government entity is not liable.Â  City 
  of Tyler v. Likes, 962 S.W.2d 489, 501 (Tex. 1997).Â  The court in City 
  of Tyler opined:

The duties of the municipal authorities 
  in adopting a general plan of drainage, and determining when and where sewers 
  shall be built, of what size and at what level, are of a quasi judicial nature, 
  involving the exercise of deliberate judgment and large discretion, and depending 
  upon considerations affecting the public health and general convenience throughout 
  an extensive territory; and the exercise of such judgment and discretion in 
  the selection and adoption of a general plan or system of drainage is not subject 
  to revision by a court or jury in a private action for not sufficiently draining 
  a particular lot of land.

Id.Â  We find a comparable degree of discretion 
  was granted to the City in the present case to exercise the measured policy 
  judgments required to build and maintain an adequate municipal sewer and drainage 
  system in Greenville. Accordingly, the City is immune from liability for negligence 
  claims arising out of the design and maintenance of the drainage system in the 
  Laurel Creek Basin.
III.Â Â Â  Liability Under South Carolina Code Section 
  5-31-450
Hawkins next appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of 
  summary judgment as to his claim under South Carolina Code section 5-31-450.Â  
  We find no error with the trial courtâ€™s ruling.
Section 5-31-450 mandates: 

Whenever, within the boundaries 
  of any municipality, it shall be necessary or desirable to carry off the surface 
  water from any street, alley or other public thoroughfare along such thoroughfare 
  rather than over private lands adjacent to or adjoining such thoroughfare, such 
  municipality shall, upon demand from the owner of such private lands, provide 
  sufficient drainage for such water through open or covered drains, except when 
  the formation of the street renders it impracticable, along or under such streets, 
  alleys or other thoroughfare in such manner as to prevent the passage of such 
  water over such private lands or property.Â  But if such drains cannot be had 
  along or under such streets, alleys or other thoroughfare, the municipal authorities 
  may obtain, under proper proceedings for condemnation on payment of damages 
  to the landowner, a right of way through the lands of such landowner for the 
  necessary drains for such drainage.Â  If any municipal corporation in this State 
  shall fail or refuse to carry out the provisions of this section, any person 
  injured thereby may have and maintain an action against such municipality for 
  the actual damages sustained by such person.

Applying this statute, our courts have 
  held that liability does not obtain under section 5-31-450 absent some affirmative 
  act by the municipality which alters the course or increases the amount of stormwater 
  runoff onto private property.Â  See Brown v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville 
  County, 251 S.C. 220, 225, 161 S.E.2d 815, 817 (1968) (holding that unless 
  the landowner pleads and proves an overt act against the municipality proximately 
  causing the damages complained of, there is no cause of action under the statute).Â  
  â€œThe statute does not purport to make the municipality an insurer of the landowner 
  against damage from surface water; it is only for such damage as results from 
  the municipalityâ€™s works that he may recover.Â  By the same token, a municipality 
  may not absolve itself from liability by diverting the surface water from its 
  streets into a natural watercourse too small to carry it off.â€Â  Hall v. City 
  of Greenville, 227 S.C. 375, 386, 88 S.E.2d 246, 251 (1955).Â  â€œThe statute 
  does not make the municipality an insurer of the landowner against damage from 
  surface water; it is only for such damage as results from the municipalityâ€™s 
  works that he may recover.Â  Therefore, unless the landowner pleads and proves 
  an overt act against the municipality proximately causing the damages complained 
  of, there is no cause of action under the statute.â€Â  Taleff v. City of Greer, 
  284 S.C. 510, 512, 327 S.E.2d 363, 364 (Ct. App. 1985) (citations omitted).Â  
  â€œUnder this statute proof of negligence, in the usual sense of the word, in 
  the design or construction of the drainage facilities installed by a municipality 
  for the purpose of carrying off surface water along a street or other public 
  thoroughfare is not an essential ingredient of the cause of action in favor 
  of an adjacent landowner whose property has been damaged by surface water cast 
  upon it as the result of such construction.â€Â  Hall, 277 S.C. at 386, 
  88 S.E.2d at 251.Â  This section apodictically contemplates positive action by 
  a municipality to render it liable for damages.Â  Brown, 251 S.C. at 225, 
  161 S.E.2d at 817.
Hawkins failed to offer proof of any affirmative, 
  positive acts which would tend to show the actions of the City caused the flooding 
  of the Servicemaster property.Â  We approve the trial courtâ€™s finding that Hawkinsâ€™ 
  claim under section 5-31-450 fails.
IV.Â Â Â  Trespass
Hawkins appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant 
  of summary judgment as to his claim for trespass against real property.Â  We 
  find no error with the trial courtâ€™s ruling.
â€œ[T]respass is any intentional invasion 
  of the plaintiffâ€™s interest in the exclusive possession of his property . . 
  . .â€Â  Hedgepath v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 356, 559 S.E.2d 
  327, 337 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Silvester v. Spring Valley Country Club, 
  344 S.C. 280, 286, 543 S.E.2d 563, 566 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. denied 
  (citing Ravan v. Greenville County, 315 S.C. 447, 434 S.E.2d 296 (Ct. 
  App. 1993))).Â  â€œTo constitute actionable trespass, however, there must be an 
  affirmative act, invasion of land must be intentional, and harm caused must 
  be the direct result of that invasion.â€Â  Snow v. City of Columbia, 305 
  S.C. 544, 553, 409 S.E.2d 797, 802 (Ct. App. 1991); accord Mack v. 
  Edens, 320 S.C. 236, 240, 464 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The gist 
  of trespass is the injury to possession, and generally either actual or constructive 
  possession is sufficient to maintain an action for trespass.Â  Macedonia Baptist 
  Church v. City of Columbia, 195 S.C. 59, 71, 10 S.E.2d 350, 355 (1940).
For a trespass action to lie, â€œthe act must be 
  affirmative, the invasion of the land must be intentional, and the harm caused 
  by the invasion of the land must be the direct result of that invasion.â€Â  Mack 
  v. Edens, 320 S.C. 236, 240, 464 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Hawkins 
  argues the same acts that he claims warrant a finding of inverse condemnation 
  also compel a finding of civil trespass.Â  Hawkins did not offer proof that any 
  action by the City caused the flooding of the Servicemaster property.
Having failed to show any affirmative 
  and intentional act necessary to sustain an action for trespass, we hold the 
  trial court properly granted summary judgment.
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Conversion
Hawkins next argues the trial court erred 
  in granting summary judgment on his claim for conversion.Â  We disagree.
â€œConversion is the unauthorized assumption 
  and exercise of the right of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging 
  to another, to the alteration of the condition or the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s 
  rights.â€Â  Crane v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 313 S.C. 70, 73, 437 
  S.E.2d 50, 52 (1993).Â  â€œConversion may arise by some illegal use or misuse, 
  or by illegal detention of anotherâ€™s personal property.â€Â  Regions Bank v. 
  Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 667, 582 S.E.2d 432, 442 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Conversion 
  is a wrongful act which emanates by either a wrongful taking or wrongful detention.Â  
  Id.Â  It is well settled that a conversion action does not lie when alleging 
  the exercise of dominion or control over real property.Â  See 18 Am. Jur. 
  2d Conversion Â§ 7 (1998) (commenting that â€œan action for conversion ordinarily 
  lies only for personal property which is tangible, or at least represented by 
  or connected with something tangibleâ€ andÂ  â€œwill not lie for such indefinite, 
  intangible, and incorporeal species of property as a . . . leasehold estate 
  or interestâ€).Â  Therefore, to the extent Hawkinsâ€™ conversion claim pertains 
  to the actions of the City with respect to real property, the claim clearly 
  fails as a matter of law.Â  Additionally, Hawkins provided no evidence that the 
  City seized, disposed, denied use, or wrongfully took control of any goods or 
  personal chattels belonging to him or his business.
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to 
  grant summary judgment on Hawkinsâ€™ conversion claim.
CONCLUSION
Finding no genuine issue of material fact 
  with respect to any of Hawkinsâ€™ causes of action, we conclude summary judgment 
  in favor of the City was proper.Â  The judgment of the trial court is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J. and BEATTY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  â€œRiprapâ€ is an industry term for piles of loose stone or angular 
    boulders built seaward of the shoreline to prevent erosion by waves or currents. 
  

 
   
    [3]  Testimony was offered at the summary judgment hearing that the National 
    Climatic Data Center recorded that 2.51 inches fell in Greenville during a 
    one-hour period on July 24, 1997.

title: InMed v. MedQuest
description: This is a cross-appeal from a jury verdict arising from an unfair trade practices dispute between two competing providers of magnetic resonance imaging services.  The primary issue in the disposition of this appeal is whether the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act can be applied to purchases of medical equipment under the South Carolina Certificate of Need and Health Facility Licensure Act.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
InMed Diagnostic Services, L.L.C., Respondent-Appellant,
v.
MedQuest Associates, Inc., Palmetto Imaging, Inc., and Open MRI of Florence, 
        Inc.,  Appellants-Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3765
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., S. Elizabeth Brosnan, M. Elizabeth 
  Crum and Robert W. Dibble, Jr., all of Columbia, for Appellant-Respondent.
Hamilton Osborne, Jr. and James Y. Becker, of Columbia, for 
  Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This appeal arises out of 
  a dispute among competing providers of magnetic resonance imaging (â€œMRIâ€) services.Â  
  MedQuest Associates, Inc., Palmetto Imaging, Inc., and Open MRI of Florence, 
  Inc. (collectively â€œMedQuestâ€) appeal a jury verdict in favor of InMed Diagnostic 
  Services, L.L.C. (â€œInMedâ€) under the Unfair Trade Practices Act (â€œUTPAâ€).Â  InMed 
  cross-appeals, arguing error in the award of attorney fees and the trial courtâ€™s 
  refusal to award treble damages.Â  We reverse the jury verdict.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The State Certification of Need and Health Facility 
  Licensure Act (â€œCON Actâ€) [1]  
  governs the acquisition and use of medical equipment such as MRI machines in 
  South Carolina.Â  Under the CON Act, a medical provider must obtain a certificate 
  of need (â€œCONâ€) from the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental 
  Control (â€œDHECâ€) before undertaking â€œthe acquisition of medical equipment which 
  is to be used for diagnosis or treatment if the total project cost is in excessâ€ 
  of $600,000. [2] Â  If the total 
  project cost in a given situation falls below the $600,000 threshold, the provider 
  may seek a determination from DHEC that the CON Act does not apply. [3] Â  A determination of this kind 
  is known as a non-applicability determination (â€œNADâ€).Â  The application 
  and review process to obtain a CON is more detailed and time-consuming than 
  that to obtain a NAD.
DHEC regulations define â€œtotal project costâ€ as 
  â€œthe estimated total capital cost of a project including land cost, construction, 
  fixed and moveable equipment, architectâ€™s fee, financing cost, and other capital 
  costs properly charged under generally accepted accounting princip[les] as a 
  capital cost.â€ [4] Â  Under 
  generally accepted accounting principles, assets are recorded at historical 
  or invoice cost when they are acquired.
MedQuest, formed in 1994, operates six facilities 
  in South Carolina that provide outpatient diagnostic imaging services, including 
  MRI services.Â  In 1998, MedQuest began negotiating with Siemens, a supplier 
  of MRI machines, for the purchase of new MRI machines. 
  [5] Â  Siemens and MedQuest reached an agreement providing that, as 
  MedQuest bought machines from Siemens, Siemens would give a major discount on 
  every third purchase.Â  MedQuest used two of these heavily discounted 
  purchases for its facilities in Columbia and Florence, South Carolina, and applied 
  to DHEC for a NAD for these acquisitions. 
  [6] Â  DHEC approved MedQuestâ€™s applications in early 1999. 
InMed, a competing provider of outpatient diagnostic 
  imaging services, was formed in 1998, when its founder, Robert Adams, purchased 
  the assets of Image Trust, an MRI provider in Florence and Columbia that had 
  ceased operations.Â  Adams subsequently purchased replacement MRI machines 
  for both locations and obtained a NAD for the Florence acquisition.
Both InMed and MedQuest challenged each otherâ€™s 
  NAD for their Florence locations.Â  InMed asserted that MedQuest substantially 
  understated the cost of its MRI equipment in its application to DHEC for a NAD.Â  
  MedQuest asserted that InMed should have included a trade-in allowance for used 
  equipment in the total cost of the project.Â  The appeals went before 
  the Administrative Law Judge Division (â€œALJDâ€); however, they were subsequently 
  dismissed by agreement between the parties.
Several months later, InMed commenced the present 
  action by filing a complaint in the Richland County Circuit Court.Â  In 
  its amended complaint, InMed alleged that the individual defendants â€œcombined 
  and conspired with each other to provide false and fictitious information to 
  DHEC concerning MedQuestâ€™s MRI equipment costs for its facilities in Columbia 
  and Florence.â€Â  The complaint also alleged unfair trade practices, common 
  law unfair competition, interference with prospective contractual relations, 
  and civil conspiracy.
Â MedQuest answered InMedâ€™s complaint, alleging 
  several affirmative defenses, including (1) that exclusive jurisdiction lay 
  with the ALJD, (2) that InMed had failed to exhaust its administrative remedies, 
  and (3) that InMedâ€™s cause of action under the UTPA should be dismissed because 
  MedQuestâ€™s conduct was controlled by the CON Act and thus was not subject to 
  liability under the Act.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In a form order dated December 6, 2001, and again 
  in a formal order dated February 20, 2002, the circuit court granted summary 
  judgment as to all causes of action against Siemens.Â  The circuit court 
  also granted summary judgment in favor of MedQuest as to the civil conspiracy 
  and interference with prospective contractual relations claims; however, summary 
  judgment was denied as to the UTPA and common law unfair competition claims. 

InMedâ€™s remaining two claims were then tried to 
  a jury from December 10-13, 2001.Â  During the course of the trial, InMed 
  dropped the common law unfair competition claim, and only the UTPA claim went 
  to the jury.Â  The jury returned a verdict for InMed, awarding $2,107,898 
  in damages.
On December 19, 2001, MedQuest moved for judgment 
  notwithstanding the verdict, or in the alternative, for a new trial.Â  The 
  next day, InMed moved for treble damages and attorney fees.Â  In a form 
  order dated January 10, 2002, the circuit court denied both motions, noting 
  further that attorney fees would be set following a hearing on the matter.Â  
  On February 4 and 6, 2002, MedQuest and InMed, respectively, appealed the denial 
  of their motions.
On March 28, 2002, the circuit court heard InMedâ€™s 
  motion for attorney fees.Â  By form order dated May 2, 2002, the circuit 
  court awarded InMed $100,000 in attorney fees.Â  InMed filed a motion 
  to alter or amend this ruling, which was denied by form order on May 20, 2002.Â  
  InMed appealed this ruling on May 29, 2002, and MedQuest likewise appealed 
  the order awarding attorney fees.Â  
On appeal, MedQuest argues the UTPA is inapplicable 
  to InMedâ€™s lawsuit because the purchase of medical equipment is specifically 
  regulated by DHEC.Â  MedQuest also argues that InMedâ€™s abandonment of 
  its appeal before the ALJD barred it from seeking relief in the circuit court.Â  
  Finally, MedQuest contends that, even assuming its actions were subject 
  to the UTPA, there was no evidence of a UTPA violation.
In its cross-appeal, InMed argues that the circuit 
  court erred by refusing to award treble damages on its cause of action for unfair 
  trade practices.Â  InMed further asks that the attorney fees award of 
  $100,000 be vacated and the matter remanded to the circuit court for appropriate 
  findings as required by the controlling case law. 
LAW/ANALYSIS         
MedQuest first argues the UTPA is inapplicable 
  to this case because medical equipment purchases are â€œactions or transactions 
  permitted under laws administered by any regulatory body or officer acting under 
  statutory authority of this state . . . or actions or transactions permitted 
  by any other South Carolina law,â€ which are specifically excluded under section 
  39-5-40(a). [7] Â  We agree.
The exemption provided in section 39-5-40(a) 
  was first interpreted in State ex rel. McLeod v. Rhoades. [8] Â  In Rhoades, the supreme court reversed 
  the overruling of a demurrer to a complaint of â€œâ€˜unfair and deceptive acts or 
  practicesâ€™ in connection with the public offering and saleâ€ of securities. [9] Â  Holding securities transactions fell within the exemption 
  provided by section 39-5-40, the supreme court adopted what has come to be known 
  as the â€œgeneral activityâ€ test and stated:Â  â€œInitially the burden is on the 
  party seeking the exemption to demonstrate its applicability.Â  Once the exemption 
  is demonstrated, the complainant must then show that the specific act in question 
  did not come within the exemption.â€ [10] Â  
Several years later, however, in Ward 
  v. Dick Dyer & Associates, the supreme court determined the general 
  activity test â€œwould not fulfill the intent of the Legislature in prohibiting 
  unfair trade practicesâ€ [11]  
  and adopted the reasoning in a decision of a Tennessee appellate court, which 
  explained the purposes of a similar exemption as follows:

The purpose of the exemption is to insure that a business 
  is not subjected to a lawsuit under the Act when it does something required 
  by law, or does something that would otherwise be a violation of the Act, but 
  which is allowed under other statutes or regulations.Â  It is intended to avoid 
  conflict between laws, not to exclude from the Actâ€™s coverage every activity 
  that is authorized or regulated by another statute or agency.Â  Virtually every 
  activity is regulated to some degree.Â  The defendantâ€™s interpretation of the 
  exemption would deprive consumers of a meaningful remedy in many situations. [12] 

In the present case, InMed argues the 
  UTPA exemption should not apply to MedQuestâ€™s actions because â€œ[t]he CON Act 
  does not allow the provision of deceptive information to DHEC in order to evade 
  the requirements of the CON Act.â€Â  We agree, however, with MedQuest that 
  this is an unduly narrow interpretation of the law.Â  Whether MedQuest submitted 
  accurate information in support of its NAD applications was necessarily for 
  DHEC to determine as part of the administrative process in deciding whether 
  or not to grant such applications.
The stated purpose of the CON Act is â€œto promote 
  cost containment, prevent unnecessary duplication of health care facilities 
  and services, guide the establishment of health facilities and services which 
  will best serve public needs, and ensure that high quality services are provided 
  in health facilities in [South Carolina].â€ [13] Â  To these ends, the Act designates DHEC as â€œthe sole 
  state agency for control and administration of the granting of Certificates 
  of Need and licensure of health facilitiesâ€ 
  [14]  and expressly requires â€œsubstantive and procedural regulations . . 
  . to carry out [DHECâ€™s] licensure and Certificate of Need duties . . . , including 
  regulations to deal with competing applications.â€  [15] 
In carrying out the legislative purpose of the 
  CON Act, DHEC has adopted Regulation 61-15, entitled â€œCertification of Need 
  for Health Facilities and Services.â€ 
  [16] Â  This regulation includes specific procedures for requesting exemptions 
  from the CON requirements. [17] 
  Â  The stated purpose of Regulation 61-15 is virtually identical to the stated 
  purpose of the CON Act. [18]  
 

We agree with MedQuest that the regulatory exemption 
  in section 39-5-40(a) is based on the concept that the legislature has determined 
  certain matters are appropriate for resolution by administrative agencies with 
  particular expertise, rather than by the general jurisdiction of a trial court. [19] Â  This concept is consistent 
  with the supreme courtâ€™s reasoning in Ward that the exemption â€œis intended 
  to exclude those actions or transactions which are . . . authorized by regulatory 
  agencies . . . .â€ [20] Â  
Ward concerned the 
  failure of an automobile dealership to inform the plaintiffs that a car it sold 
  to them had been involved in an accident. [21] Â  In that case, the dealership argued the 
  activity in question was regulated by Title 56 of the South Carolina Code, which 
  (1) requires automobile dealers to be licensed by the South Carolina Department 
  of Highways and Public Transportation; (2) subjects dealers who fail to secure 
  a license to criminal liability; (3) provides for denial, suspension, or revocation 
  of dealer licenses in certain cases; (4) declares certain unfair methods of 
  competition and unfair or deceptive acts or practices to be unlawful; and (5) 
  allows for a private right of action for certain violations. 
  [22] Â  Nowhere, however, as far as we can tell, is there any reference in 
  the opinion or in the record to any statute or regulation governing the transaction 
  that formed the basis for the complaint, i.e., the sale of the car.Â  Moreover, 
  the supreme court did not base its holding on the argument that there was no 
  law allowing or authorizing the specific misconduct the defendant was alleged 
  to have committed. [23] 
In contrast, the specific transaction at issue 
  in the present controversy is MedQuestâ€™s application for a NAD, a process for 
  which DHEC has formulated exacting procedural requirements.Â  Whether or not 
  MedQuest followed these procedures correctly is uniquely within the competency 
  of DHEC, whose involvement in the application process could continue beyond 
  granting the approval should it ever become apparent that a violation of the 
  CON Act occurred. [24] Â  To allow a jury in the court of common pleas 
  to make the determination that MedQuest had submitted misleading information 
  in support of its application for a NADâ€”especially after InMed declined to pursue 
  its administrative appeal of DHECâ€™s approval of the applicationâ€”would undermine 
  the purpose of the exemption in section 39-5-40(a), even as that section has 
  been narrowly interpreted in Ward, of â€œexclud[ing] those actions or transactions 
  which are allowed or authorized by regulatory agencies or other statutes.â€ [25] 
We therefore hold the circuit court erred in declining 
  to hold that, as a matter of law, the regulatory exemption of section 39-5-40 
  of the UTPA applies to this lawsuit and bars InMedâ€™s UTPA claim.Â  Because our 
  determination of this issue controls the case, we need not address MedQuestâ€™s 
  remaining arguments or InMedâ€™s cross-appeal concerning treble damages and attorney 
  fees.  [26] 
 REVERSED.
STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-7-110 to -370 (2002).Â  

 
   
    [2] Â  Id. Â§ 44-7-160(6); 24A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 61-15 Â§ 102(f) 
    (Supp. 2003).Â  

 
   
    [3] Â  See 24A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 61-15 Â§ 102.3 (Supp. 2003) (â€œWhen 
    any question exists, a potential applicant shall forward a letter requesting 
    a formal determination by [DHEC] as to the applicability of the certificate 
    of need requirements to a particular project.â€).Â  

 
   
    [4] Â  Id. Â§ 103.25.Â  

 
   
    [5]  Siemens was also originally named as a defendant, but was granted 
    summary judgment and dismissed from the action.Â  InMed has challenged 
    this ruling in a separate appeal.Â 

 
   
    [6]  The purchase prices presented to DHEC for the two machines at issue 
    in this dispute were $365,000 for the Florence location and $395,000 for the 
    Columbia facility. 

 
   
    [7] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-40(a) (1985).

 
   
    [8] Â  275 S.C. 104, 267 S.E.2d 539 (1980).Â  

 
   [9] Â  Id. at 105, 267 S.E.2d at 540.

 
   [10]  Id. at 107, 267 S.E.2d 
    at 541.

 
   
    [11]  Ward v. Dick Dyer & Assocs., 304 S.C. 152, 155, 403 S.E.2d 
    310, 312 (1991).

 
   [12]  Id. at 156, 403 S.E.2d 
    at 312 (quoting Skinner v. Steele, 730 S.W.2d 335, 337 (Tenn. Ct. App. 
    1987)).Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [13]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-120 (2003).

 
   
    [14]  Id. Â§ 44-7-140 (emphasis added).

 
   [15]  Id. Â§ 44-7-150(3).

 
   
    [16]  24A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. Â§ 61-15 (Supp. 2003). 

 
   
    [17]  Id. Â§ 104.

 
   
    [18]  Id. Â§ 101.Â  

 
   
    [19]  See, e.g., Unisys Corp. v. South Carolina Budget and Control 
    Bd., 346 S.C. 158, 176, 551 S.E.2d 263, 273 (2001) (holding transactions 
    under the Consolidated Procurement Code are exempt from the UTPA); South 
    Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control v. Armstrong, 293 S.C. 209, 
    215-16, 359 S.E.2d 302, 305 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThe evaluation of the adequacy 
    of a sewage disposal system is uniquely within the competency of DHEC, not 
    the courts. . . . By interfering with DHECâ€™s final decision on Armstrongâ€™s 
    application, the trial judge deprived the department of its opportunity to 
    exercise the discretion granted it by the General Assembly.â€); United Merchants 
    and Mfrs., Inc. v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 208 F.2d 685, 687 (4th 
    Cir. 1953) (holding that the proper remedy for the plaintiff in an action 
    alleging the defendant had improperly induced it to withdraw opposition to 
    a rate increase was an application to the South Carolina Public Service Commission 
    for revision of rates followed by an appeal from any adverse decision to the 
    South Carolina state court and that an action in the federal district court 
    for fraud was â€œan attempt to by-pass the Commission, which should not be permittedâ€).Â Â Â 

 
   
    [20]  Ward, 304 S.C. at 155, 403 S.E.2d at 312.Â  

 
   [21]  Id. at 154, 403 S.E.2d at 311.Â  

 
   
    [22]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 56-15-10 through -360 (1991 & Supp. 
    2003).Â  The references to Dick Dyerâ€™s arguments are taken from the Respondentâ€™s 
    Brief for Dick Dyer & Associates at 6-7, Ward v. Dick Dyer & Assocs., 
    304 S.C. 152, 403 S.E.2d 310 (1991).Â Â  

 
   
    [23]  Cf. Smith v. Globe Life Ins. Co., 597 N.W.2d 28, 38 
    (Mich. 1999) (â€œ[W]e conclude that the relevant inquiry is not whether the 
    specific misconduct alleged by the plaintiffs is â€˜specifically authorized.â€™Â  
    Rather, it is whether the general transaction is specifically authorized by 
    law, regardless of whether the specific misconduct alleged is prohibited.â€).

 
   
    [24]  Anyone â€œundertaking any activity requiring certificate of need reviewâ€ 
    without approval from DHEC is subject to penalty as provided by South Carolina 
    Code sections 44-7-320 through -340.Â  24A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. Â§ 61-15.702.Â  
    Sections 44-7-320 through -340 authorize DHEC to deny, suspend, or revoke 
    licenses; to institute lawsuits for violations of the CON Act; and to subject 
    persons or facilities violating the Act to criminal liability. S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§Â§ 44-7-320 through -340 (2002).

 
   [25]  Ward, 304 S.C. at 155, 403 S.E.2d at 
    312.

 
   [26]  See Futch v. McAllister 
    Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) 
    (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination 
    of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).Â
