THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cheryl Howard Craig, Appellant,
v.
William Rhett Craig, III, Respondent.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Greenville County
Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3766
Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jean Perrin Derrick, of Lexington, and Stuart G. Anderson, 
  Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
T. Preston Reid, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  The family court granted 
  Cheryl Howard Craig (Wife) and William Rhett Craig, III (Husband) a divorce 
  and divided the marital property.Â  The court set alimony and child support, 
  ordered the marital home be sold and the equity evenly distributed, granted 
  Wife a special equity interest in several nonmarital properties, and awarded 
  Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The parties were married in 1974, while Husband 
  was in medical school.Â  Soon thereafter, Husband commenced his service commitment 
  to the United States Army and the couple was stationed in Alaska.Â  They returned 
  to Charleston, where Husband finished his medical residency.Â  The parties later 
  moved to Greenville, where they continue to reside.Â  Husband and Wife have three 
  children.Â  At the time of the divorce, the oldest child lived at home as a result 
  of injuries suffered in a childhood bicycle accident.Â  The second child completed 
  college, but was residing at home while searching for employment.Â  The youngest 
  child was a junior in high school and also lived at the marital residence. 
Wife has a Masters Degree in nursing and has been 
  employed as a critical care nurse.Â  She has been fully employed for several 
  years, though she worked part-time during a portion of the marriage.Â  She earns 
  approximately $60,000.00 per year.Â  Husband is a partner in a medical group 
  and specializes in internal medicine.Â  While his income declined when his group 
  separated, his income at the time of the hearing was approximately $200,000.00 
  per year.
The parties had significant marital property, 
  including a house valued over $500,000.00 with equity of over $260,000.00, significant 
  personal property, Husbandâ€™s retirement account valued over $1.8 million, and 
  savings and investment accounts.Â  Husband had several nonmarital properties, 
  which he inherited from his father.Â  However, marital funds were used for some 
  improvements on the property after the inheritance. 
Wife filed this action for divorce and 
  sought custody of the youngest child, division of the marital property, alimony, 
  child support, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband sought joint custody and admitted 
  his responsibility to pay child support.Â  Further, he sought equitable distribution 
  of the property, including the marital residence.
By consent at a temporary hearing, Wife 
  received sole custody of the minor child and retained use of the marital residence.Â  
  Husband agreed to pay child support in the amount of $900.00 per month and the 
  mortgage on the residence of $3,425.00 per month.Â  Wife was allowed to withdraw 
  $20,000.00 to defray costs of litigation and other expenses.
Husband admitted adultery prior to separation, 
  and this was the basis for the divorce.Â  The court concluded alimony of $500.00 
  per month was warranted.Â  Wife was permitted to remain in the marital home until 
  the youngest son graduated from high school.Â  Until that time, she received 
  $850.00 in transitional alimony.Â  Once the son graduated, the marital home was 
  to be sold and the equity divided evenly between the parties.
The court found nonmarital assets owned 
  by Husband were not transmuted into marital property, but that Wife was entitled 
  to a special equity in the property.Â  The court concluded marital funds were 
  used for improvements and awarded Wife a special equity of $8,036.78.
The court further divided the remaining 
  marital property equally.Â  Wife was given the furniture, two retirement accounts, 
  a savings account, and her vehicle.Â  Husband was awarded some furniture, several 
  accounts, his vehicle, and the boat.Â  Husbandâ€™s retirement account was divided 
  such that the ultimate distribution was equal.
After considering the fault of Husband 
  in the divorce, as well as the other appropriate factors, the court concluded 
  Wife was entitled to a contribution towards her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
  She was awarded a total of $21,370.00, with Husband receiving credit for half 
  of the $20,000.00 that Wife was allowed to withdraw from an account pursuant 
  to the temporary order.
Wife filed a motion to alter or amend 
  the courtâ€™s judgment, pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  The court determined the 
  personal property was properly valued for purposes of equitable distribution.Â  
  The requirement that the marital home was to be sold was reaffirmed; however, 
  the judge extended the time until the sale was required.Â  Finally, the last 
  major amendment was to the amount of alimony.Â  The transitional alimony was 
  set at $3,000.00 per month and was to be applied to the mortgage and expenses 
  of the marital home.Â  It was set to continue until December 2003 when the marital 
  home was to be offered for sale.Â  At that time, the periodic alimony was ordered 
  decreased to $875.00 per month.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this Court has the 
  authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 
  157, 160 (1992); Oâ€™Neill v. Oâ€™Neill, 293 S.C. 112, 359 S.E.2d 68 (Ct. 
  App. 1987).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this Court 
  to disregard the factual findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither are we required to ignore 
  the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better 
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their 
  testimony.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
        
         Did the trial court err in failing to award sufficient 
  permanent periodic alimony?
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in failing to award Wife 
  ownership of the marital residence instead of requiring its sale?
      
      
        III.   
         Did the trial court err in failing to award Wife 
  a sufficient special equity interest in Husbandâ€™s nonmarital property?
      
      
        IV.  
         Did the trial court err in failing to properly value 
  the personal property for inclusion in the equitable distribution?
      
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony
Wife maintains the trial court erred in 
  awarding transitional alimony and not awarding a greater amount of permanent 
  periodic alimony given the financial status of the parties and the lifestyle 
  to which Wife was accustomed.Â  We agree.Â  Luculently, the dissolution of the 
  marriage in this case resulted from the fault of the Husband.Â  The Husband committed 
  adultery pre-separation of the Husband and Wife.Â  The adultery committed by 
  the Husband destroyed this marital relationship.Â  Indubitably, the Husband is 
  at fault.
An award of alimony rests within the sound discretion 
  of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002); 
  Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 79, 535 S.E.2d 913, 917 (2000); Hatfield 
  v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 364, 489 S.E.2d 212, 215 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œAlimony 
  is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  
  Spence v. Spence, 260 S.C. 526, 197 S.E.2d 683 (1973); McNaughton 
  v. McNaughton, 258 S.C. 554, 189 S.E.2d 820 (1972); Johnson v. Johnson, 
  296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œGenerally, alimony 
  should place the supported spouse, as nearly as is practical, in the same position 
  he or she enjoyed during the marriage.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 
  184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001); accord Hickum v. Hickum, 
  320 S.C. 97, 463 S.E.2d 321 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œIt is the duty of the family 
  court to make an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just if the claim 
  is well founded.â€ Allen, 347 S.C. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424 (citing Woodward 
  v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 217, 363 S.E.2d 413, 417 (Ct. App. 1987)).Â  The 
  family court judge may grant alimony in an amount and for a term as the judge 
  considers appropriate under the circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) 
  (Supp. 2003); accord Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 462, 486 S.E.2d 
  516, 523 (Ct. App. 1997).
Factors to be considered in making an 
  alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage;Â  (2) physical and emotional 
  health of the parties;Â  (3) educational background of the parties;Â  (4) employment 
  history and earning potential of the parties;Â  (5) standard of living established 
  during the marriage;Â  (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the 
  parties;Â  (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties;Â  (8) 
  marital and nonmarital properties of the parties;Â  (9) custody of children;Â  
  (10) marital misconduct or fault;Â  (11) tax consequences;Â  and (12) prior support 
  obligations;Â  as well as (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2003); Hatfield, 327 S.C. at 364, 489 
  S.E.2d at 215.Â Â  The court is required to consider all relevant factors in determining 
  alimony.Â  Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 415, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886 
  (Ct. App. 1994); see also Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 290, 555 
  S.E.2d 386, 391 (2001) (finding the trial courtâ€™s denial of alimony was erroneous 
  because the court did not address â€œseveral important factorsâ€ when determining 
  no alimony should be awarded).Â  No one factor is dispositive.Â  Lide v. Lide, 
  277 S.C. 155, 157, 283 S.E.2d 832, 833 (1981).Â  â€œFault is an appropriate factor 
  for consideration in determining alimony in cases where the misconduct affected 
  the economic circumstances of the parties or contributed to the breakup of the 
  marriage.â€Â  Smith, 327 S.C. at 463, 486 S.E.2d at 523-24.
South Carolina law requires the court 
  to award support sufficient to allow Appellant to maintain the standard of living 
  the parties had themselves chosen and lived by during their marriage.Â  The standard 
  of living established during this marriage was very high.Â  The parties lived 
  in one of the most influential neighborhoods in Greenville; vacationed at the 
  Husbandâ€™s family lake house, which is in a gated community; enjoyed recreating 
  on their boat; and drove luxury automobiles.
â€œAlthough rehabilitative alimony may be 
  an appropriate form of spousal support in some cases, permanent periodic alimony 
  is favored in South Carolina.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 95, 
  545 S.E.2d 531, 535 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œRehabilitative alimony may be awarded 
  only upon a showing of special circumstances justifying a departure from the 
  normal preference for permanent periodic support.Â  The purpose of rehabilitative 
  alimony is to encourage a dependent spouse to become self-supporting after a 
  divorce.â€Â  Id. (citing Johnson, 296 S.C. at 301, 372 S.E.2d at 
  114.).
In this case, the court concluded that 
  Wife should receive $875.00 in permanent periodic alimony.Â  We reject the finding 
  by the trial court on permanent periodic alimony.Â  His ruling completely overlooks 
  the standard of living in place at the time of the separation of the parties.Â  
  We award the Wife $3000 per month of permanent periodic alimony.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Equitable Distribution
Wife contends the trial court erred in 
  distributing the marital property. First, she maintains the court assigned an 
  incorrect valuation to the personal property, which was awarded to her.Â  Second, 
  she asserts the family court should have awarded her sole possession of the 
  marital home instead of requiring it to be sold or her to purchase Husbandâ€™s 
  share.
The apportionment of marital property is within 
  the discretion of the family court judge and will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Morris v. Morris, 295 S.C. 
  37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 
  2002) provides the family court must consider fifteen factors and give each 
  weight as it determines.Â  On review, this court looks to the fairness of the 
  overall apportionment, and if the end result is equitable, the fact that this 
  court might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court 
  is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 
  107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988); Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 
  859 (Ct. App. 1996) (the reviewing court will affirm the family court judgeâ€™s 
  apportionment of marital property if it can be determined that the judge addressed 
  the relevant factors under section 20-7-472 with sufficiency for the reviewing 
  court to conclude the judge was cognizant of the statutory factors).
In this case, the overall distribution was fifty 
  percent of the estate to each party.Â  We find, given the statutory factors, 
  that this distribution is fair and equitable. Â Given the length of the marriage, 
  the value of the marital property, and the incomes of the parties, we find the 
  trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding an even distribution of 
  the marital property.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Personal Property Valuation
Wife argues the family court erred in 
  its valuation of the personal property it awarded to her.Â  She maintains the 
  value assigned was much greater than the fair market value and does not have 
  a proper basis in the record.Â  We agree the family court erred in the value 
  assigned to the property.
In dividing marital property, the family 
  court must identify both real and personal property and determine the fair market 
  value of the identified property.Â Â  Perry v. Estate of Perry, 323 S.C. 
  232, 237, 473 S.E.2d 860, 863 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The value given personal property 
  should be its fair market value.Â  Id. at 238, 473 S.E.2d at 864.
The trial court found the value of the 
  personal property in Wifeâ€™s possession to be $185,743.00.Â  The trial court took 
  the value of the personal property off the Wifeâ€™s declaration of property and 
  then subtracted the value assigned to the furnishings in Husbandâ€™s possession.Â  
  However, the court did not adjust for the values of various bank accounts and 
  other items also included in the delineation by Wife.Â  The $195,000.00 figure 
  offered by Wife clearly includes items such as vehicles and multiple savings 
  and investment accounts, as these are not delineated separately on the declaration 
  form.Â  Additionally, Wife submitted a more detailed valuation of the property, 
  which totaled $70,789.00.Â  Finally, Husbandâ€™s estimated valuation of the personal 
  property totaled only $62,000.00. 
We find the family court failed to make 
  the proper adjustments in valuing the personal property assigned to Wife.Â  The 
  value is not the fair market value, as the figure used included items not awarded 
  to Wife as part of the personal property.Â  The only figures before the court 
  that valued only the personal property were the $70,789.00 offered by Wife and 
  the $62,000.00 offered by Husband.Â  
We remand to the court for a determination of an 
  accurate value of the personal property awarded to Wife.Â  Additionally, the 
  family court is instructed to maintain the fifty percent award for each party 
  by making the necessary adjustments to the distribution.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Marital Residence
Wife contends the family court erred in 
  not awarding her the marital residence and instead requiring her to buy out 
  Husbandâ€™s share or sell the home.
In order to effect an equitable apportionment, 
  the family court may require the sale of marital property and a division of 
  the proceeds.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 384 S.E.2d 741 (1989); 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-476 (Supp. 2002) (providing that â€œ[t]he court in making 
  an equitable apportionment may order the public or private sale of all or any 
  portion of the marital property upon terms it determinesâ€).Â  The court, however, 
  should first attempt an â€œin-kindâ€ distribution of the marital assets.Â  Donahue, 
  299 S.C. at 360, 384 S.E.2d at 745; Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 
  412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988).Â  A family court may grant a spouse title to the 
  marital home as part of the equitable distribution.Â  Donahue, 299 S.C. 
  at 360, 384 S.E.2d at 745.Â  Pursuant to section 20-7-472(10) of the South Carolina 
  Code, the court, in making apportionment, â€œmust give weight in such proportion 
  as it finds appropriate to all of the following factors: . . . (10) the desirability 
  of awarding the family home as part of equitable distribution.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 20-7-472(10) (Supp. 2003).
Section 20-7-472 lists fifteen factors 
  for the family court to consider when making an equitable apportionment of the 
  marital estate.Â  Bowers, 349 S.C. at 97, 561 S.E.2d at 616.Â  The statute 
  vests the family court with the discretion to decide what weight should be assigned 
  to the various factors.Â  Id.Â  On review, this court looks to the overall 
  fairness of the apportionment, and if the result is equitable, that this court 
  might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  
  Id.
The family court is to â€œcarefully consider the 
  claim of a party that the interests of that party or the children are so predominant, 
  when balanced against the interests of the other, that an award of exclusive 
  possession of the marital home is compelled.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 285 
  S.C. 308, 311, 329 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 1985).
It is not equitable for the home to be 
  sold and Wife required to move from the marital home.Â  Based on our review of 
  the evidence, we conclude the assets should be divided in-kind as follows:

  
    
      
        HUSBAND:
        
      
      
        Health Source
        $15,000.00
      
      
        Timberwoods
            
          8,000.00
      
      
        IRA-SolomonÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

        Prudential life cash value Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
          
          13,468.00
      
      
        Regions (Bank account 2)Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

In awarding the marital home to the Wife in the equitable 
  distribution as outlined above, we rule that the Wife must pay the mortgage 
  payment on the marital home.
III.Â Â Â  Special Equity
Wife contends the family court failed 
  to award her a sufficient special equity in the nonmarital property inherited 
  by Husband.Â  She asserts the valuation of her work and the amount of marital 
  funds used to improve the property were greater than that calculated by the 
  trial court.
South Carolina Code section 20-7-473(5) 
  allows a special equity for the increase in value of nonmarital property resulting 
  from the material contribution of the nonowner spouse.Â  The spouse is entitled 
  to a special interest to compensate for the contributions made to the nonmarital 
  property and for the marital funds used in the improvement of the nonmarital 
  property.Â  See Murray v. Murray, 312 S.C. 154, 159, 439 S.E.2d 
  312, 316 (Ct. App. 1993).
The trial court in this case only considered 
  the monetary contributions from marital funds.Â  He made no allowance for Wifeâ€™s 
  contributions through her efforts or for any overall increase in the value of 
  the property.Â  If Wifeâ€™s contributions increased the value of the property or 
  if she put forth sufficient effort to result in a material contribution, this 
  needed to be considered by the family court.Â  We remand this issue to the trial 
  court to properly consider the full extent of Wifeâ€™s contributions, the full 
  amount of marital funds employed, and any increase in the value of the property 
  resulting directly from the contributions of Wife.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the amount of alimony provided 
  by the family court was not sufficient and equitable.Â  We conclude the overall 
  apportionment of property at fifty percent to each party was appropriate.Â  The 
  trial court did err in requiring the sale of the marital home.Â  We rule the 
  family court erred in its valuation of the special equity to be awarded Wife, 
  as it only considered the exact dollar amounts contributed and did not also 
  take into consideration any work done by Wife or the increase in the valuation 
  of the property as a result of Wifeâ€™s contributions.Â  We conclude the valuation 
  of the personal property was in error.Â  We hold the family court shall maintain 
  the same fifty-percent equitable distributions, but must make such changes as 
  necessary to the apportionment to adjust for changes in the valuation of the 
  personal property consistent with this opinion.Â  Accordingly, the decision of 
  the family court is 
AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, and REMANDED.
HUFF, J., concurs.
CURETON, J., concurs and dissents in a separate 
  opinion.
CURETON, AJ (Concurring and dissenting in part): 
  I disagree with the majority on the issues of the amount of alimony and 
  the award to Wife of exclusive ownership of the marital home. I treat these 
  issues together because they are so closely intertwined. 
The apportionment of marital property is within 
  the family court judgeâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 97, 
  561 S.E.2d 610, 616 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2002) 
  lists fifteen factors for the family court to consider when making an equitable 
  apportionment of the marital estate and vests the family court with the discretion 
  to determine what weight should be assigned to each factor.Â  On review, this 
  court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment, and if the result 
  is equitable, taken as a whole, that this court might have weighed specific 
  factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 
  296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The right of spouses to realize the benefits of 
  equity in a marital home has always been guarded in this state.Â  As the majority 
  correctly points out, the family court is to â€œcarefully consider the claim of 
  a party that the interests of that party or the children are so predominant, 
  when balanced against the interests of the other, that an award of exclusive 
  possession of the marital home is compelled.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 285 
  S.C. 308, 311, 329 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The rationale for scrutinizing 
  such requests lies in the substantial burden upon the party who must defer realization 
  of the value of his or her share of the marital home.Â  Morris v. Morris, 
  335 S.C. 525, 534, 517 S.E.2d 720, 725 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
Some, but not all, of the compelling interests the court 
  may consider are:Â  (1) adequate shelter for minors; (2) the inability of the 
  occupying spouse to otherwise obtain adequate housing; (3) the size of the non-occupying 
  spouseâ€™s equity in the home relative to his other assets or income; (4) the 
  size of the home relative to the expected use and the cost of maintaining the 
  home in comparison to the benefits received; and (5) the potential duration 
  of the exclusive possession.Â  See Morris, 335 S.C. at 534, 517 
  S.E.2d at 725.Â  
The threshold issue in this case is whether the 
  award of the house to Wife is required to maintain her standard of living or 
  whether the award of the exclusive ownership of the house places too great of 
  a burden on Husband.Â  The trial judge concluded it was not essential to her 
  standard of living to remain in the house, and I agree.Â  
Factually, the house was acquired when the household 
  consisted of five persons, the parties and their three children. [1] Â  The children are now emancipated and are not a factor in considering 
  Wifeâ€™s needs.Â  The trial court properly allowed Wife the continued use of the 
  marital residence while the youngest child was still in high school.Â  
The house has five bedrooms, three and a half baths 
  and over 5000 square feet.Â  The trial court found that Wife had not demonstrated 
  she had any practical need for a home the size of the marital home now that 
  two children are completely emancipated.  
  [2] Â  The costs of ownership of a house that size for one person greatly 
  outweigh any need or benefit obtained from allowing Wife to retain the property.
There is no indication Wife cannot find a suitable 
  home in the same or similar neighborhood, while greatly reducing her monthly 
  housing expenses.Â  She testified that she enjoyed the safety offered by the 
  neighborhood and the ability to walk the neighborhood pathways.Â  However, she 
  also admitted that other neighborhoods could offer just as much and be just 
  as secure.Â  
The trial court reasoned that the parties could 
  sell the marital home and realize over $250,000 from its sale.Â  Expert testimony 
  provided that the parties could then split the equity and each could purchase 
  another home for approximately $250,000 paying $125,000 down, and thereafter 
  have housing expenses of approximately $1664.00 per month instead of the $4,441.00 
  per month expense on the marital home.Â  The court further concluded that unitizing 
  Wifeâ€™s claimed expenses and adding to them the $1664.00 projected housing expense, 
  her total expenses would be approximately $4,700.00 per month.Â  Finally, the 
  trial court concluded that by awarding Wife $875.00 per month in permanent alimony, 
  she would still have approximately $600 per month left after paying her expenses.Â  
  Wifeâ€™s share of the equity in the home, coupled with her income, alimony, and 
  the other assets she receives in the distribution will allow her to obtain more 
  than sufficient housing and maintain her standard of living.
Questions concerning alimony rest within 
  the sound discretion of the trial court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed 
  on appeal absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 
  351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs 
  when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based 
  upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.Â  McKnight v. McKnight, 
  283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1984). In appeals from family 
  court, the appellate court has authority to find facts in accordance with its 
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  However, when an appellate court 
  chooses to find facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence, the court 
  must state distinctly its findings of fact and the reason for its decision.Â  
  Dearybury, 351 S.C. at 283, 569 S.E.2d at 369.
Alimony is a substitute for the support 
  that is normally incident to the marital relationship.Â  Ordinarily, the purpose 
  of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as nearly as practical, in the 
  position of support he or she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Alimony should not 
  dissuade a spouse, to the extent possible, from becoming self-supporting.Â  McElveen 
  v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œWhere, 
  as here, a wife has been awarded a fair percentage of the marital estate, it 
  is error to award her permanent alimony substantially in excess of her needs.â€Â  
  Woodard v. Woodard, 294 S.C. 210, 217, 363 S.E.2d 413, 417 (Ct. App. 
  1987). Such an award â€œis in the nature of a division of the husbandâ€™s future 
  excess income.â€Â  Id.
The reason expressed by the majority for 
  increasing Wifeâ€™s alimony was to maintain her standard of living.Â  It became 
  clear during oral argument that but for the excessive mortgage payment Wife 
  would be burdened with if she remains in the marital home, there would be no 
  practical need for alimony in excess of the amount awarded by the trial court.Â  
  Thus, the result of the majorityâ€™s decision to award Wife the marital home is 
  to artificially create a need for additional alimony to pay the expenses on 
  the marital residence.Â  
Clearly, Husband was at fault in the breakup of 
  this marriage and should incur some penalty for his marital fault.Â  The trial 
  court provided significant marital assets to Wife and allowed her to maintain 
  her standard of living without the extravagance of a home that is too costly 
  for her needs.Â  The award by the majority is excessive and unnecessary given 
  her lifestyle and actual needs.Â  As the trial courtâ€™s order is structured, I 
  fail to see an abuse of discretion in its award of alimony and the required 
  sale of the marital home.Â  I would affirm those awards. 

 
   [1]  At time of trial, the court found that Wife, the 
    partiesâ€™ oldest child Zackery age 27, and a minor child lived in the home.Â  
    The court further found that all of the children had the benefit of educational 
    trusts, from inheritances.Â  Additionally, while Zackery suffered a head injury 
    as a child in an accident, he â€œis capable of sole support and has other resources 
    to rely upon for his support.â€ At oral argument, Wifeâ€™s counsel informed the 
    court that only Zackery continued to remain in the marital home. In any event 
    there is no contention that Wife should be awarded the marital home to accommodate 
    the partiesâ€™ children.

 
   [2]  The trial court concluded â€œ[t] his ruling does 
    not prevent [Wife] from buying [Husbandâ€™s] interest in the house (using the 
    agreed valuation) or on other terms mutually agreeable to them.â€

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
J. W. Hunt, Jr., and William R. Hunt,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Forestry Commission,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3767
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  29, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Robert E. Horner, of Columbia, for Appellant.
C. Kenneth Powell, J. Lewis Cromer and J. Philip Murphy, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  The South Carolina Forestry 
  Commission (â€œSCFCâ€) appeals an order of the trial court, which held that a deed 
  granted to the SCFC in 1937 conveying a ten-acre tract of land merely conveyed 
  a fee simple determinable with a possibility of reverter and not a fee simple 
  absolute.Â  We reverse. [1] 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 11, 1937, The First Carolinas Joint 
  Stock Land Bank of Columbia issued a deed to the SCFC granting the commission 
  ten acres of land for the consideration of one dollar.Â  
The granting clause of this deed reads:

The First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbiaâ€¦ [has] 
  granted, bargained, sold and released, and by these presents [does] grant, bargain, 
  sell and release unto the said [SCFC] and their successors in office all 
  that certain piece . . . .

(emphasis added).
The habendum clause provides:

To Have and to Hold all and singular the premises before mentioned 
  unto the said [SCFC] and their successors in office, and assigns forever.

(emphasis added).
Following a description of the property 
  conveyed to the SCFC, the deed states:

[T]his deed is upon the express condition that the grantee 
  shall with reasonable dispatch erect and maintain on said lands a suitable fire 
  tower or towers and suitable buildings for the keeper thereof, and use said 
  lands in furthering the cause of reforestation and forest protection, and should 
  the grantee at any time for a period of two years cease to use the property 
  aforesaid for said purposes the title thereto shall revert to the grantor, its 
  successors and assigns, provided, however, that in such case the grantee shall 
  have the right to remove any fire tower or towers or other buildings, if any 
  which the grantee may place on the said lands.

In 1941, The First Carolinas Joint 
  Stock Land Bank of Columbia sold a piece of property adjacent to the ten-acre 
  tract to Thomas Thain.Â  This deed to Thain intended to convey the reversionary 
  rights to the SCFCâ€™s ten-acre parcel.
By deed granted in 1943, Thain 
  conveyed various parcels of land to J.W. Hunt, Sr., including most of the tract 
  granted to Thain by the bank.Â  This deed purported to convey to J.W. Hunt, Sr., 
  the reversionary rights in the parcel at issue in this case.
Via an instrument entitled â€œDeed of Reversionary 
  Rightsâ€ dated March 30, 1984, J.W. Hunt, Sr., conveyed to J.W. Hunt, Jr., and 
  William R. Hunt (â€œRespondentsâ€) any interest he had received from Thain by the 
  1943 deed in the ten-acre parcel at issue.
In 1984, Respondents asked the 
  SCFC for a wider easement across the ten-acre tract for the purpose of allowing 
  trucks greater accessibility in harvesting the tractâ€™s lumber.Â  Prior to granting 
  Respondents an easement, however, the SCFC requested they execute an estoppel 
  agreement whereby Respondents agreed they would not use the easement extension 
  as a basis for arguing that the property had reverted to them.Â  This document 
  was drafted by Respondentsâ€™ attorney and was signed by Respondents.Â  The agreement 
  did not profess to bind the SCFC and was not signed by any agent of the State 
  of South Carolina or the SCFC.
With the advent of airplane surveillance, 
  the use of fire towers for forest protection became obsolete.Â  In 1993 and 1994, 
  the fire tower and accompanying buildings located on the ten-acre parcel were 
  removed.Â  The SCFC and Respondents undertook preparations to transfer the land 
  to Respondents.Â  After about a year and half of working with the SCFC on obtaining 
  the ten-acre tract, [2]  the SCFC informed Respondents that their attorneys believed 
  that Respondents had no valid interest in the property.Â  Based on the SCFCâ€™s 
  refusal to transfer the land, Respondents initiated an action seeking a grant 
  of clear title to the ten-acre parcel.
By order filed June 28, 2001, the trial 
  court found that the SCFC was the owner of the land in question.Â  Following 
  a hearing on Respondentsâ€™ motion to reconsider, however, the trial court withdrew 
  its initial order and filed a substitute order.Â  In the substituted order, the 
  trial court found that the deed granting the land to the SCFC conveyed only 
  a fee simple determinable with a possibility of reverter.Â  Furthermore, the 
  court found that the conditional fee had terminated in 1997. Nevertheless, the 
  order denied Respondentsâ€™ claim to legal title of the land due to the fact that 
  inter vivos transfers of reversionary rights are invalid and without 
  effect in South Carolina. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The construction of a clear and unambiguous 
  deed is a question of law for the court.Â  Gardner v. Mozingo, 293 S.C. 
  23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 392 (1987); Hammond v. Lindsay, 277 S.C. 182, 
  184, 284 S.E.2d 581, 582 (1981).Â  â€œ[I]t is the duty of the court to construe 
  deeds and determine their legal effect, where there is no such ambiguity as 
  requires parol proof and submission to the jury.â€Â  26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 
  168 (2001).Â  

Deeds are construed to determine the intent of the parties.Â  
  To construe a deed, a court looks first at the language of the instrument because 
  the court presumes it declares the intent of the parties.Â  When, and only when, 
  the meaning of a deed is not clear, or is ambiguous or uncertain, will a court 
  resort to established rules of construction to aid in the ascertainment of the 
  grantorâ€™s intention by artificial means where such intention cannot otherwise 
  be ascertained.

23 Am.Jur.2d Deeds Â§ 192 (2002).Â  â€œ[I]f the 
  language of the deed is unambiguous, then its interpretation is a question of 
  law to be resolved by the reviewing court without resort to extrinsic evidence.â€Â  
  Id.Â  While a trial courtâ€™s findings of fact in a nonjury action at law 
  should not be disturbed on appeal unless they are without evidentiary support, 
  a reviewing court is free to decide questions of law with no particular deference 
  to the trial court.Â  See Rickborn v. Liberty Life Ins. Co., 321 
  S.C. 291, 296, 468 S.E.2d 292, 295 (1996); Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church 
  of God, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000); see Okatie 
  River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 340 S.C. 367, 372, 532 
  S.E.2d 269, 272 (2000) (â€œIn an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate 
  court standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.â€); 
  State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co. v. Moorer, 330 S.C. 46, 51, 496 S.E.2d 
  875, 878 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œIn legal actions, our scope of review extends only 
  to the correction of errors of law.â€).Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
The SCFC argues that the 1937 deed granted it the 
  ten-acre tract in fee simple absolute; thus they are under no legal obligation, 
  no matter how the property is used, to transfer the tract to Respondents.Â  We 
  agree.
Respondents assert that the language following 
  the physical description of the property in the deed â€œcuts downâ€ the fee simple 
  conveyance of the granting clause to a fee simple determinable with a possibility 
  of reverter.Â  While this is certainly a sensible interpretation of this deed 
  when read in its entirety, this construction is nevertheless legally incorrect.Â  
  It is a well established rule of law that where the granting clause of a deed 
  purports to convey title in fee simple, the estate may not be cut down by subsequent 
  words in the same instrument.Â  Shealy v. South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co., 
  278 S.C. 132, 135, 293 S.E.2d 306, 308 (1982) (â€œWhere granting clause in deed 
  purports to convey fee simple absolute title, subsequent provisions of deed 
  cannot diminish that granted or deprive grantee of incidents of ownership in 
  property.â€); County of Abbeville v. Knox, 267 S.C. 38, 40, 225 S.E.2d 
  863, 864 (1976) (holding where the deed conveyed fee simple absolute estate 
  in its granting clause by use of words of inheritance, provision inserted in 
  deed after description of property, that property would be used for industrial 
  development, is not a condition subsequent; instead, deed would be construed 
  as conveying a fee simple absolute estate); Stylecraft, Inc. v. Thomas, 
  250 S.C. 495, 498, 159 S.E.2d 46, 47 (1968) (finding that â€œthe granting clause 
  conveyed a fee simple absolute; the restrictive words following the description 
  of the property were ineffectual to cut down that estateâ€).Â  Only if the granting 
  clause is deemed â€œindefinite,â€ may the court look to other parts of the deed 
  to ascertain the intent of the grantor.Â  See Batesburg-Leesville Sch. 
  Dist. No. 3 v. Tarrant, 293 S.C. 442, 445, 361 S.E.2d 343, 345 (Ct. App. 
  1987).
Respondents argue that the granting clause of the 
  1937 deed is indefinite due to the lack of the word â€œforever.â€Â  The granting 
  clause of the deed in question conveys the tract to the SCFC and â€œand their 
  successors in office.â€Â  Traditionally, the phrase â€œand their successors in office, 
  foreverâ€ is the classic language of inheritance used for granting a fee simple 
  absolute in land to a government entity.Â  See Hoogenboom v. City of 
  Beaufort, 315 S.C. 306, 316, 433 S.E.2d 875, 882 (Ct. App. 1992).Â Â Â  
To constitute a definite grant in fee simple absolute, 
  the granting clause of a deed must contain language of inheritance limiting 
  the grant to the intended grantee and his heirs.Â  McMichael v. McMichael, 
  51 S.C. 555, 557, 29 S.E. 403, 403 (1898); see also Wayburn 
  v. Smith, 270 S.C. 38, 42, 239 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1977) (â€œIt is the rule in 
  this State that where an incomplete or indefinite estate is conveyed by the 
  granting clause, as for instance where no words of inheritance accompany the 
  grant, or where the granting clause creates a life estate, resort may be had 
  to the habendum for the purpose of ascertaining the intention of the grantor 
  and thus a life estate may be enlarged into a fee simple estate.â€); Atl. 
  Coast Lumber Corp. v. Langston Lumber Co., 128 S.C. 7, 9, 122 S.E. 395, 
  396 (1924) (â€œA conveyance of real estate not carrying the word â€˜heirsâ€™ cannot 
  convey the fee.â€); Tarrant, 293 S.C. at 445, 361 S.E.2d at 345 (finding 
  an indefinite estate was conveyed by the granting clause because of the omission 
  of words of inheritance; and therefore, resort was had to the habendum clause 
  for the purpose of ascertaining the intent of the grantors).Â  This court is 
  unaware, however, of any authority requiring the inclusion of words of perpetuity 
  such as â€œforeverâ€ in a deedâ€™s granting clause.Â  On the contrary, when looking 
  at case law concerning deeds granting fee simple to individuals, it appears, 
  by analogy, that no such language is necessary.Â  See Antley v. Antley, 
  132 S.C. 306, 309, 128 S.E. 31, 32 (1925) (â€œA deed to one and his heirs grants 
  a fee-simple estate.â€).Â  When conveying property to a government entity, the 
  words â€œsuccessors in officeâ€ contemplate the same principle of inheritance that 
  â€œheirsâ€ would in a deed granted to an individual.Â  While the phrase â€œsuccessors 
  in officeâ€ is bolstered by the word â€œforever,â€ the word is not logically required 
  to communicate the required limitation on inheritance.Â  
Furthermore, in Shealy, the supreme court 
  held that the granting clause â€œgrant, bargain, sell and release unto the said 
  Lexington Water Power Company, its successors and assignsâ€ was a definite grant 
  of a fee simple estate.Â  278 S.C. at 134, 293 S.E.2d at 307.Â  The court did 
  so with no mention or record in its opinion of any words of perpetuity in the 
  deedâ€™s granting clause such as â€œforever.â€Â  We conclude, therefore, that the 
  word â€œforeverâ€ is not required in the granting clause of a deed for the clause 
  to constitute a definite grant of fee simple absolute.Â  
When reading the 1937 deed in its entirety, it 
  does appear that the grantor intended the property to revert on the occurrence 
  of certain circumstances set forth in the deed.Â  While it is a cardinal rule 
  of deed construction that the intention of the grantor must be ascertained and 
  effectuated, this intention cannot stand if it contravenes some well settled 
  rule of law or public policy.Â  Wayburn, 270 S.C. at 41, 239 S.E.2d at 
  892.Â  In a â€œlong and unbroken line of decisions,â€ South Carolina courts have 
  approved the rule that where the granting clause in a deed purports to convey 
  title in fee simple absolute, that estate may not be cut down by subsequent 
  words in the same instrument.Â  Stylecraft, 250 S.C. at 497, 159 S.E.2d 
  at 47; accord Shealy, 278 S.C. at 135, 293 S.E.2d at 308; Knox, 
  267 S.C. at 40, 225 S.E.2d at 864.Â  This court â€œwill not undertake to overthrow 
  a rule of property so long established.â€Â  Purvis v. McElveen, 234 S.C. 
  94, 102, 106 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1959).Â  This rule of construction must be adhered 
  to even if it runs contrary to the express intentions of the grantor.Â  Stylecraft, 
  250 S.C. at 497, 159 S.E.2d at 47.Â  This contention is best expressed in Creswell 
  v. Bank of Greenwood, 210 S.C. 47, 55, 41 S.E.2d 393, 397 (1947) (quoted 
  in Wayburn, 270 S.C. at 43, 239 S.E.2d at 892-93), as follows:

[I]ntention is unavailing to avoid [a rule of law] where 
  words of settled legal import are used and contrary principles are encountered.Â  
  In such cases the intention will be conclusively presumed to accord with the 
  established meaning of the words and to conform to the fixed rules of construction.Â  
  Otherwise, there would be little stability of land titles.

Upon finding that the granting clause of the 1937 deed constitutes 
  a definite grant in fee simple, this court must hold that the purpose clause 
  following the property description is ineffectual.Â  The SCFC, therefore, owns 
  the ten-acre parcel in fee simple absolute, notwithstanding any comments Mr. 
  Bumble may care to make on the matter. 
  [3] Â Â  
Alternatively, were we to assume arguendo that 
  the granting clause was indefinite, title in fee simple would still lie with 
  the SCFC.Â  It is the rule in this State that where an incomplete or indefinite 
  estate is conveyed by the granting clause, as in the instance where no words 
  of inheritance accompany the grant, resort may be had to the habendum clause 
  for the purpose of ascertaining the intention of the grantor.Â  Wayburn, 
  270 S.C. at 42, 239 S.E.2d at 892; Bean v. Bean, 253 S.C. 340, 343-44, 
  170 S.E.2d 654, 655-56 (1969).Â  The habendum clause of the deed in question 
  reads, â€œTo Have and to Hold all and singular the premises before mentioned unto 
  the said [SCFC] and their successors in office, and assigns forever.â€Â  
  When a habendum clause contains the traditional words of inheritance, it has 
  the effect of enlarging an indefinite granting clause into a fee simple.Â  Id.Â  
  Thus, any indefiniteness in the granting clause of the 1937 deed in question 
  is cured by the language utilized in the deedâ€™s habendum clause.
Respondents assert, as an additional sustaining 
  ground, that the SCFC is estopped from contesting Respondentsâ€™ ownership of 
  the land.Â  We find that Respondents have abandoned this issue.Â  Respondentsâ€™ 
  cite no authority to support their contention that the actions of the SCFC warrant 
  a finding of estoppel.Â  Issues raised in a brief but not supported by authority 
  are deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal.Â  See In 
  re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 92, 551 S.E.2d 235, 238 (2001).
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the order of 
  the trial court is
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Initially, the SCFC helped facilitate this transfer of title to Respondents.Â  
    The parties agreed to what needed to be done prior to this transfer (e.g., 
    survey the land, establish proof of a clear chain of title, etc.) and agreed 
    to split the costs. 

 
   [3]  In discussing this rule of law, the trial judge 
    referenced the characterâ€™s quote â€œIf the law supposes that, â€¦ the lawâ€™s a 
    ass â€“ a idiot.â€Â  Charles Dickens, Oliver Twist, Chapter 51.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Joseph Michael Austin and Sandra Austin,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Specialty Transportation Services, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3768
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  29, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
A. Todd Darwin, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Gene Adams and Robert E. Davis, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Joseph Michael Austin and Sandra Austin (collectively, 
  â€œRespondentsâ€) brought an action against Specialty Transportation Services, 
  Inc. (Appellant) and its employee, Walter Ray Bishop, in connection with an 
  automobile accident.Â  Respondents obtained an entry of default against Bishop 
  and Appellant. [1] Â  The trial 
  court awarded actual and punitive damages to Respondents.Â  We affirm. 
  [2] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On November 18, 1999, Respondents were seriously injured in 
  an automobile accident when a tractor-trailer truck driven by Appellantâ€™s employee 
  hit their vehicle.Â  Respondents were traveling south on U.S. 29, and the truck 
  was approaching U.S. 29 from an Interstate 85 exit ramp.Â  A stop sign controlled 
  the truckâ€™s lane of traffic.Â  However, the driver of the truck failed to yield 
  the right of way to Respondentsâ€™ vehicle.Â  The truck entered U.S. 29 and struck 
  Respondentsâ€™ vehicle.
Joseph was trapped in the vehicle for more than an hour.Â  
  While Joseph was in the car, he was in tremendous pain, his leg was broken in 
  such a way that it was resting between his left shoulder and cheek, and he feared 
  he would burn to death.Â  Joseph sustained injuries to his lower back, neck, 
  right shoulder, right elbow, right leg, and right ankle.Â  Joseph was hospitalized 
  until December 1, 1999.Â  During his hospitalization, Joseph had surgeries on 
  his leg and received counseling for depression.Â  Joseph underwent two additional 
  surgeries after his release from the hospital and endured painful rehabilitation.Â  
  Joseph described his injuries and resulting pain, including how they have altered 
  his life:

[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Did you have immediate problems in all of those areas 
  [right knee, right leg, neck, hands, and fingers] after the accident on November 
  18, 1999?
[Joseph]:Â  The leg was very evident that it was broken, and I had again a long 
  period of that.Â  I complained fairly early about my neck but everybody seemed 
  to be more concerned about the leg healing and basically being bedridden.Â  I 
  wasnâ€™t using my arm so I assumed that back problem or the neck problem wasnâ€™t 
  really apparent.
. . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Now, Joe what was the state of your fitness prior to 
  the accident?Â  Did you exercise regularly, walk, jog and things like that?
[Joseph]:Â  Yes.Â  My download, or my basically the way Iâ€”instead of other people 
  have different ways of relieving stress.Â  My stress reliever is to walk behind 
  our house.Â  We had a place about a mile and a half down to a dam, on your way 
  you visit like hanging rock and then down to the dam, then you cross the river 
  and then you basically backtrack a different trial [sic], which the about the 
  same length, that was a daily ritual.Â  Cutting the grass, cutting the bushes, 
  pretty muchâ€”we built a deck on the back of our house, me and Sandra.Â  We decided 
  we wanted a deck so we built a deck.
Anything I wanted to do.Â  We were going every weekend.Â  If we wanted 
  to go somewhere we would pack the car and just go.Â  Jonathan was in the Grand 
  Canyon at eight months.Â  It just all changed.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Joe, have you made that walk down to the river since 
  the accident occurred?
[Joseph]:Â  No, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Can you make that walk now?
[Joseph]:Â  No, sir.
 . . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  When you came to [after the accident], Joe, what configuration 
  were you in?Â  
[Joseph]:Â  Well, I was laying kind of over and I was looking basically at the 
  sole of my shoe of my right leg and I was wondering, â€œWell, how in the heck 
  was that there.â€
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Where was that?Â  Show the Judge with your hand.
[Joseph]:Â  Basically, it was laying kind of here.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Youâ€™re showing on your left shoulder between your left 
  shoulder and your cheek.
[Joseph]:Â  Yes, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Were you able to move as if to get out of the car?
[Joseph]:Â  No.Â  Because the door had pressed in on me, and all I could see was 
  my foot and what I thought was blood everywhere, it was coffee from my wifeâ€™s 
  coffee.Â  And all of the sudden this blue flame shot in and smoke started rolling 
  in and I looked at my wife and told her to get away from the car.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  What were your thoughts when the blue flame rolled 
  through?
[Joseph]:Â  I thought I was going to burn to death.
. . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  What goes through your mind?Â  What went through your 
  mind?
[Joseph]: Itâ€™s just a lot of pain, discomfort, question and confusion whatâ€™s 
  happened.Â  At time an EMS person hops in the back seat and they start basically 
  taking my clothes off with the scissors and stabbing me with a needle.Â  Again, 
  it wasâ€”I was trying to get out with the good leg but the good leg was actually 
  trapped underneath the console of the car and this leg just over here.
. . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  . . . Were you on any pain medication?Â  When did you 
  first receive pain medication if you know?
[Joseph]:Â  . . . And I remember a doctor [in the Emergency Room] saying, â€œSon, 
  can I take a look at that leg please?â€
And I let go and he basically pulled it out and I must have passed out from 
  the pain because when I woke back up they were still doing similar things.Â  
  I was trembling, it was cold and they wouldnâ€™t get me any medication because 
  they thought I had internal bleeding.
. . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Tell us about your neck and back, Joe.Â  What problems 
  do you have with your neck and arm?
[Joseph]:Â  Basically, it stiffens up.Â  Like the tingles in the hands, if I drive 
  long distances with arms elevated basically I lose my grip capability, ability 
  of gripping or stiff gripping.Â  I can still grip like if the object is as big 
  as this I can grab it but if itâ€™s as small as a steering wheel on my car itâ€™s 
  hard.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Do you have pain in your neck and back?
[Joseph]:Â  Yes, sir, thereâ€™s pain.Â  Thatâ€™s kind of become a thing that you have 
  everyday.Â  When you get up in the morning itâ€™s either the leg, itâ€™s the foot, 
  itâ€™s the back itâ€™s the beck [sic], itâ€™s the arms, itâ€™s the fingers.
. . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  And are you in pain on a daily basis in your leg?
[Joseph]:Â  Yes, sir, neck and pack [sic].

Josephâ€™s orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Michael Wayne Funderburk, estimates Joseph 
  will require surgery on his knee every two to five years for the remainder of 
  his life.Â  Dr. Funderburk assessed a forty percent permanent impairment to Josephâ€™s 
  lower right extremity.Â  Joseph has $170,010.62 in present and future medical 
  bills.Â  At trial, Dr. Funderburk discussed Josephâ€™s present and future condition:

[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  All right, sir.Â  Tell us about 
  his course of recovery after that, Doctor.
[Funderburk]:Â  Well, heâ€™s done very well for this fracture 
  in my opinion.Â  He certainly has a painful situation as far as his kneecap, 
  and this is because of extensive muscle trauma as well as the damage to the 
  inside of the knee.Â  Thereâ€™s a lot of scarring and limited mobility over that 
  segment, which worsens the arthritic problem underneath that kneecap because 
  thereâ€™s so much tethering from the muscle damage and the damage to the kneecap 
  proper.
We have subsequently performed arthroscopy surgery and debridement 
  of this, with some benefit.Â  I think that this is going to be a progressive 
  problem for him unfortunately.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Well, will he require, in your professional judgment, 
  debridement surgery in the future for that knee?
[Funderburk]:Â  Yes, I do believe he will.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  How often will he require that in your judgement, Doctor?
[Funderburk]:Â  You know, I think that as the arthritis and as the debris within 
  the knee builds up he may need this every two years to clean the knee out.Â  
  The only other option you have is to replace the knee.Â  And I think in someone 
  this age you would hope that you could use conservative means to try to keep 
  this knee as long as you could before you performed a replacement type surgery 
  on him.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  This condition that he has in the knee underneath the 
  kneecap, is that a painful condition?
[Funderburk]:Â  It is.
. . . .
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Okay.Â  Tell us aboutâ€”you said [Joe has] pain in the 
  neck and also some tingling or pain into the hands.Â  Tell us what that comes 
  from.
[Funderburk]:Â  Well, anytime thereâ€™s swelling or problems around the neck from 
  degenerative changes or disk problems there can be neurological symptoms or 
  nerve pain down into the hands with numbness being one of the common findings 
  into the arms from the neck.Â  
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Okay.Â  Are these permanent conditions?
[Funderburk]:Â  They are.Â  They can be progressive conditions that can worsen.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Is it fair to say theyâ€™re not going to get any better?
[Funderburk]:Â  I donâ€™t believe they are.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Okay.Â  Now Doctor, do you believe that Joe has sustained 
  a permanent injury to his legâ€”his lower right extremity?
[Funderburk]:Â  Yes, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Do you have an opinion as to the percent disability 
  he sustained to his lower right extremity?
[Funderburk]:Â  Iâ€™ve rated him at forty percent permanent 
  impairment to this extremity.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  And that rating is based upon what consideration?
[Funderburk]:Â  That rating is based upon the consideration on limitation of 
  motion, the arthritis I know is going to occur within this knee as well as the 
  limitation of motion and pain in the right foot as well.Â  I felt that with the 
  progressive problems within the right knee as well as the permanency to the 
  right foot that this was a rating that I gave to his leg.

Sandra suffered injuries 
  to her breast, right hand, and neck.Â  She incurred $57,460.58 in liquidated 
  actual damages.Â  Sandra detailed her injuries:

Basically I had a large bruise 
  over my left breast.Â  I ended up having, just from the force of the accident, 
  issues with my right hand.Â  It made it hard to pick up things, I broke dishes, 
  cookware, that kind of thing, and just issues with fine detail.Â  I had troubleâ€”actually 
  when they asked me to sign the informed consent I was hurting signing the informed 
  consent.Â  I had difficulty holding the pen to do, that kind, plus I had some 
  issues in the neck.

Sandra, who is a registered nurse, 
  cared for Joseph twenty-four hours a day for many months.Â  During this time, 
  Sandra missed work and lost several bonuses.Â  Sandra enunciated:

[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  In addition to the fact that 
  you were under medical treatment, was there any other reason you had to be home 
  during that period of time?
[Sandra]:Â  Yes.Â  Part of the stipulation for Joeâ€™s dismissal at the hospital 
  was that I would not work and be there for twenty-four hour care giver [sic].Â  
  That was the agreement that we made with the physician to discharge my husband.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]: When Joe was discharged from the hospital, was he discharged 
  bedridden?
[Sandra]:Â  Yes, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Was he discharged in traction?
[Sandra]:Â  Yes, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]: Was that twenty-four hours a day? [Sandra]: Â Yes, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]: Was Joe able to get out of bed? [Sandra]:Â  No, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]: Was Joe able to go to the bathroom?
[Sandra]:Â  No, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]: Was Joe even able to use a potty seat?
[Sandra]:Â  No, sir.
[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Did you have to do all of that for him?
[Sandra]:Â  Yes, sir. 

Sandra testified the accident has substantially changed her 
  familyâ€™s lives: 

[Respondentsâ€™ Counsel]:Â  Now, how is Joe doing now, Sandra? 
[Sandra]:Â  We learn to live with it.Â  Heâ€™s still depressed.Â  Heâ€™s not the same 
  guy fourteen years ago.

On February 11, 2002, Respondents obtained an entry 
  of default against the driver of the truck and Appellant.Â  After a combined 
  hearing on the issues of relief from default and damages, the trial court denied 
  Appellantâ€™s motion for relief from default and awarded actual and punitive damages 
  to Respondents.Â  The trial judge awarded Joseph $850,000 in actual damages and 
  $2,158,000 in punitive damages.Â  He awarded Sandra $175,000 in actual damages 
  and $442,000 in punitive damages.Â  Appellant filed a motion to alter or amend 
  the judgment.Â  In response, Respondents filed a motion to open the judgment.Â  
  The trial court denied Appellantâ€™s motion and granted Respondentsâ€™ motion.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The trial judge has considerable discretion regarding the amount of damages, 
  both actual or punitive.Â  Collins Entmâ€™t Corp. v. Coats & Coats Rental 
  Amusement, 355 S.C. 125, 584 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 2003); Kuznik v. Bees 
  Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 538 S.E.2d 15 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Because of 
  this discretion, our review on appeal is limited to the correction of errors 
  of law.Â  Kuznik, 342 S.C. at 611, 538 S.E.2d at 32; Welch v. Epstein, 
  342 S.C. 279, 536 S.E.2d 408 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Our task in reviewing a damages 
  award is not to weigh the evidence, but to determine if there is any evidence 
  to support the damages award.Â  See Hutson v. Cummins Carolinas, Inc., 
  280 S.C. 552, 314 S.E.2d 19 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  AMOUNT OF DAMAGE AWARDS
Appellant argues the evidence in the record does 
  not support the trial courtâ€™s excessive damage awards to Respondents.Â  We review 
  the damage awards separately and distinctly.
A.Â  Actual Damages
Being mindful of the standard of review in the present case, which does not 
  require this Court to weigh the evidence, but merely determine if there is any 
  evidence to support the damage awards, we find the amounts of actual damages 
  awarded to Joseph and Sandra were proper.Â  See Hutson v. Cummins Carolinas, 
  Inc., 280 S.C. 552, 314 S.E.2d 19 (Ct. App. 1984).
Actual damages are properly called compensatory damages, meaning 
  to compensate, to make the injured party whole, to put him in the same position 
  he was in prior to the damages received insofar as this is monetarily possible.Â  
  See Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000).Â  Actual 
  damages are awarded to a litigant in compensation for his actual loss or injury.Â  
  Laird v. Nationwide Ins. Co., 243 S.C. 388, 134 S.E.2d 206 (1964).Â  Actual 
  damages are such as will compensate the party for injuries suffered or losses 
  sustained.Â  Id.Â  They are such damages as will simply make good or replace 
  the loss caused by the wrong or injury.Â  Actual damages are damages in satisfaction 
  of, or in recompense for, loss or injury sustained.Â  Barnwell v. Barber-Colman 
  Co., 301 S.C. 534, 393 S.E.2d 162 (1989).Â  The goal is to restore the injured 
  party, as nearly as possible through the payment of money, to the same position 
  he was in before the wrongful injury occurred.Â  Clark, 339 S.C. at 378, 
  529 S.E.2d at 533.
Actual or compensatory damages include compensation for all injuries 
  which are naturally the proximate result of the alleged wrongful conduct of 
  the defendant.Â  See Rogers v. Florence Printing Co., 233 S.C. 
  567, 106 S.E.2d 258 (1958).Â  The basic measure of actual damages is the amount 
  needed to compensate the plaintiff for the losses proximately caused by the 
  defendantâ€™s wrong so that the plaintiff will be in the same position he would 
  have been in if there had been no wrongful injury.Â  See Rogers, 
  233 S.C. at 578, 106 S.E.2d at 264; Hutchison v. Town of Summerville, 
  66 S.C. 442, 45 S.E. 8 (1903).
The trial court awarded $850,000 in actual damages to Joseph.Â  Joseph presented 
  uncontested evidence of a total of $170,010.62 in present and future medical 
  bills.Â  He testified as to his extreme pain and suffering, impaired ability 
  to work, and loss of enjoyment of life.Â  Joseph underwent four surgeries and 
  is expected to receive surgery every two years for the remainder of his life.Â  
  In addition, his doctor rated Joseph as having a forty percent permanent 
  impairment to his lower right extremity. 
The trial court awarded $175,000 in actual damages to Sandra.Â  Sandra 
  presented uncontested evidence of $57,460.58 in liquidated actual damages.Â  
  She testified as to the leave she took from her job as a registered nurse in 
  order to care for Joseph twenty-four hours a day for many months.
We find Joseph and Sandra presented sufficient evidence to support the trial 
  courtâ€™s actual damage awards.
B.Â  Propriety of Punitive Damages
Appellant contends the trial court erred in awarding 
  any punitive damages, as they were not supported by the record and are based 
  on improper considerations.Â  We disagree.
Punitive damages, also known as exemplary 
  damages, are imposed as punishment.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 
  529 S.E.2d 528 (2000).Â  Punitive damages are allowed in the interest of society 
  in the nature of punishment and as a warning and example to deter the wrongdoer 
  and others from committing like offenses in the future.Â  Id.Â  Moreover, 
  they serve to vindicate a private right by requiring the wrongdoer to pay money 
  to the injured party.Â  Id.
Punitive damages serve at least three important 
  purposes: (1) punishment of the defendantâ€™s reckless, willful, wanton, or malicious 
  conduct; (2) deterrence of similar future conduct by the defendant or others; 
  and (3) compensation for the reckless or willful invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s 
  private rights.Â  Id.Â  The paramount purpose for awarding punitive damages 
  is not to compensate the plaintiff but to punish and set an example for others.
On the issue of punitive damages, the highest
